full_content:
New article – Wade Caves on ‘Finding Fortuna’
Skyscript
22 October
3
As a follow-up to the recent member presentation Wade Caves gave on whether or not it’s necessary to reverse the Part of Fortune by night, he has now written a short, well informed article drawing together and highlighting the key points he discussed.

The full video of his presentation (now on YouTube) is embedded at the end of the article, so anyone can read and watch together for a complete view of his argument.

The article is available on the Skyscript website:
• Read the article: https://www.skyscript.co.uk/fortuna.html
• Watch the recording: https://youtu.be/OEjwYV0jj_c?si=6OUI5DwK6ZaLoTZ8&t=269
A new discussion area has also been set up in the Skyscript forum for anyone who’d like to comment or explore the issue further:
https://www.skyscript.co.uk/forums/viewtopic.php?p=133786

content_blocks.text: Cardan’s De Exemplis

Casebooks – collections of astrologers’ own examples – give us a glimpse of how symbolism was handled in practice, though such records are rare before the later tradition. One of the most fascinating comes from the 16th-century astrologer Gerolamo Cardano.In this talk we explore some of the horoscopes he recorded, seeing how he worked with charts in practice and how his choices were shaped by the world he lived in. We also consider how, half a millennium later, we can engage with his insights and see what they still have to say to us today.Simão Cortêsis a Portuguese astrologer and teacher now based in Canterbury, UK, where he is completing his PhD. He works in horary and natal astrology, specialising in remedial techniques. He trained withCEIAand theCompany of Astrologers. He holds an MA in Myth, Cosmology and the Sacred fromCanterbury Christ Church University, where he wrote on the pedagogy of astrology. He is founder ofDuranki, a community devoted to astrology, magic, and dream work. He teaches in multiple countries and recently translated Geoffrey Cornelius’sThe Moment of Astrologyinto Portuguese.Date: Thursday, 13 November 2025starting at –8:30 pm UTC← click this to see the time for you

If you want to go straight to the showreel for this and the previous EPM recording, go here:
https://vimeopro.com/stapresenter/epm
Add in the password - (add password: Merlin)
Important announcement (!)
Do not watch The White Princess!
Apologies to anyone who started watching this drama series last night, based on my insistence that you must watch it. This morning I woke up with the shocking realisation that it’s not The White Princess you should be watching – it’s The White Queen.
So, to clarify: do not watch The White Princess. You may watch it if you wish to, but first watch The White Queen – that is, if you want to follow my advice, free of the error I made yesterday when I gave you the wrong title.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_White_Queen_(TV_series)
Google - where to watch link
Why watch? It’s a romanticised drama series but very engaging and for the most part historically accurate. It vividly covers the political background to the Wars of the Roses, that rich period of English history which gives context to many of the events Lilly refers to in his 15-century Saturn–Jupiter conj. Charts.
It turns hard-to-place historical figures into characters you can relate to and remember – which will enhance your understanding of Shakespeare (if you care about such things) and allow you to discuss English history with the semblance of expertise while skipping the degree. Also, we have a great article coming up in our next Journal by John Dawson, exploring the marriage election of Richard III and Anne Neville – so this will make that more interesting for you too.

Not sure? Here's a 3 min flash of what to expect

I will endeavour to get ahead of the handouts with more time to spare for the next meeting. 

By then you need to have completed the White Queen because we move on to Lilly’s exploration of natal charts for the Tudors, starting with Henry VIII. (Spoiler alert: the Tudors win at the end of the White Queen). 

Before that, mark your calendars for our next guest speaker event on 13 November with Simão Cortês - see you then!

Cardan’s De Exemplis
Casebooks – collections of astrologers’ own examples – give us a glimpse of how symbolism was handled in practice, though such records are rare before the later tradition. One of the most fascinating comes from the 16th-century astrologer Gerolamo Cardano.
In this talk we explore some of the horoscopes he recorded, seeing how he worked with charts in practice and how his choices were shaped by the world he lived in. We also consider how, half a millennium later, we can engage with his insights and see what they still have to say to us today.


Simão Cortês is a Portuguese astrologer and teacher now based in Canterbury, UK, where he is completing his PhD. He works in horary and natal astrology, specialising in remedial techniques. He trained with CEIA and the Company of Astrologers. He holds an MA in Myth, Cosmology and the Sacred from Canterbury Christ Church University, where he wrote on the pedagogy of astrology. He is founder of Duranki, a community devoted to astrology, magic, and dream work. He teaches in multiple countries and recently translated Geoffrey Cornelius’s The Moment of Astrology into Portuguese.

content_blocks.html: For anyone who wasn’t able to attend Wade’s talk Finding Fortuna on Thursday 9th October, the recording is now available here in this post. It’s also linked into the Members Area, together with the other showreels available there.

content_blocks.text: Wade’s presentation examined the origin of the split opinion on whether the Part of Fortune should be reversed in nocturnal charts. Considering the major role that this part plays in many astrological techniques this is a matter of considerable significance.
content_blocks.html: Wade’s presentation examined the origin of the split opinion on whether the Part of Fortune should be reversed in nocturnal charts. Considering the major role that this part plays in many astrological techniques this is a matter of considerable significance.

content_blocks.text: After the talk I asked Wade if he might be willing to summarise the key points in an accessible article that could be shared on Skyscript, linking to the full video for those who want deeper context. I’m happy to say he’s agreed, and we hope to publish that before the end of the month. Once it’s up, I’ll also open a public Skyscript forum post so that this issue can be discussed more broadly amongst the community, with an opportunity for further input and exploration.

For those who missed Wade Caves’ presentation on Fortuna
Skyscript
11 October
10
3
For anyone who wasn’t able to attend Wade’s talk Finding Fortuna on Thursday 9th October, the recording is now available here in this post. It’s also linked into the Members Area, together with the other showreels available there.
Wade’s presentation examined the origin of the split opinion on whether the Part of Fortune should be reversed in nocturnal charts. Considering the major role that this part plays in many astrological techniques this is a matter of considerable significance.
After the talk I asked Wade if he might be willing to summarise the key points in an accessible article that could be shared on Skyscript, linking to the full video for those who want deeper context. I’m happy to say he’s agreed, and we hope to publish that before the end of the month. Once it’s up, I’ll also open a public Skyscript forum post so that this issue can be discussed more broadly amongst the community, with an opportunity for further input and exploration.

Upcoming events
Remember to check the Members Area for details of all past and upcoming events and publications.
We will meet again at 8.30 pm UTC on Sunday 19th October for the second meeting of the England’s Prophetical Merlin Reading Group.
Our next speaker presentation will take place on Thursday 13th November, when Simão Cortês will discuss some of the horoscopes and judgements recorded in the casebooks of Jerome Cardan.
Simão Cortês is a Portuguese astrologer and teacher now based in Canterbury, UK, where he is completing his PhD. He works in horary and natal astrology, specialising in remedial techniques. He trained with CEIA and the Company of Astrologers. He holds an MA in Myth, Cosmology and the Sacred from Canterbury Christ Church University, where he wrote on the pedagogy of astrology. He is founder of Duranki, a community devoted to astrology, magic, and dream work. He teaches in multiple countries and recently translated Geoffrey Cornelius’s The Moment of Astrology into Portuguese.

content_blocks.author: Georgius
content_blocks.text:
Hm, I am not convinced of Wades’ description. Maybe I missed something, maybe my knowledge is too poor. But…

First, why should the Ascendant be an Acendant of the Sun? Everything is ascending at the Ascendant not only the Sun.

Second, why was the difference measured from the Sun to the Moon first of all? What were the thoughts behind this formula?

Third, the Sun is the leading light at day, the Moon is it by night, so it seems to be natural to change the formula according to sect.

content_blocks.author: Skyscript
content_blocks.text:
Hi Georgius

You might have noticed in the post I recently circulated that Wade has agreed to write an accompanying commentary about this for the site. I hope to publish that soon and open a public discussion area in the Skyscript forum. But since Wade doesn’t have easy access to these comments, let me offer a few of my own thoughts for what they’re worth.

On your first point – why should the Ascendant be of the Sun when everything rises there? I think there’s an intrinsic relationship between the Sun and the Ascendant, and a counter-relationship between the Moon and the Descendant, which is quite widely acknowledged in historical and traditional texts. Think about the principle of the Sun astrologically: it signifies life and vitality, while the absence of its light symbolises decline and death. These are exactly the principles embedded into the symbolism of those points – the Ascendant representing life and emergence, and the Descendant representing retreat and the turning inward of energy.

As for your second question – why measure from the Sun to the Moon? I can’t say I know the full reasoning behind the formula, but it makes sense to me that the Part of Fortune marks the phase relationship between the Sun and Moon. When we speak about lunar phases today, we describe the Moon’s position in relation to the Sun – its distance *from* it – not the distance it has left to travel before rejoining it. We say, for example, that the Moon is in its waxing square from the Sun, not that it has “three squares to go” before reunion. The measurement naturally flows from the Sun as the source to the Moon as the emitter, and that may well be the symbolic logic at work.

Your final point about sect is interesting. I imagin many astrologers will feel it’s natural to reverse the formula according to sect, but is it really? Or has that just become habit through recent custom and practice? I can’t think of any other area of astrology where sect makes us *reverse a calculation* – where we’d say, “in this situation, add; in that situation to obtain *the same point*, subtract”. Usually sect shifts emphasis, rather than invert calculation. So I’d say it feels more consistent to keep the same formula for both, while acknowledging that each has its counterpoint – as the Part of Fortune does with the Part of Spirit. Once we start both reversing and pairing everything, it becomes unnecessarily tangled and, to me, rather unnatural.

Anyway, those are just some casual reflections. I’m not too invested in the debate – in fact, I’ve always felt that the use of too many lots is generally over-extended, and that the planets themselves give us a stronger, more reliable framework. But it’s a worthwhile topic, and I hope we’ll continue it when the new discussion thread opens.

title: A Medieval Horary: Ganivetus’ Sick Man - & October Update

content_blocks.text: A Medieval Horary: Ganivetus’ Sick Man - & October Update
Skyscript
2 October
content_blocks.html: 2 October

content_blocks.text: Today I completed my translation of ‘The Sick Man Horary’ by Ganivetus. Parts of this will be going up on Skyscript, but I’ve included a much fuller piece here for members. This version includes both the Latin and English translation, along with the front matter that leads into the judgement. In this, Ganivetus discusses the signification of disease, sets out some general principles, and then develops his judgement of the illness.
content_blocks.html: Today I completed my translation of ‘The Sick Man Horary’ by Ganivetus. Parts of this will be going up on Skyscript, but I’ve included a much fuller piece here for members. This version includes both the Latin and English translation, along with the front matter that leads into the judgement. In this, Ganivetus discusses the signification of disease, sets out some general principles, and then develops his judgement of the illness.

content_blocks.text: Although I always had a sense that this horary would be fascinating, it wasn’t until I reached the end of it today that I realised how dramatic its conclusion is. I want to give you a trigger warning for that, and advise you to brace yourself. Overall though, I strongly recommend you make time for this – it’s loaded with points of significance, whether your interest is horary, decumbiture, traditional technique, health matters, medieval history, or simply the power of astrological symbolism in action. But be prepared for that ending – it really does come as a shock.

content_blocks.author: Leena Chauhan
content_blocks.text:
There’s a ton of stark general death symbolism in this chart. A malefic-ruled sign rises, one malefic is on the ASC and co-signifies the sick man, the other malefic - the querent’s significator - is on the 8th cusp of death and disposed by the 8th ruler. The Moon applies tightly to Lord of the 8th, and the 8th house itself is packed. 

There’s also death symbolism more tailored to this story. Mars, the exalted chart ruler’s application to the ASC is testimony for the sick servant causing his own death. The afflicted Moon's applying square to the Sun, the 8th Lord, echoes that, and also signifies a junior person initiating strife with a boss figure (not that I saw that coming).

Mercury, as 6th ruler, is a general significator for a servant and is combust, retrograde, has separated from an afflicted Moon and is reversing into grim reaper Saturn. More pointers to death.

A midheaven at a mid-degree of Scorpio with exalted Mars rising promises this is not going to end well. The Mercury-Mars themes suggest illness of the mind and violence - but I never would have guessed how this turned out...

content_blocks.author: Skyscript
content_blocks.text: Agreed, Ganivet recognised the Mercury-Mars themes very well, and saw the intensity and concern in the situation, but I imagine even he was shocked when he learned how it ended.  I think there are interesting testimonied onhow the death was self-inflicted in the end.

content_blocks.author: Jane
content_blocks.text:
That was a very interesting horary Deb, thanks for it. I was really struck by Ganivet's approach to the chart; he reads it (as far as I can tell) as an event chart about a possible death. Even though the questioner asked about his brother's servant Ganivet makes no attempt to identify the brother or the servant in the chart; its all about a 'death event' and the circumstances surrounding it.

Have to bite my tongue to hold back on the obvious dark humour pun....

content_blocks.author: Skyscript
content_blocks.text:
I see it as a legitimate horary myself, and Ganivet certainly treats it that way. He’s quite specific about there being two possible approaches – one from the timing of an event, the other from a question – and he does use the word “question” in the Latin. His judgement is framed around a question which was expressed in his text, so it all fits well with our understanding of what a horary fundamentally is.

But the thing is, when you get trained in judicial astrology technique, the application of them doesn’t lead to a lot of difference, whether you apply them to a horary chart, a consultation chart, a commencement chart, a decumbiture chart, or an event chart. We’re basically using the same approach. With a horary, I don’t think it’s necessary here for him to try to turn the chart to identify the sick man as the servant of the querent’s brother. As Lilly explains in CA, if the question is about life or death for someone, and neither the querent nor their brother are directly involved, there’s no need to span the significations out like that. We can go straight to seeing the chart as immediately relevant for the person it concerns. This is in line with what Lilly teaches and does – if the matter doesn’t involve an enemy or a relationship where another party plays a central role, we can attach the signification of the person directly to the Ascendant and let the whole chart speak of them.

BTW, for my own interest I did look at charts for around 8 a.m., when the frenzied episode began. At that time Mars was very strong and angular, exactly on the IC - two hours later (around the time of death), the Part of Fortune, the Part of Death, and Saturn were all angular on the Midheaven. The times he gives are too imprecise to use formally, but they did make a lot of sense of the anger and drama, and then the very (let's not say the word) end.

content_blocks.author: Georgius
content_blocks.text: Very dramatic. I have not seen this kind of death.

content_blocks.author: Skyscript
content_blocks.text: Its a rare one - LOL - the tradition has not captured rules for this particular eventuality

content_blocks.author: Drums
content_blocks.text: "What would be the end of his illness, death or recovery? For which the figure of heaven thus fell over Vienne at the time of the question." Beautiful 💞.  More beautiful than the ending...I can't imagine 'recovering' him was much fun.

content_blocks.author: Janice Holmes
content_blocks.text: Thanks for all your hard work in bringing this story to light for us Deb. I read it in the small hours as suggested. Nobody could have predicted that ending. Chilling!

content_blocks.author: Georgius
content_blocks.text: Ganivetus predicted it quite exactly. Not all of it but with more details than I did.

A Medieval Horary: Ganivetus’ Sick Man - & October Update
Skyscript
2 October
8
11
Today I completed my translation of ‘The Sick Man Horary’ by Ganivetus. Parts of this will be going up on Skyscript, but I’ve included a much fuller piece here for members. This version includes both the Latin and English translation, along with the front matter that leads into the judgement. In this, Ganivetus discusses the signification of disease, sets out some general principles, and then develops his judgement of the illness.
Although I always had a sense that this horary would be fascinating, it wasn’t until I reached the end of it today that I realised how dramatic its conclusion is. I want to give you a trigger warning for that, and advise you to brace yourself. Overall though, I strongly recommend you make time for this – it’s loaded with points of significance, whether your interest is horary, decumbiture, traditional technique, health matters, medieval history, or simply the power of astrological symbolism in action. But be prepared for that ending – it really does come as a shock.
Updating the upcoming …
A couple of days ago I circulated advance details of our next event on the 9th of October. My apologies, that event is changing in theme. There are reasons behind this (not just me being mutable), but the original topic will be rescheduled for later in the programme.
Instead, Wade Caves will be presenting an important talk on a very pertinent issue. Almost all astrologers make use of the Part of Fortune in some way, yet there’s a sharp split within its doctrine that affects its calculation by night. Why is this, and is it possible to resolve? Wade will be exploring this in a thoughtful, well-researched presentation expected to last about 75 minutes.
I still need to finish the updated preparations for that talk, so details will be uploaded to the members’ area tomorrow. I’ll also send a reminder with full information early next week.

Enjoy this rather dark medieval horary – it would be best read in the next few hours, as the Moon applies to Mars in Scorpio.

I see it as a legitimate horary myself, and Ganivet certainly treats it that way. He’s quite specific about there being two possible approaches – one from the timing of an event, the other from a question – and he does use the word “question” in the Latin. His judgement is framed around a question which was expressed in his text, so it all fits well with our understanding of what a horary fundamentally is.

But the thing is, when you get trained in judicial astrology technique, the application of them doesn’t lead to a lot of difference, whether you apply them to a horary chart, a consultation chart, a commencement chart, a decumbiture chart, or an event chart. We’re basically using the same approach. With a horary, I don’t think it’s necessary here for him to try to turn the chart to identify the sick man as the servant of the querent’s brother. As Lilly explains in CA, if the question is about life or death for someone, and neither the querent nor their brother are directly involved, there’s no need to span the significations out like that. We can go straight to seeing the chart as immediately relevant for the person it concerns. This is in line with what Lilly teaches and does – if the matter doesn’t involve an enemy or a relationship where another party plays a central role, we can attach the signification of the person directly to the Ascendant and let the whole chart speak of them.

BTW, for my own interest I did look at charts for around 8 a.m., when the frenzied episode began. At that time Mars was very strong and angular, exactly on the IC - two hours later (around the time of death), the Part of Fortune, the Part of Death, and Saturn were all angular on the Midheaven. The times he gives are too imprecise to use formally, but they did make a lot of sense of the anger and drama, and then the very (let's not say the word) end.

title: The Ganivet Chart Form

content_blocks.text: The Ganivet Chart Form
Skyscript
30 September
content_blocks.html: 30 September

content_blocks.text: A little more on the Ganivet horary (the interpretation will follow in full to members this weekend).
content_blocks.html: A little more on the Ganivet horary (the interpretation will follow in full to members this weekend).

content_blocks.text: The modern chart image I presented earlier (shown in miniature in the centre of the diagram here) is an exact reproduction of the published details, set in a more familiar format to allow us to understand the chart that Ganivet looked at. The closest computer match to these positions relates to 4:12 pm, 24 August 1418, Vienne.
content_blocks.html: The modern chart image I presented earlier (shown in miniature in the centre of the diagram here) is an exact reproduction of the published details, set in a more familiar format to allow us to understand the chart that Ganivet looked at. The closest computer match to these positions relates to 4:12 pm, 24 August 1418, Vienne.

content_blocks.text: By translating the chart details we can see that Ganivet’s positions are surprisingly close to what we would calculate by computer today, considering the tools he was working with. He gives all positions to the nearest degree, and it’s clear he used Alcabitius houses (all cusps are correct to within the degree – the day and hour rulers are also Mercury and Saturn, as he reports). All planets are correctly placed with the exception of Mars, which is about 3° earlier than Ganivet has it. In addition, we must assume a printer’s error has lost the 2 in the degree position of Saturn (it is clearly intended to mark 27 Leo, to sit between the 8th cusp at 25 Leo and Virgo at 4 Virgo).
content_blocks.html: By translating the chart details we can see that Ganivet’s positions are surprisingly close to what we would calculate by computer today, considering the tools he was working with. He gives all positions to the nearest degree, and it’s clear he used Alcabitius houses (all cusps are correct to within the degree – the day and hour rulers are also Mercury and Saturn, as he reports). All planets are correctly placed with the exception of Mars, which is about 3° earlier than Ganivet has it. In addition, we must assume a printer’s error has lost the 2 in the degree position of Saturn (it is clearly intended to mark 27 Leo, to sit between the 8th cusp at 25 Leo and Virgo at 4 Virgo).

content_blocks.text: It’s interesting to note how this edition sits in the transitional period when astrological symbols were beginning to be brought into diagrams. Although earlier major works had introduced them, up to the early 17th century most printers relied on standard movable typesets only (letters, numerals, and a few punctuation marks). Special symbols like planetary glyphs had to be cast separately - costly and not feasible for most smaller presses. Hence this early 17th-century edition of Ganivet’s work still marks positions by text abbreviations. Astrological publishing expanded significantly around the time of Lilly, after which most presses invested in proper glyph sets.

30 September

A little more on the Ganivet horary (the interpretation will follow in full to members this weekend).
The modern chart image I presented earlier (shown in miniature in the centre of the diagram here) is an exact reproduction of the published details, set in a more familiar format to allow us to understand the chart that Ganivet looked at. The closest computer match to these positions relates to 4:12 pm, 24 August 1418, Vienne.
By translating the chart details we can see that Ganivet’s positions are surprisingly close to what we would calculate by computer today, considering the tools he was working with. He gives all positions to the nearest degree, and it’s clear he used Alcabitius houses (all cusps are correct to within the degree – the day and hour rulers are also Mercury and Saturn, as he reports). All planets are correctly placed with the exception of Mars, which is about 3° earlier than Ganivet has it. In addition, we must assume a printer’s error has lost the 2 in the degree position of Saturn (it is clearly intended to mark 27 Leo, to sit between the 8th cusp at 25 Leo and Virgo at 4 Virgo).
It’s interesting to note how this edition sits in the transitional period when astrological symbols were beginning to be brought into diagrams. Although earlier major works had introduced them, up to the early 17th century most printers relied on standard movable typesets only (letters, numerals, and a few punctuation marks). Special symbols like planetary glyphs had to be cast separately - costly and not feasible for most smaller presses. Hence this early 17th-century edition of Ganivet’s work still marks positions by text abbreviations. Astrological publishing expanded significantly around the time of Lilly, after which most presses invested in proper glyph sets.

Skyscript
30 September
content_blocks.html: 30 September

content_blocks.text: Thanks to everyone who joined the new reading group meeting yesterday, and for those who couldn’t attend at the time, the recording is attached. (It is also linked into themembers’ areaalong with outline details of our next meeting:8:30 pm UTC Sun 19 Oct 2025)
content_blocks.html: Thanks to everyone who joined the new reading group meeting yesterday, and for those who couldn’t attend at the time, the recording is attached. (It is also linked into the members’ area along with outline details of our next meeting: 8:30 pm UTC Sun 19 Oct 2025)

content_blocks.text: Ganivet

We had several interesting side issues to explore. One point of reference was the astrologerJean Ganivet(‘Ganivetus’), whose 1431 textAmicus Medicorum(‘Physician’s Friend’) was the source of the first conjunction chart Lilly discusses, dated to 1425. I showed some pages of his Latin text on screen and mentioned that Ganivet was an important source for Lilly’s work generally – according to Lynne Thorndyke his wok was “probably the most influential [medical astrology] treatise composed in Europe during the fifteenth century”.
content_blocks.html: We had several interesting side issues to explore. One point of reference was the astrologer Jean Ganivet (‘Ganivetus’), whose 1431 text Amicus Medicorum (‘Physician’s Friend’) was the source of the first conjunction chart Lilly discusses, dated to 1425. I showed some pages of his Latin text on screen and mentioned that Ganivet was an important source for Lilly’s work generally – according to Lynne Thorndyke his wok was “probably the most influential [medical astrology] treatise composed in Europe during the fifteenth century”.

items: Brief biography of Ganivetin the glossary pages on Skyscript (includes link to his Latin text and some other related resources.)

content_blocks.text: The recent horary chart I posted – on whether a sick man would die or recover – is taken from Ganivet’s work, and offers a relatively rare and valuable example of a horary judgement from the late medieval period. I’ll post the full judgement of it within the week (I’m still working on the final parts of the translation). In the meantime, to give more context for the chart itself and the type of material Ganivet covers, I’ve included below the opening section to the chart in Book 3, Chapter 5. When the full translation is complete, I’ll assemble everything, including the original Latin text as well as its translation, into a PDF for members.

content_blocks.text: GANIVETUS - AMICUS MEDICORUM (c.1430)BOOK III- V
content_blocks.html:
GANIVETUS - AMICUS MEDICORUM (c.1430)

BOOK III  - V

content_blocks.text: On the declaration of the planets influencing various illnesses, and on the knowledge of whether illnesses are curable or not.
content_blocks.html: On the declaration of the planets influencing various illnesses, and on the knowledge of whether illnesses are curable or not.

content_blocks.text: Here follows an account of the planets and of the degrees of the heavens influencing various illnesses. And note that nothing here is said of diseases inflicted by God: of which Sacred Scripture speaks sufficiently, but only of illnesses arising through the course of nature and the celestial influences.
content_blocks.html: Here follows an account of the planets and of the degrees of the heavens influencing various illnesses. And note that nothing here is said of diseases inflicted by God: of which Sacred Scripture speaks sufficiently, but only of illnesses arising through the course of nature and the celestial influences.

content_blocks.text: Concerning these natural infirmities, it must be noted that some bodily illnesses do not always last yet bring pain, such as iliac passion, colic, gout in the feet or hands, and the like; others always last but do not bring pain, such as blindness, deafness, hunchback, mutilation of limbs, and the like; others always last and also bring pain, such as continual fever, acute fever, and similar diseases.
content_blocks.html: Concerning these natural infirmities, it must be noted that some bodily illnesses do not always last yet bring pain, such as iliac passion, colic, gout in the feet or hands, and the like; others always last but do not bring pain, such as blindness, deafness, hunchback, mutilation of limbs, and the like; others always last and also bring pain, such as continual fever, acute fever, and similar diseases.

content_blocks.text: Infirmities that can be more easily cured, and in a short time, such as acute fevers, are measured by the influence of the Moon. But those which last longer, such as quartan fever, are measured by the motion of the Sun, even if the matter proceeds from Saturn; yet the cure itself and the duration of the cure are measured by the influence of the Sun.
content_blocks.html: Infirmities that can be more easily cured, and in a short time, such as acute fevers, are measured by the influence of the Moon. But those which last longer, such as quartan fever, are measured by the motion of the Sun, even if the matter proceeds from Saturn; yet the cure itself and the duration of the cure are measured by the influence of the Sun.

content_blocks.text: It should further be considered that each planet signifies its own particular illnesses according to its inherent nature and influence, and that these illnesses increase, persist, grow, or diminish, according to the signs and degrees, and depending on whether they fall in azimene [lame], bright or dark degrees, or are angular, succedent or cadent. Hence:
content_blocks.html: It should further be considered that each planet signifies its own particular illnesses according to its inherent nature and influence, and that these illnesses increase, persist, grow, or diminish, according to the signs and degrees, and depending on whether they fall in azimene [lame], bright or dark degrees, or are angular, succedent or cadent. Hence:

content_blocks.text: Saturnillnesses are phthisis, catarrh, hectic fever, splenetic disease, dropsy, looseness of the bowels, and more serious disorders such as leprosy, especially elephantiasis, gout, cancer, and the like, and those that chiefly arise from coldness.Jupitersignifies quinsy, pneumonia, pleurisy, apoplexy, spasm, headache, lethargy, heart disease, and in general all illnesses arising from an excess or corruption of blood, such as synocha [fever arising from excess heat of the blood], synochus [putrid fever from corrupted blood], and similar diseases.Marssignifies hepatitis, tertian fevers, pestilential fevers, migraine, erysipelas of a choleric nature [St. Anthony’s fire], abortion, suppuration [abscesses], and every illness arising from an excess of choler, which brings about burning and pain, especially those marked by redness.The Sunhas influence over rheums affecting the eyes [catarrhal discharges], lesions [or chapping] of the mouth, and over those hot and dry diseases which do not arise from the influence of Mars.Venushas influence over cold and moist illnesses, such as soft swellings or abscesses, fistulas, bodily fluids and moist discharges, and excessive fluxes, especially affecting the genitals and the private parts of women.Mercuryhas influence over mental disturbances, mania, melancholy, epilepsy, dizziness [vertigo], coughing and an abundance of phlegm.The Moonhas influence over paralysis, facial palsies, convulsions [strokes] of the limbs, and ailments arising from obstruction of the nerves.

And note that when the lord of the Ascendant, or the Moon, or the Part of Fortune are in an azimene degree, or in dark or pitted degrees, it signifies deep rooted [chronic] illnesses. In bright degrees they are newly arisen [acute]; and their signification is more adverse in Aries, Cancer, Scorpio, Capricorn, and Pisces. And sometimes in these signs they signify leprosy, abscesses, pustules, scabies, skin eruptions, and spreading rashes, according to the houses of the figure and the degrees in which the lord of the Ascendant, the Moon, and the Part of Fortune are found.
content_blocks.html: And note that when the lord of the Ascendant, or the Moon, or the Part of Fortune are in an azimene degree, or in dark or pitted degrees, it signifies deep rooted [chronic] illnesses. In bright degrees they are newly arisen [acute]; and their signification is more adverse in Aries, Cancer, Scorpio, Capricorn, and Pisces. And sometimes in these signs they signify leprosy, abscesses, pustules, scabies, skin eruptions, and spreading rashes, according to the houses of the figure and the degrees in which the lord of the Ascendant, the Moon, and the Part of Fortune are found.

content_blocks.text: Also consider the Moon in each of the signs; and if the Moon is in Aries with Mars or the Sun there will be illness in the head, a pounding headache, burning fever, anxiety, and difficulty speaking. There may be great pain in the chest and in the lungs, with a most violent pulse, so it is advantageous that the vein of the heart be bled and that cold foods be taken, since there is danger of delirium. And if the Moon is conjoined to malefics, or in a perilous aspect with malefics, there is mortal danger within seven days. For the Moon being with the benefics is favourable and fortunate, but with malefics it is harmful and unfortunate, especially with Mars when the Moon is waxing and Saturn when the Moon is waning. Take note of what has been said.
content_blocks.html: Also consider the Moon in each of the signs; and if the Moon is in Aries with Mars or the Sun there will be illness in the head, a pounding headache, burning fever, anxiety, and difficulty speaking. There may be great pain in the chest and in the lungs, with a most violent pulse, so it is advantageous that the vein of the heart be bled and that cold foods be taken, since there is danger of delirium. And if the Moon is conjoined to malefics, or in a perilous aspect with malefics, there is mortal danger within seven days. For the Moon being with the benefics is favourable and fortunate, but with malefics it is harmful and unfortunate, especially with Mars when the Moon is waxing and Saturn when the Moon is waning. Take note of what has been said.

content_blocks.text: Regarding the general influence of planets and degrees over various illnesses, it will be seen in another part of this chapter whether such illnesses are curable or not. And careful judgement is a foremost requirement in this matter: for example, leprosy is said to be incurable because it is cured with difficulty, and rarely, since not every type of leprosy is curable by art but only certain kinds. And the same with many other diseases, each to be considered in its own way and according to the common judgement of physicians, to whom the first determination of such matters belongs. But in turning to specifics and to astrological judgement, many of the matters already explained in this chapter must be borne in mind; and, to the matter at hand, when a case is presented to the astrologer, he must consider whether the illness is curable or not.
content_blocks.html: Regarding the general influence of planets and degrees over various illnesses, it will be seen in another part of this chapter whether such illnesses are curable or not. And careful judgement is a foremost requirement in this matter: for example, leprosy is said to be incurable because it is cured with difficulty, and rarely, since not every type of leprosy is curable by art but only certain kinds. And the same with many other diseases, each to be considered in its own way and according to the common judgement of physicians, to whom the first determination of such matters belongs. But in turning to specifics and to astrological judgement, many of the matters already explained in this chapter must be borne in mind; and, to the matter at hand, when a case is presented to the astrologer, he must consider whether the illness is curable or not.

content_blocks.text: Of this, it should be noted that the astrologer has two ways to commence the inquiry: either through the true onset of the illness, or through a question. The astrologer’s judgement is the same, whether by question or by the onset of the illness; though more truly by the onset, if that can be reliably known.
content_blocks.html: Of this, it should be noted that the astrologer has two ways to commence the inquiry: either through the true onset of the illness, or through a question. The astrologer’s judgement is the same, whether by question or by the onset of the illness; though more truly by the onset, if that can be reliably known.

content_blocks.text: And to show this a little more clearly, I will give an example from the year of our Lord 1418, 24th day of August, the basis of time being three hours after the meridian with 12 celestial degrees,* on the day of Mercury, hour of Saturn. A certain cleric called John Mortier asked on behalf of his brother’s sick servant, what would be the end of his illness: death or recovery? For which the figure of heaven fell thus over Vienne at the time of the question.

This video uses Vimeo’s DNT parameter. Vimeo may still store and/or gain access to information on your device, including cookies and local storage.
EPM Reading Group 1 recording (28 Sep 2025) & extract from Ganivetus
Skyscript
30 September
6
Thanks to everyone who joined the new reading group meeting yesterday, and for those who couldn’t attend at the time, the recording is attached. (It is also linked into the members’ area along with outline details of our next meeting: 8:30 pm UTC Sun 19 Oct 2025)
Ganivet
We had several interesting side issues to explore. One point of reference was the astrologer Jean Ganivet (‘Ganivetus’), whose 1431 text Amicus Medicorum (‘Physician’s Friend’) was the source of the first conjunction chart Lilly discusses, dated to 1425. I showed some pages of his Latin text on screen and mentioned that Ganivet was an important source for Lilly’s work generally – according to Lynne Thorndyke his wok was “probably the most influential [medical astrology] treatise composed in Europe during the fifteenth century”. 
Brief biography of Ganivet in the glossary pages on Skyscript (includes link to his Latin text and some other related resources.)
The recent horary chart I posted – on whether a sick man would die or recover – is taken from Ganivet’s work, and offers a relatively rare and valuable example of a horary judgement from the late medieval period. I’ll post the full judgement of it within the week (I’m still working on the final parts of the translation). In the meantime, to give more context for the chart itself and the type of material Ganivet covers, I’ve included below the opening section to the chart in Book 3, Chapter 5. When the full translation is complete, I’ll assemble everything, including the original Latin text as well as its translation, into a PDF for members.

Upcoming
A quick note that our next Skyscript presentation will be on 9th October, when I’ll give a talk on the use of directions in horary – by this I mean compass directions, not primary directions :) I’ll circulate a more pertinent reminder closer to the event.



━━━━ ✦ ✦ ━━━━━━━━ ✦ ✦ ━━━━

GANIVETUS - AMICUS MEDICORUM (c.1430)

BOOK III  - V
On the declaration of the planets influencing various illnesses, and on the knowledge of whether illnesses are curable or not.
Here follows an account of the planets and of the degrees of the heavens influencing various illnesses. And note that nothing here is said of diseases inflicted by God: of which Sacred Scripture speaks sufficiently, but only of illnesses arising through the course of nature and the celestial influences.
Concerning these natural infirmities, it must be noted that some bodily illnesses do not always last yet bring pain, such as iliac passion, colic, gout in the feet or hands, and the like; others always last but do not bring pain, such as blindness, deafness, hunchback, mutilation of limbs, and the like; others always last and also bring pain, such as continual fever, acute fever, and similar diseases.
Infirmities that can be more easily cured, and in a short time, such as acute fevers, are measured by the influence of the Moon. But those which last longer, such as quartan fever, are measured by the motion of the Sun, even if the matter proceeds from Saturn; yet the cure itself and the duration of the cure are measured by the influence of the Sun.
It should further be considered that each planet signifies its own particular illnesses according to its inherent nature and influence, and that these illnesses increase, persist, grow, or diminish, according to the signs and degrees, and depending on whether they fall in azimene [lame], bright or dark degrees, or are angular, succedent or cadent. Hence:
Saturn illnesses are phthisis, catarrh, hectic fever, splenetic disease, dropsy, looseness of the bowels, and more serious disorders such as leprosy, especially elephantiasis, gout, cancer, and the like, and those that chiefly arise from coldness.
Jupiter signifies quinsy, pneumonia, pleurisy, apoplexy, spasm, headache, lethargy, heart disease, and in general all illnesses arising from an excess or corruption of blood, such as synocha [fever arising from excess heat of the blood], synochus [putrid fever from corrupted blood], and similar diseases.
Mars signifies hepatitis, tertian fevers, pestilential fevers, migraine, erysipelas of a choleric nature [St. Anthony’s fire], abortion, suppuration [abscesses], and every illness arising from an excess of choler, which brings about burning and pain, especially those marked by redness.
The Sun has influence over rheums affecting the eyes [catarrhal discharges], lesions [or chapping] of the mouth, and over those hot and dry diseases which do not arise from the influence of Mars.
Venus has influence over cold and moist illnesses, such as soft swellings or abscesses, fistulas, bodily fluids and moist discharges, and excessive fluxes, especially affecting the genitals and the private parts of women.
Mercury has influence over mental disturbances, mania, melancholy, epilepsy, dizziness [vertigo], coughing and an abundance of phlegm.
The Moon has influence over paralysis, facial palsies, convulsions [strokes] of the limbs, and ailments arising from obstruction of the nerves.

And note that when the lord of the Ascendant, or the Moon, or the Part of Fortune are in an azimene degree, or in dark or pitted degrees, it signifies deep rooted [chronic] illnesses. In bright degrees they are newly arisen [acute]; and their signification is more adverse in Aries, Cancer, Scorpio, Capricorn, and Pisces. And sometimes in these signs they signify leprosy, abscesses, pustules, scabies, skin eruptions, and spreading rashes, according to the houses of the figure and the degrees in which the lord of the Ascendant, the Moon, and the Part of Fortune are found.
Also consider the Moon in each of the signs; and if the Moon is in Aries with Mars or the Sun there will be illness in the head, a pounding headache, burning fever, anxiety, and difficulty speaking. There may be great pain in the chest and in the lungs, with a most violent pulse, so it is advantageous that the vein of the heart be bled and that cold foods be taken, since there is danger of delirium. And if the Moon is conjoined to malefics, or in a perilous aspect with malefics, there is mortal danger within seven days. For the Moon being with the benefics is favourable and fortunate, but with malefics it is harmful and unfortunate, especially with Mars when the Moon is waxing and Saturn when the Moon is waning. Take note of what has been said.
Regarding the general influence of planets and degrees over various illnesses, it will be seen in another part of this chapter whether such illnesses are curable or not. And careful judgement is a foremost requirement in this matter: for example, leprosy is said to be incurable because it is cured with difficulty, and rarely, since not every type of leprosy is curable by art but only certain kinds. And the same with many other diseases, each to be considered in its own way and according to the common judgement of physicians, to whom the first determination of such matters belongs. But in turning to specifics and to astrological judgement, many of the matters already explained in this chapter must be borne in mind; and, to the matter at hand, when a case is presented to the astrologer, he must consider whether the illness is curable or not.
Of this, it should be noted that the astrologer has two ways to commence the inquiry: either through the true onset of the illness, or through a question. The astrologer’s judgement is the same, whether by question or by the onset of the illness; though more truly by the onset, if that can be reliably known.
And to show this a little more clearly, I will give an example from the year of our Lord 1418, 24th day of August, the basis of time being three hours after the meridian with 12 celestial degrees,* on the day of Mercury, hour of Saturn. A certain cleric called John Mortier asked on behalf of his brother’s sick servant, what would be the end of his illness: death or recovery? For which the figure of heaven fell thus over Vienne at the time of the question.
[*Note – don’t draw the chart for that time, because he later explains that he is using seasonal hours here – I show the chart as it appears in the Latin text and its closest computerised match below - the chart above is an exact reproduction of the original chart presented in modern format. His positions are rounded to the nearest degree, and all planets and house cusps align with modern computation with the exception of the PoD being 1° out and Mars being misplaced by 3° (This is to be expected of historical charts - Mars was always the planet that was the most difficult to place exactly according to historical tables). Overall, its agreement with modern values shows a high level of skill for an astrologer of his era.
[To be continued ...]

title: Historical Horary

content_blocks.text: Historical Horary
Skyscript
28 September
content_blocks.html: 28 September

content_blocks.text: Just sharing an interesting horary cast several hundred years ago (from a text I’m currently working on). It’s a hard question asked at a time of plague: a sick man – signified by the first house – faces a battle of life or death. The astrologer was asked to judge whether he would die or might recover. He gave a decisive answer on the basis that this chart gives clear testimony.If you’d like to muse on what you’d make of this yourself, next week I will have my passage finished and polished, and will share the astrologer’s judgement.
content_blocks.html:
Just sharing an interesting horary cast several hundred years ago (from a text I’m currently working on). It’s a hard question asked at a time of plague: a sick man – signified by the first house – faces a battle of life or death. The astrologer was asked to judge whether he would die or might recover. He gave a decisive answer on the basis that this chart gives clear testimony.

If you’d like to muse on what you’d make of this yourself, next week I will have my passage finished and polished, and will share the astrologer’s judgement.

content_blocks.author: The Star Is You
content_blocks.text:
There’s something tricky about this chart, otherwise Deb wouldn’t have it published…
Yes, L1 is on the verge of death (8th house), such a populated death house captures our attention. 
But… what about the translation of light of the Moon between Mercury Rx and the Sun (life and vitality)? Mercury Rx rules the 6th house, meaning the disease is “going backwards”, then the Sun is activated in Virgo, also a sign ruled by Mercury, so the Sun appreciates the recovering disease.
L1 Saturn is not affected by any nasty aspect from the Moon, neither the Sun (death) nor Mars (inflammation, fevers).
Other factor: later the Moon trines Fortuna in Libra, disposed by Venus, again ruled by Mercury Rx. Fortuna also squares Mars and the ASC, since Mars can symbolize the treatment (L10), probably it’s also a favorable testimony.
I would bet he survived, and this was the astrologer judgment, even with all the other testimonies mentioned before, which favour death.

content_blocks.author: Georgius
content_blocks.text:
Sun is L8.
I’m not convinced that aspects to lots are that important (excluded conjunctions).

content_blocks.author: Georgius
content_blocks.text: According to Morinus as Lee Lehman reported in her “Traditional Medical Astrology” Mars is the Anareta, “the bringer of death”. The killer visits the patient (Mars on the Asc). But as Mars has very high dignities I say that he will die a natural death on pestilence.

content_blocks.author: CROSSLEY Mireille
content_blocks.text: Death has the upper hand:) so sadly  i don't think he will make it:) ruler of Part of Death on the ASC/Querent Saturn in 8H/Moon app square Sun ruler of 8H/dispositor of Part of Life/end of matter Venus in 8H and the Moon will square it....

content_blocks.author: Theodora Vasilopoulou
content_blocks.text: I say “death”

content_blocks.author: Skyscript
content_blocks.text: Straight to the point - I hope that's not the style you use for your own clients :)

content_blocks.author: Janice Holmes
content_blocks.text:
Yes, completely agree with Samantha but I have a mind it's more tricksy than the obvious merely because you've asked the question. 😊 So to counter all of that, the Mars in Capricorn conjunct the ascendant gives good vitality to the querent. Jupiter is applying to the part of life and mercury (ruler of the 6th of health matters) strong in Virgo is applying to that Jupiter. 
If it wasn't the sick man asking the question but maybe the sibling or wife then  wouldn't that put a whole new slant on it? Can't wait to read the final dénouement.

content_blocks.author: Skyscript
content_blocks.text:
Well, if you’re looking for clues beyond the chart, “He gave a decisive answer on the basis that this chart gives clear testimony” also suggests this is straight up with no hidden angles :) There really isn’t any hidden catch in this, so no need to look past the obvious.

But you are right that the sick man didn’t ask the question himself, someone else asked about him. I didn’t mention this because the astrologer gave signification of the sick man to the Ascendant on the basis that the first house signifies life and is the primary concern in all matters. (Also, the enquirer wasn’t directly related - it was asked by the brother of his employer.) In any event he treated the sick man as the focus of the query, as though he had asked it himself.

Anyway, no new slant here Janice, but do continue to entertain us with your colourful ideas :)

content_blocks.author: Samantha Blackadder
content_blocks.text: Definitely doesn't look good - ruler of the Lot of Death, powerful and applying to the Ascendant in 1 UOT. Symbol of Life - Saturn, weak in Leo, further weakened in the house of death. Moon applying to L8 in 1 UOT. L8 applying to Lot of Death, then its ruler ergh. Not much is going right with the indications for life - Saturn..., the Lot of Life near the IC, the ruler weak and not aspecting it.  That's a tough horary!

full_content:
Historical Horary
Skyscript
28 September
8
17
Just sharing an interesting horary cast several hundred years ago (from a text I’m currently working on). It’s a hard question asked at a time of plague: a sick man – signified by the first house – faces a battle of life or death. The astrologer was asked to judge whether he would die or might recover. He gave a decisive answer on the basis that this chart gives clear testimony.

If you’d like to muse on what you’d make of this yourself, next week I will have my passage finished and polished, and will share the astrologer’s judgement.
(I’ll be sharing this chart on my Facebook page too, but here on Patreon you’ll receive the full translation of the complete passage once it’s finished. I am being vague for now - more details to follow soon.)
17 comments
The Star Is You
·
1mo
There’s something tricky about this chart, otherwise Deb wouldn’t have it published…
Yes, L1 is on the verge of death (8th house), such a populated death house captures our attention. 
But… what about the translation of light of the Moon between Mercury Rx and the Sun (life and vitality)? Mercury Rx rules the 6th house, meaning the disease is “going backwards”, then the Sun is activated in Virgo, also a sign ruled by Mercury, so the Sun appreciates the recovering disease.
L1 Saturn is not affected by any nasty aspect from the Moon, neither the Sun (death) nor Mars (inflammation, fevers).
Other factor: later the Moon trines Fortuna in Libra, disposed by Venus, again ruled by Mercury Rx. Fortuna also squares Mars and the ASC, since Mars can symbolize the treatment (L10), probably it’s also a favorable testimony.
I would bet he survived, and this was the astrologer judgment, even with all the other testimonies mentioned before, which favour death.

content_blocks.text: Attached to this post is a copy of Lilly’sAddress to the Reader– a taster of the work we've been doing preparing this text. We’ve decided not to start the reading group with thisAddress to the Reader; instead we’ll begin on Sunday where Lilly enters the main topic, then circle back to these pages later (they’re full of gems), after we’ve got some understanding of his main theme under our belt first. Monthly meeting - about 75 minutes
━━━━ ✦ ✦ ━━━━
A reminder that the new Skyscript Reading Group begins this upcoming Sunday, focused on William Lilly’s England’s Prophetic Merlin. We’ll be exploring his treatment of Saturn-Jupiter cycles and mundane astrology, while relating his ideas to those of other astrologers.
Attached to this post is a copy of Lilly’s Address to the Reader – a taster of the work we've been doing preparing this text. It’s a fascinating exploration of situations and people impressed on Lilly’s mind at the time he wrote, followed by an appendix about the prophecy of Merlin (the inspiration for his work and title). We’ve decided not to start the reading group with this Address to the Reader; instead we’ll begin on Sunday where Lilly enters the main topic, then circle back to these pages later (they’re full of gems), after we’ve got some understanding of his main theme under our belt first. I’ll post the pages we start the reading group with on Sunday, when I circulate the final reminder.
All assets (including the PDF circulated here) will also be housed in the Members area: https://www.skyscript.co.uk/members.html.
This will be a very friendly and illuminating meeting – come and join us if you have an hour to spare, and don’t worry if you don’t feel you know enough about the subject yet! It’s open to all Skyscript patrons and will be recorded for anyone who can’t attend live. For those of you who can, I’ll look forward to seeing you then 🌱
Illustrated spread from England’s Prophetic Merlin. The left page shows portraits of King James I and William Lilly

title: Recording: Alberto Forero - William Lilly on Marriage Indications in the Nativity

content_blocks.text: This video uses Vimeo’s DNT parameter. Vimeo may still store and/or gain access to information on your device, including cookies and local storage.
content_blocks.html: This video uses Vimeo’s DNT parameter. Vimeo may still store and/or gain access to information on your device, including cookies and local storage.

content_blocks.text: Recording: Alberto Forero - William Lilly on Marriage Indications in the Nativity
Skyscript
19 September
content_blocks.html: 19 September

content_blocks.text: Alberto Forero gave an engaging talk last night on his work with Book 3 of Lilly’sChristian Astrology. His overview of Seventh House themes raised some interesting details, and I’m still reflecting on how Lilly’s unhappy love life links to the bad reputation of Mars in Virgo in the seventh. Obviously, Mars there signals an ‘annoying’ marriage, which Lilly says applies whether it aspects Venus or not. That surely points to reception, Virgo being where Venus is debilitated, so the principle of love, desire and compassion takes a hit. Lilly’s statement that he was unable to shed a tear after the death of his wife of 25 years, leaves us to wonder how much marital strain and ill-will shadowed his most productive years.I'm struck by how often unhappy marriages appear in the lives of historical astrologers. Poor Culpeper eloped with his sweetheart, only for their carriage to be struck by lightning that night, killing her tragically.  J.B. Morin was so shocked when his intended died suddenly on the night he was due to propose that he took it as a divine sign (or a sign of a curse) and chose to remain celibate for the rest of his days.  By comparison, Lilly didn't do too bad! :)
content_blocks.html:
Alberto Forero gave an engaging talk last night on his work with Book 3 of Lilly’s Christian Astrology. His overview of Seventh House themes raised some interesting details, and I’m still reflecting on how Lilly’s unhappy love life links to the bad reputation of Mars in Virgo in the seventh. Obviously, Mars there signals an ‘annoying’ marriage, which Lilly says applies whether it aspects Venus or not. That surely points to reception, Virgo being where Venus is debilitated, so the principle of love, desire and compassion takes a hit. Lilly’s statement that he was unable to shed a tear after the death of his wife of 25 years, leaves us to wonder how much marital strain and ill-will shadowed his most productive years.

I'm struck by how often unhappy marriages appear in the lives of historical astrologers. Poor Culpeper eloped with his sweetheart, only for their carriage to be struck by lightning that night, killing her tragically. J.B. Morin was so shocked when his intended died suddenly on the night he was due to propose that he took it as a divine sign (or a sign of a curse) and chose to remain celibate for the rest of his days. By comparison, Lilly didn't do too bad! :)

This video uses Vimeo’s DNT parameter. Vimeo may still store and/or gain access to information on your device, including cookies and local storage.
Recording: Alberto Forero - William Lilly on Marriage Indications in the Nativity
Skyscript
19 September
6
Alberto Forero gave an engaging talk last night on his work with Book 3 of Lilly’s Christian Astrology. His overview of Seventh House themes raised some interesting details, and I’m still reflecting on how Lilly’s unhappy love life links to the bad reputation of Mars in Virgo in the seventh. Obviously, Mars there signals an ‘annoying’ marriage, which Lilly says applies whether it aspects Venus or not. That surely points to reception, Virgo being where Venus is debilitated, so the principle of love, desire and compassion takes a hit. Lilly’s statement that he was unable to shed a tear after the death of his wife of 25 years, leaves us to wonder how much marital strain and ill-will shadowed his most productive years.

I'm struck by how often unhappy marriages appear in the lives of historical astrologers. Poor Culpeper eloped with his sweetheart, only for their carriage to be struck by lightning that night, killing her tragically. J.B. Morin was so shocked when his intended died suddenly on the night he was due to propose that he took it as a divine sign (or a sign of a curse) and chose to remain celibate for the rest of his days. By comparison, Lilly didn't do too bad! :)
The recording is attached to this post and is also linked into the member’s area, where you can find it alongside our showreel of past presentations:
https://vimeopro.com/stapresenter/latest

---A change of focus – and some exciting news
content_blocks.html:
---


A change of focus – and some exciting news

content_blocks.text: We’re making a temporary change of direction for the reading group – one you should find very worthwhile. After making great progress exploring books I & II of Manilius’Astronomica, we are going to pause that project before resuming with book III next year.
content_blocks.html: We’re making a temporary change of direction for the reading group – one you should find very worthwhile. After making great progress exploring books I & II of Manilius’ Astronomica, we are going to pause that project before resuming with book III next year.

content_blocks.text: Why? Read on …
content_blocks.html: Why? Read on …

content_blocks.text: An initiative that’s been developing behind the scenes has reached a stage where it’s timely to share. A small group of us – myself, Josh, Sheila, Morgan, Jane and Michelle – have been working on an annotated and illustrated edition of William Lilly’sEngland’s Prophetic Merlin. The work is going very well and uncovering some remarkable nuggets of astrological gold.
content_blocks.html: An initiative that’s been developing behind the scenes has reached a stage where it’s timely to share. A small group of us – myself, Josh, Sheila, Morgan, Jane and Michelle – have been working on an annotated and illustrated edition of William Lilly’s England’s Prophetic Merlin. The work is going very well and uncovering some remarkable nuggets of astrological gold.

content_blocks.text: Although the annotations capture a lot, there is much more to explore than we can fit on the page. Lilly’s text centres on the Saturn-Jupiter Great Conjunction cycles, but behind that main thread lies a rich backdrop of sources and techniques that informed Lilly’s art – material that lets us look more closely at the lives and methods of earlier astrologers who shaped his thinking, while learning the techniques that Lilly used so well.
content_blocks.html: Although the annotations capture a lot, there is much more to explore than we can fit on the page. Lilly’s text centres on the Saturn-Jupiter Great Conjunction cycles, but behind that main thread lies a rich backdrop of sources and techniques that informed Lilly’s art – material that lets us look more closely at the lives and methods of earlier astrologers who shaped his thinking, while learning the techniques that Lilly used so well.

content_blocks.text: What’s next?
content_blocks.html: What’s next?

content_blocks.text: To share this material more openly we’re setting up a new reading group built around our progress withMerlin. This will give us space to open out the ideas, demonstrate and experiment with the practical elements, and work directly with charts connected to the text and its themes. We expect it to be a rich and lively exploration with plenty of new insights for you to take into practice.
content_blocks.html: To share this material more openly we’re setting up a new reading group built around our progress with Merlin. This will give us space to open out the ideas, demonstrate and experiment with the practical elements, and work directly with charts connected to the text and its themes. We expect it to be a rich and lively exploration with plenty of new insights for you to take into practice.

content_blocks.text: What will you get out of this?
content_blocks.html: What will you get out of this?

content_blocks.text: If you’ve enjoyed the Manilius group, you will definitely enjoy the new theme. We’ll be looking over Lilly’s shoulder and into his life while exploring plenty of charts and delving into other historical avenues that throb with unrecognised significance. Whether your interest is ancient, Renaissance or modern astrology, there’s a lot of great information and practical takeaways to be gained from exploring this text.

Skyscript
13 September
8
Don’t miss our next live Skyscript Speaker Event – coming up next week
On Thursday 18 September at 7 pm UTC we’ll be welcoming Alberto Forero for a 90-minute presentation on William Lilly on Marriage Indications in the Nativity. Alberto has produced his own modern-English edition of Book 3 of Christian Astrology and will be giving us an overview of the text along with some of the key relationship themes from the Seventh House section. I have already seen glimpses of this and I was bowled over by the beautiful presentation Alberto has put together. The session will be live on Zoom and also be recorded for Skyscript members unable to attend at that time.

Event Details
Thursday, 18th September 2025
starting at – 7 pm UTC ← click this to see the time for you!
Find the Zoom link at the end of this post - and always prominent in the members area
About our speaker:
Alberto Forero (Translationoflight.org) is the President of the San Francisco Astrological Society and member of NCGR and ISAR. An astrologer, designer, and YouTuber based in San Francisco, Alberto posts astrological analyses on the Translation of Light channel on YouTube (https://www.youtube.com/@TranslationofLight) and is working on the Alexandria iBase Project online Astrological Library.
---


A change of focus – and some exciting news
We’re making a temporary change of direction for the reading group – one you should find very worthwhile. After making great progress exploring books I & II of Manilius’ Astronomica, we are going to pause that project before resuming with book III next year.
Why? Read on …
An initiative that’s been developing behind the scenes has reached a stage where it’s timely to share. A small group of us – myself, Josh, Sheila, Morgan, Jane and Michelle – have been working on an annotated and illustrated edition of William Lilly’s England’s Prophetic Merlin. The work is going very well and uncovering some remarkable nuggets of astrological gold.
Although the annotations capture a lot, there is much more to explore than we can fit on the page. Lilly’s text centres on the Saturn-Jupiter Great Conjunction cycles, but behind that main thread lies a rich backdrop of sources and techniques that informed Lilly’s art – material that lets us look more closely at the lives and methods of earlier astrologers who shaped his thinking, while learning the techniques that Lilly used so well.
What’s next?
To share this material more openly we’re setting up a new reading group built around our progress with Merlin. This will give us space to open out the ideas, demonstrate and experiment with the practical elements, and work directly with charts connected to the text and its themes. We expect it to be a rich and lively exploration with plenty of new insights for you to take into practice.
What will you get out of this?
If you’ve enjoyed the Manilius group, you will definitely enjoy the new theme. We’ll be looking over Lilly’s shoulder and into his life while exploring plenty of charts and delving into other historical avenues that throb with unrecognised significance. Whether your interest is ancient, Renaissance or modern astrology, there’s a lot of great information and practical takeaways to be gained from exploring this text.
First meeting: Sunday 28 September
This reading group will be held on Sundays – and our first will start at 8:30 pm UTC on Sunday 28th September. I’ll post more details at the end of next week with early reading material.
For now, I’m attaching an article written to introduce the theme and provide a handy overview, which will also feature in the upcoming journal. This is very useful to keep as a reference as it also includes a full table of Saturn-Jupiter conjunctions over 5,000 years.
All of us involved in this project are excited at the thought of delving in and exploring it together.

title: Morin’s Biography: new insights from the Vita

content_blocks.text: Morin’s Biography: new insights from the Vita
Skyscript
17 August
content_blocks.html: 17 August

content_blocks.text: I’ve recently had reason to look more deeply into the report that Morin predicted the time of his death. This led me to work on the detailed biography written by his contemporary, which appears in the preface to theAstrologia Gallica.
content_blocks.html: I’ve recently had reason to look more deeply into the report that Morin predicted the time of his death. This led me to work on the detailed biography written by his contemporary, which appears in the preface to the Astrologia Gallica.

content_blocks.text: To my knowledge, this biography has not been translated into English before – and it’s a mine of valuable information. My focus was the period of his death, so I’ve produced a careful, full translation of the final three pages, but I’ve also compiled a detailed paraphrased outline of the full 21 pages, so the main points can be skimmed easily and referred back to for research.
content_blocks.html: To my knowledge, this biography has not been translated into English before – and it’s a mine of valuable information. My focus was the period of his death, so I’ve produced a careful, full translation of the final three pages, but I’ve also compiled a detailed paraphrased outline of the full 21 pages, so the main points can be skimmed easily and referred back to for research.

content_blocks.text: Since this is a ‘work-in-progress’ that may sit on my desk for some time, I thought I’d circulate what is already in good shape to Skyscript members. If you’re interested in the history of astrology or Morin’s life and work, you will definitely find this of interest.
content_blocks.html: Since this is a ‘work-in-progress’ that may sit on my desk for some time, I thought I’d circulate what is already in good shape to Skyscript members. If you’re interested in the history of astrology or Morin’s life and work, you will definitely find this of interest.

content_blocks.text: The last three pages are especially rich concerning Morin’s views at the end of life: they describe his openness to wider divinatory methods, his experience with chiromancy and prophetic dreams; the prediction of his death made by a palmist; Morin’s own reiterated forecast; how he prepared for death, the timing of it, and the arrangements that followed.
content_blocks.html: The last three pages are especially rich concerning Morin’s views at the end of life: they describe his openness to wider divinatory methods, his experience with chiromancy and prophetic dreams; the prediction of his death made by a palmist; Morin’s own reiterated forecast; how he prepared for death, the timing of it, and the arrangements that followed.

content_blocks.text: I was struck by the concluding record of his interment in the church of Saint-Étienne-du-Mont in Paris. This is the same church where Pascal is buried, and where Racine and other luminaries were interred. full_content:
Morin’s Biography: new insights from the Vita
Skyscript
17 August
6
2


I’ve recently had reason to look more deeply into the report that Morin predicted the time of his death. This led me to work on the detailed biography written by his contemporary, which appears in the preface to the Astrologia Gallica.
To my knowledge, this biography has not been translated into English before – and it’s a mine of valuable information. My focus was the period of his death, so I’ve produced a careful, full translation of the final three pages, but I’ve also compiled a detailed paraphrased outline of the full 21 pages, so the main points can be skimmed easily and referred back to for research.
Since this is a ‘work-in-progress’ that may sit on my desk for some time, I thought I’d circulate what is already in good shape to Skyscript members. If you’re interested in the history of astrology or Morin’s life and work, you will definitely find this of interest.
The last three pages are especially rich concerning Morin’s views at the end of life: they describe his openness to wider divinatory methods, his experience with chiromancy and prophetic dreams; the prediction of his death made by a palmist; Morin’s own reiterated forecast; how he prepared for death, the timing of it, and the arrangements that followed.
I was struck by the concluding record of his interment in the church of Saint-Étienne-du-Mont in Paris. This is the same church where Pascal is buried, and where Racine and other luminaries were interred. This point seems to have gone entirely unreported in English sources, although it's confirmed by French burial listings.
I think that is fascinating in its own right. For anyone visiting Paris, Saint-Étienne-du-Mont is a beautiful and much-visited church, well worth a detour. It would be wonderful if someone could capture an image of Morin’s epitaph there!

https://www.saintetiennedumont.fr/english/history-architecture/

Full details of where his epitaph is located are included at the end of the biography – the last page of the attached PDF.
