content_blocks.author: Joanna Grant
content_blocks.text: Another good talk, thank you. It really highlighted (for me) the whole ethos of "just do as you are told and don't question the authorities" . The questions that were sent to Maimonides were so intelligent and interested; I felt it was a graphic illustration of people getting very close to real knowledge, and being dismissed, because to admit that astrology "worked" would be to cede power and agency to those who were not of the, in this case, religious establishment. This power play is still very much in evidence today, just wearing different clothes!

content_blocks.author: Skyscript
content_blocks.text:
I couldn’t help but wonder if Maimonides felt like I do when I’m behind deadline and swamped with emails. He didn’t grapple with any of the issues, did he? Entering into any one of them seemed like more time and concern than he was willing to give. (I imagine involuntary temple-vein throbs every time Ibn Ezra was mentioned).

But you’re absolutely right – it’s an uncomfortable recognition we can all relate to, when legitimate questions get shut down because taking them seriously would mean admitting that change is needed.

content_blocks.author: Karl Skellenger
content_blocks.text:
Great presentation that raised lots of provocative questions. Catafalque by Peter Kingsley is the book I referred to during the discussion. He ties Carl Jung's lifelong interest in Gnosticism and Alchemy back to Empedocles and Permenides. He makes the case that Plato and Aristotle are the roots to our modern day rationalizing with its corresponding loss of the prophets who could interpret the song of the birds and rustle of the wind, this loss of connection has resulted in the rise of the modern American technologic nightmare that threatens us all taking whatever free will we might have.  

Several times recently I have heard commentators state that we have chosen to be here during this time and so we are meant to be here. -- Perhaps we are subjected to a degree of fate while at the same time we are being tested to determine what level of free will we ultimately choose to employ.

I'm going to have to watch Peggy Sue Got Married, the movie that was recommended. I follow blogger, author, and content provider Christopher Knowles who draws meaning from synchromystic content from pop culture and the stars. Nicholas Cage movies are top of his go to list.   https://www.patreon.com/posts/secret-sun-canon-100197819

content_blocks.author: Skyscript
content_blocks.text:
Ah, thank you Karl – I see now why I struggled to catch the name of the book last night :)
I took a look on Amazon to get a bit more info about it –

This book is the first major re-imagining of both Jung and his work since the publication of the Red Book in 2009 – and is the only serious assessment of them written by a classical scholar who understands the ancient Gnostic, Hermetic and alchemical foundations of his thought as well as Jung himself did. At the same time it skilfully tells the forgotten story of Jung’s relationship with the great Sufi scholar, Henry Corbin, and with Persian Sufi tradition.

I’m surprised to see Plato mentioned alongside Aristotle in the description you gave. My understanding is that Aristotle is far more clearly tied to rationalism – with his systematising and empirical approach – whereas Plato relates more to a mystical or visionary element, with his myths and metaphors pointing beyond reason, and his sense of the soul being something that can’t be analysed by intellectual search. I can see how both could be seen as part of a shift away from the older prophetic traditions you describe, but I wouldn’t have instinctively grouped them in that way. That exploration does sound fascinating.

Meira Epstein: Exploring the Medieval Jewish Conundrum with Astrology - recording available
Skyscript
17 August
3
5
I want to thank Meira for her insightful contribution last night, sharing her specialist expertise which gave us much to reflect on. The recording is attached to this post and also available in the members’ area showreel of past presentations.
This talk will be of particular interest to astrologers drawn to theological issues — especially the controversies that astrology raised in the medieval world. Meira explored in detail how these concerns were vividly debated, focusing especially on medieval Jewish theology, where the work of Jewish practitioners such as Ibn Ezra could be considered highly controversial and even potentially blasphemous.
Unfortunately, Meira’s connection dropped right at the end, so I didn’t have a chance to thank her properly in the moment — but I hope she knows how much her contribution was valued and appreciated.
Heads up for our next event:
Our next presentation will be on Thursday 18 September 2025, when Alberto Forero will be speaking on William Lilly on Marriage Indications in the Nativity. Alberto will give an overview of Book 3 of Christian Astrology (Lilly’s detailed treatment of natal astrology, rarely explored in depth) and illustrate the relationship themes from its section on Seventh House judgments — including how many spouses a person may have, where they will come from, their attractiveness, and the harmony of the relationship, all brought to life with chart examples.

[Check your local time here]
Finally, the Manilius Reading Group is expected to start up again in September, but for now there’s uncertainty on the exact date. Mirielle and I agreed it’s best to finalise details once the summer holidays, grandmother babysitting duties, and other commitments are behind us, so I’ll share full details then.
Lots more to come — thank you for being part of it!
Deb

Skyscript
14 August
2
Just a quick reminder that this Sunday we’ll be welcoming back Meira Epstein for what promises to be a captivating journey into the medieval world. She’ll take us into the famous correspondence between Maimonides and the Rabbis of the South of France – an exchange that illustrates the philosophical issues surrounding the use of astrology in the medieval era and within mainstream Judaism. Meira’s knowledge of this subject is exceptional, and she’s a lively, engaging speaker, so this is one you won’t want to miss.

Full details below:

Event details:
Sunday, 17th August 2025
starting at – 5 pm UTC ← click this to see the time for you!
Our Zoom link:
http://us06web.zoom.us/j/6123333126
Meeting password = Skyscript
About our speaker:
Meira Epstein lectures and teaches internationally on all aspects of astrology. She is a certified professional astrological consultant and a principal teacher for the NCGR education and certification programme. Her early career as a programmer–analyst on Wall Street foreshadowed the multifaceted talents she would employ in integrating an ancient language into our modern world.
Meira is active in the revival of ancient and medieval Hebrew texts and techniques, and has researched Abraham Ibn Ezra’s astrological texts since the late 1980s. Her published translations include The Beginning of Wisdom, The Book of Reasons, The Book of Nativities and Revolutions, and The Correspondence between Maimonides and the Rabbis of the South of France about Astrology. In preparation are The Book of Elections and The Book of Interrogations.
Visit Meira’s website at www.bear-star.com.

content_blocks.html: Ibn Ezra and the Maimonides Correspondence – Medieval Conundrum in a Modern Light

content_blocks.text: With Meira Epstein
content_blocks.html: With Meira Epstein

content_blocks.text: Maimonides (1138–1204) was a renowned Jewish theologian and philosopher whose authority and leadership remain influential today. InThe Correspondence, he addresses questions sent to him by Jewish scholars in Provence about the validity of astrology, its conflict with religion, and even some technical points. Maimonides’ response is a historical milestone in the relationship between mainstream Judaism and astrology, and starkly contrasts with Ibn Ezra’s work, which clearly influenced the Provençal Rabbis and is unmistakably referenced in the correspondence.

In The Correspondence, he addresses questions sent to him by Jewish scholars in Provence about the validity of astrology, its conflict with religion, and even some technical points. Maimonides’ response is a historical milestone in the relationship between mainstream Judaism and astrology, and starkly contrasts with Ibn Ezra’s work, which clearly influenced the Provençal Rabbis and is unmistakably referenced in the correspondence.

content_blocks.text: About our speaker

Meira Epsteinlectures and teaches internationally on all aspects of astrology. She is a certified professional astrological consultant and a principal teacher for the NCGR education and certification programme. Her early career as a programmer–analyst on Wall Street foreshadowed the multifaceted talents she would employ in integrating an ancient language into our modern world.

Next member Presentation – Sun 17 Aug: Meira Epstein explores a Medieval Conundrum
Skyscript
9 August
3
Next Sunday, we’ll be welcoming back Meira Epstein for what promises to be a captivating journey into the medieval world. She’ll take us into the famous correspondence between Maimonides and the Rabbis of the South of France – an exchange that illustrates the philosophical issues surrounding the use of astrology in the medieval era and within mainstream Judaism. Meira’s knowledge of this subject is exceptional, and she’s a lively, engaging speaker, so this is one you won’t want to miss.




As a quick personal note – I’ve been a little quiet here lately. It’s been a very hectic few weeks, much of it spent battling the sort of trouble many websites increasingly face these days from server overloads due to an overwhelming number of AI scrapers and automated bots. Thankfully, the work seems to have paid off, and things are running smoothly again.
I’m also deep in prep mode for two presentations at the AA conference at the end of this month. If you’re attending, please let me know – I’d love to connect in person.

In the meantime, I’m looking forward to being on the listening side next weekend with Meira. Her talk will appeal to anyone interested in the crosscurrents of history, philosophy, and astrology — and in how medieval debates can still feel surprisingly relevant today. Fuller details below:

Event Details
Sunday, 17th August 2025
starting at – 5 pm UTC ← click this to see the time for you!
Our Zoom link:
http://us06web.zoom.us/j/6123333126
Meeting password = Skyscript

Talk description
Ibn Ezra and the Maimonides Correspondence – Medieval Conundrum in a Modern Light
With Meira Epstein
Maimonides (1138–1204) was a renowned Jewish theologian and philosopher whose authority and leadership remain influential today. In The Correspondence, he addresses questions sent to him by Jewish scholars in Provence about the validity of astrology, its conflict with religion, and even some technical points. Maimonides’ response is a historical milestone in the relationship between mainstream Judaism and astrology, and starkly contrasts with Ibn Ezra’s work, which clearly influenced the Provençal Rabbis and is unmistakably referenced in the correspondence.

About our speaker
Meira Epstein lectures and teaches internationally on all aspects of astrology. She is a certified professional astrological consultant and a principal teacher for the NCGR education and certification programme. Her early career as a programmer–analyst on Wall Street foreshadowed the multifaceted talents she would employ in integrating an ancient language into our modern world.
Meira is active in the revival of ancient and medieval Hebrew texts and techniques, and has researched Abraham Ibn Ezra’s astrological texts since the late 1980s. Her published translations include The Beginning of Wisdom, The Book of Reasons, The Book of Nativities and Revolutions, and The Correspondence between Maimonides and the Rabbis of the South of France about Astrology. In preparation are The Book of Elections and The Book of Interrogations.
Visit Meira’s website at www.bear-star.com.

content_blocks.text: Following on from our recent exploration of astrology and research, I’m sharing a paper here by Susan Archer, written in 2016, which some of you may find very relevant and thought-provoking.
content_blocks.html: Following on from our recent exploration of astrology and research, I’m sharing a paper here by Susan Archer, written in 2016, which some of you may find very relevant and thought-provoking.

content_blocks.text: It looks at whether certain planetary patterns show up more often in the natal charts of mass and serial murderers – and whether those patterns differ from charts of similarly high-profile individuals born around the same time.
content_blocks.html: It looks at whether certain planetary patterns show up more often in the natal charts of mass and serial murderers – and whether those patterns differ from charts of similarly high-profile individuals born around the same time.

content_blocks.text: Susan draws on some of the ideas of Dennis Elwell and keeps her method deliberately simple: no asteroids, no obscure techniques – just a focus on dignities, house placements, aspects, and planetary groupings. The sample is small and the conclusions cautious, but she raises some useful points about what we can (and maybe can’t) draw from the natal chart when it comes to identifying dangerous traits.

full_content:
Seeing the Monsters Among Us - serial murder research paper by Susan Archer
Skyscript
13 July
4
2


Following on from our recent exploration of astrology and research, I’m sharing a paper here by Susan Archer, written in 2016, which some of you may find very relevant and thought-provoking.
It looks at whether certain planetary patterns show up more often in the natal charts of mass and serial murderers – and whether those patterns differ from charts of similarly high-profile individuals born around the same time.
Susan draws on some of the ideas of Dennis Elwell and keeps her method deliberately simple: no asteroids, no obscure techniques – just a focus on dignities, house placements, aspects, and planetary groupings. The sample is small and the conclusions cautious, but she raises some useful points about what we can (and maybe can’t) draw from the natal chart when it comes to identifying dangerous traits.
The full article is attached here as a 6-page PDF – it’s an easy and interesting read.
Thank you Susan!

Skyscript
13 July
content_blocks.html: 13 July

content_blocks.text: The video recording of the recent presentation exploring what it means to subject astrology to empirical scrutiny is now available in the members area and embedded in this post.
content_blocks.html: The video recording of the recent presentation exploring what it means to subject astrology to empirical scrutiny is now available in the members area and embedded in this post.

content_blocks.text: I got a lot from this event. Garry’s points about the inescapable subjectivity in how we work are very relevant, and it was great to have Robert guiding the discussion with the insight he brings as editor ofCorrelation. Below are some assets, additions, and follow-up notes linked to topics we touched on during the session.

content_blocks.text: 3) Where I’m Going Next – Gunshots and Firing Squads

I’ve followed Robert’s advice on making use of AI to determine the samples for the next collection in my data project. It will focus on a very specific category of politically motivated gunshot deaths. The cases will be grouped into two sets of 10 charts, distinguishing whether the death was the result of execution or assassination, plus an additional set of 10 charts for notable examples where the birth data is less reliable.
content_blocks.html: I’ve followed Robert’s advice on making use of AI to determine the samples for the next collection in my data project. It will focus on a very specific category of politically motivated gunshot deaths. The cases will be grouped into two sets of 10 charts, distinguishing whether the death was the result of execution or assassination, plus an additional set of 10 charts for notable examples where the birth data is less reliable.

items: Set 1: State-Sanctioned Executions / Revolutionary KillingsDeaths by gunshot carried out under government authority or regime approval during political revolution – cases with timed birth data (Rodden A, B or C)
Set 2: Political Assassinations (Non-State Sanctioned)Assassinations carried out by individuals or groups acting outside official authority – cases with timed birth data (Rodden A, B or C)

Set 3: Significant Cases with Limited Birth DataFamous or culturally significant cases from either category where birth data is missing or unreliable – noon charts used, with time-sensitive techniques removed from analysis

content_blocks.text: Robert suggested using AI to eliminate any unconscious personal selection bias in compiling a list of famous and historically significant cases. This sounds easy - but was not without issues! For example, Mata Hari was originally excluded, with AI stating that no reliable birth data existed. I had to point out that her chart carries an AA Rodden rating – at which point the system acknowledged the correction and moved her to the top of the list. It also included many cases that didn’t meet the criteria (such as executions by hanging - or the sybject wasn't even dead -!-), so the output needed a lot of careful filtering. AI isn’t the neutral arbiter we might hope for – its output requires human oversight to ensure relevance and accuracy.

This video uses Vimeo’s DNT parameter. Vimeo may still store and/or gain access to information on your device, including cookies and local storage.
Measuring Astrology – Recording & Follow-up
Skyscript
13 July
7
6
The video recording of the recent presentation exploring what it means to subject astrology to empirical scrutiny is now available in the members area and embedded in this post.
I got a lot from this event. Garry’s points about the inescapable subjectivity in how we work are very relevant, and it was great to have Robert guiding the discussion with the insight he brings as editor of Correlation. Below are some assets, additions, and follow-up notes linked to topics we touched on during the session.
Here’s what’s covered in this longer-than-usual recording mailout:
Giveaway: 3 Annual Subscriptions to Correlation
Follow-up Links:
Rawlins’ sTARBABY
Astrological Factors and Dog Behaviour
Where I’m Going Next – Gunshots & Firing Squads
Upcoming Events


1) Giveaway: 3 Annual Subscriptions to Correlation
Correlation is the Astrological Association’s peer-reviewed journal dedicated to research in astrology. It focuses on peer-reviewed studies that examine astrological claims using empirical methods, including statistical analysis, psychological testing, and historical review. Articles range from original research to reviews and theoretical discussion. It’s a valuable resource for astrologers interested in the relationship between astrology and science, or simply looking to stay informed on developments in astrological research.
Explore the journal here: https://correlationjournal.com
Thanks to Robert’s support, I have three annual digital subscriptions to Correlation to give away to Skyscript members. If you’d like to be entered into the draw, just comment beneath this post or email me at deb@skyscript.co.uk (be sure to include your Patreon member name). I’ll draw the winners at midnight UTC on Saturday 19 July and announce them the following day.
2) Follow-up Links
i) Rawlins’ sTARBABY
This is the detailed account of the American astronomer and reputed skeptic Dennis Rawlins, as published in Fate magazine in 1981, which describes his experience as a former member of CSICOP (Committee for the Scientific Investigation of Claims of the Paranormal). It gives a detailed account of how CSICOP mishandled the Gauquelin ‘Mars Effect’ data.
According to Rawlins, CSICOP’s attempt to replicate the Gauquelins’ findings actually confirmed the original result – showing a statistically significant link between Mars’ position and athletic eminence. However, senior members allegedly distorted the methodology and suppressed the outcome in order to preserve the organisation’s sceptical stance. Rawlins resigned and published sTARBABY as an exposé of what he called a serious breach of scientific integrity.
Read it here: https://www.newdualism.org/papers/D.Rawlins/Starbaby.html
ii) Astrological Factors and Dog Behaviour
This is the study Robert mentioned during the meeting – a 2007 paper from the Journal of Scientific Exploration which tested temperament traits in 500 pedigree puppies using astrological data. The study, conducted by Suzel Fuzeau‑Braesch and Jean‑Baptiste Denis, examined whether angular planetary positions correlated with behavioural traits such as dominance, extraversion, and sociability.
The results showed statistically significant associations: angular Mars and Jupiter, in particular, were linked to stronger dominance and extraversion. As the subjects were dogs, the study avoided common criticisms about bias in human cultural conditioning.
Read the study here:
https://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/document?doi=170986c26a09b16eb1e80f951e6d0489497b7d0d&repid=rep1&type=pdf
3) Where I’m Going Next – Gunshots and Firing Squads
I’ve followed Robert’s advice on making use of AI to determine the samples for the next collection in my data project. It will focus on a very specific category of politically motivated gunshot deaths. The cases will be grouped into two sets of 10 charts, distinguishing whether the death was the result of execution or assassination, plus an additional set of 10 charts for notable examples where the birth data is less reliable.
Set 1: State-Sanctioned Executions / Revolutionary Killings
Deaths by gunshot carried out under government authority or regime approval during political revolution – cases with timed birth data (Rodden A, B or C)
Set 2: Political Assassinations (Non-State Sanctioned)
Assassinations carried out by individuals or groups acting outside official authority – cases with timed birth data (Rodden A, B or C)
Set 3: Significant Cases with Limited Birth Data
Famous or culturally significant cases from either category where birth data is missing or unreliable – noon charts used, with time-sensitive techniques removed from analysis
Robert suggested using AI to eliminate any unconscious personal selection bias in compiling a list of famous and historically significant cases. This sounds easy - but was not without issues! For example, Mata Hari was originally excluded, with AI stating that no reliable birth data existed. I had to point out that her chart carries an AA Rodden rating – at which point the system acknowledged the correction and moved her to the top of the list. It also included many cases that didn’t meet the criteria (such as executions by hanging - or the sybject wasn't even dead -!-), so the output needed a lot of careful filtering. AI isn’t the neutral arbiter we might hope for – its output requires human oversight to ensure relevance and accuracy.
The problem I faced wasn’t choosing between many examples – it was identifying enough significant cases to form a group of 10 in each set. It took a lot of work, riddling through AI-generated results, prompting it again and again to correct itself and keep digging deeper.
That said, after many hours, the following list was achieved. I now have a very interesting set of charts to work from and I’m looking forward to seeing and sharing what the analysis reveals.
Set 1 – Executed (or regime-approved death involving gunshot)
Benito Mussolini – Rodden AA
Che Guevara – Rodden B
Mata Hari – Rodden AA
Nicolae Ceaușescu – Rodden AA
Claus von Stauffenberg – Rodden AA
Edith Cavell – Rodden A
José Rizal – Rodden B
Maximilian I of Mexico – Rodden AA
Víctor Jara – Rodden AA
Augusto César Sandino – Rodden AA
Set 2 – Assassinated
John F. Kennedy – Rodden A
Abraham Lincoln – Rodden B
Martin Luther King Jr. – Rodden A
Mahatma Gandhi – Rodden C
Franz Ferdinand – Rodden AA
Malcolm X – Rodden AA
Indira Gandhi – Rodden A
Yitzhak Rabin – Rodden C
Olof Palme – Rodden AA
Ninoy Aquino – Rodden A
Set 3 – Unidentified Times (Noon Chart Set)
Osama Bin Laden – Astro-databank
Anwar Sadat – Astro-databank
Benazir Bhutto – Astro-databank
Patrice Lumumba – Wikipedia
Nikolai II, Czar of Russia – Astro-databank
Vidkun Quisling – Wikipedia
Francisco Macías Nguema – Wikipedia
Jang Song-thaek – Wikipedia
Tony Frangieh – Wikipedia
Farrokhroo Parsa – Wikipedia
László Bárdossy – Wikipedia
4. Upcoming Events
Finally, an early heads-up about our next speaker event – a welcome return from Meira Epstein, offering us another chance to glean insights from expertise on the work of Ibn Ezra. Outline details in the graphic below, with full information to follow closer to the date.
Also, I’m currently liaising with Mireille to confirm the start date for the recommencement of the Manilius Reading Group. It’s tentatively set for 25th September, but we need to double-check a couple of details, so I’ll confirm that more securely soon.

Until next time,
Deb 🌟

content_blocks.html: PS: In my last message, I mentioned an ‘issue with Issuu’, the platform hosting flipbook versions of many Skyscript publications. For reasons that defy logic, their hosting costs have suddenly increased more than tenfold compared to what I was previously paying. Incredibly, they are now asking almost as much for a monthly subscription as their annual plan cost when I signed up three years ago.

content_blocks.text: Skyscript simply doesn’t have the budget to meet their inflated prices, and trying to resolve the issue has been draining and maddening – I've been stuck in a loop with unhelpful AI customer support, no matter how much I tried to get through to a living soul. The basic message every time is that the company has changed ownership and rates have now changed.

full_content:
A Fresh Edition: Skyscript Journal Issue 16
Skyscript
9 July
7
3
I’m genuinely delighted to release the long-awaited Issue 16. I really hope you enjoy it – I think this one’s a gem. It covers a lot of ground, and I’m certain it has something of value for every serious astrologer.
The edition is coded into the top of the members’ area, but if you want to go straight to it, you can use this direct link. I’ve also attached a low-resolution copy of the PDF to this post – but the digital edition is much better: higher resolution display and loaded with extras and cross-reference links.
Tip: Click the bullet list icon in the top bar to bring up the contents list – it makes navigation quick and easy. Details on how to purchase a hard copy at a low-priced members’ rate are also included at the end of this post.
My editorial gives a summary of the contents, so I won’t repeat that here. But one section I recommend checking quickly – if you’re planning to attend the Measuring Astrology presentation tomorrow – is the set of ten celebrity charts at the end. These form part of a personal study I’ll be discussing.
Here are the details of that event again – it will be recorded for those of you unable to attend live at this time:
📅 Thursday, 10 July 2025
🕖 Starting at 7pm UTC ← Click here to check the time in your locality
🔗 Zoom link: http://us06web.zoom.us/j/6123333126
🔒 Meeting password: Skyscript

PS: In my last message, I mentioned an ‘issue with Issuu’, the platform hosting flipbook versions of many Skyscript publications. For reasons that defy logic, their hosting costs have suddenly increased more than tenfold compared to what I was previously paying. Incredibly, they are now asking almost as much for a monthly subscription as their annual plan cost when I signed up three years ago.
Skyscript simply doesn’t have the budget to meet their inflated prices, and trying to resolve the issue has been draining and maddening – I've been stuck in a loop with unhelpful AI customer support, no matter how much I tried to get through to a living soul. The basic message every time is that the company has changed ownership and rates have now changed.
The good news is that Skyscript now has stronger facilities for hosting flipbooks directly on its own server. It was always part of my long-term plan to bring all content onto the site anyway – this just makes the task more urgent, and moves it to the top of my priority list. So, I’ll be moving almost everything away from Issuu as soon as I feasibly can. This newsletter is already hosted on-site, as are the older issues (there are links to each of the older issues on the back cover of issue 16).

Prefer to hold it?
It would be wonderful if, one day, subscriptions increased to the point where the journal could be produced as a print magazine – but it's nowhere near that possibility at present.
Currently, the only viable way to get an attractive hard copy is through Peecho’s print-on-demand service. It’s not a particularly cheap option, but it is a lovely edition, with beautiful layout, imagery, and high-quality glossy pages.
It’s available for public sale there at a cost of £21.99 + p&p. If you’d like to purchase a hard copy, please enter the following code at checkout to receive a 25% discount on that rate:
Purchase link:
https://www.peecho.com/print/en/1897988
Member discount code – enter at checkout:
Member 25

Thanks, as always, for your support – I really hope you enjoy the issue!
- Deb

About our speaker

Frank Cliffordhas built an eclectic, 35-year career as the writer of a dozen books, a consultant astrologer and palmist, a publisher/editor, a researcher of birth data, and the Principal of theLondon School of Astrology, which has branches in China and Japan. In 2012, he was the youngest recipient of a lifetime honour from the Astrological Association for his contribution to astrology, and a writing award from ISAR and various ISAR and Regulus Award (UAC) nominations have since followed. Frank Clifford has built an eclectic, 35-year career as the writer of a dozen books, a consultant astrologer and palmist, a publisher/editor, a researcher of birth data, and the Principal of the London School of Astrology, which has branches in China and Japan. In 2012, he was the youngest recipient of a lifetime honour from the Astrological Association for his contribution to astrology, and a writing award from ISAR and various ISAR and Regulus Award (UAC) nominations have since followed. In mid-2025 he is relaunching the Mountain Astrologer magazine as a multi-media publication. www.londonschoolofastrology.com

Manilius recording & publication of Books I & II
Skyscript
24 May
3
The recording of the recent Manilius Reading Group is attached to this post, and also linked into the showreel of all MRG recordings embedded in the member’s area, or available at:
https://vimeopro.com/stapresenter/manilius
(add password: Garrod)
As our exploration of Book II is now complete, I have collated all the annotated pages into a new digital publication, which is only available to Skyscript Members (the link is given here, and placed in two prominent places within the Member's area).
This is loaded with original research points, and many useful annotations, tables, diagrams and points of cross reference, and will be of great interest to anyone interested in the work of Manilius or the ancient development and practice of astrology.


Thank you for your continued support of this Skyscript Patreon project, because without your patronage, this kind of research would not be possible.  I want to apologise for the fact that I have been so busy creating, researching and coding over the last several months that I have barely managed to keep up with day-to-day correspondence, leaving me no extra time to keep you informed on all the many developments and additions that have been, and still are being made to Skyscript and its associated resources.  There is a lot of valuable work for me to update you on, and I hope to break through a barrier soon where I can find more time to share news more often and point you to all the new material that is coming through. 
But for now, staying on the topic of Manilius: I have yet to determine the date of the next Manilius Reading Group meeting, which will begin exploring the text of Book III using the 1977 translation of G. P. Goold.  Goold’s text is still under copyright, but we have obtained permission for the use of his translation of Book III only for our project. I will set the date for the next meeting once I have created shareable handouts for that.
Also, in the last meeting, there was some interesting discussion about how the arrangement of house themes reflected ancient Egyptian thoughts on the passage of the soul – and I thought this follow-up link might be of interest for anyone who wanted to delve into that.

Finally, a heads-up for our next Skyscript presentation meeting, delivered by Frank Clifford on the use of the consultation chart:
Friday, 6 June 2025
Starting at - 7pm UTC ← click this Time and Date link to check the time in your locality.
About our speaker
Frank Clifford has built an eclectic, 35-year career as the writer of a dozen books, a consultant astrologer and palmist, a publisher/editor, a researcher of birth data, and the Principal of the London School of Astrology, which has branches in China and Japan. In 2012, he was the youngest recipient of a lifetime honour from the Astrological Association for his contribution to astrology, and a writing award from ISAR and various ISAR and Regulus Award (UAC) nominations have since followed. In mid-2025 he is relaunching the Mountain Astrologer magazine as a multi-media publication. www.londonschoolofastrology.com

content_blocks.text: Date:Thurs, 8 May 2025Starting at -6 pm UTC← click this to see the time for you!Our Zoom link:http://us06web.zoom.us/j/6123333126Meeting password = Skyscript
Beneath a Blessed Blade: Surgical Elections
Astrological Elections & Surgery
content_blocks.html: Astrological Elections & Surgery

content_blocks.text: Guidelines for optimal surgical elections are included in some of the earliest astrological texts, and many of these aphorisms have become staple knowledge for all astrologers. Rhyan’s talk will explore the philosophy and evolution of the principles to help us apply them appropriately when working with modern scheduling factors to select safe surgery dates. We also explore demonstrations from high-profile celebrity surgeries to see how the presence or absence of certain rules may have shaped the outcome

Ryhan Butler presents for Skyscript today
Skyscript
8 May
1
A final reminder that we meet today for Ryhan Butler’s presentation on Surgical Elections
Date: Thurs, 8 May 2025
Starting at - 6 pm UTC ← click this to see the time for you!

Our Zoom link:
http://us06web.zoom.us/j/6123333126
Meeting password = Skyscript
Beneath a Blessed Blade: Surgical Elections
Astrological Elections & Surgery 
Guidelines for optimal surgical elections are included in some of the earliest astrological texts, and many of these aphorisms have become staple knowledge for all astrologers. Rhyan’s talk will explore the philosophy and evolution of the principles to help us apply them appropriately when working with modern scheduling factors to select safe surgery dates. We also explore demonstrations from high-profile celebrity surgeries to see how the presence or absence of certain rules may have shaped the outcome

About our speaker:
Ryhan Butler is a New Mexico based professional astrologer who has studied classical astrological techniques with an emphasis on medieval astrology since 2009. He hosts the Medieval Astrology Guide website and YouTube channel where he shares articles and video content about ancient medicine, astrology, and magic. He has also served the community on the boards of AFAN (now part of OPA) and ISAR. Outside of astrology, Ryhan volunteers for local feral cat rescue programs and Big Brothers Big Sisters.

Happy Easter!
The recording is attached for the recent illuminating and lively (note to self: must stop shouting in what I advertise as a ‘very friendly’ group, LOL) Manilius Reading Group, where we explored the ancient instruction on the dodecatemory divisions and their rulers. If anyone uses the dodecatemories or wants to dive a little deeper into their history and early use, there are some interesting new perspectives on this technique.

This recording is also linked into the member’s area and can be viewed as part of our showreel of past presentations. For the showreel of all the Manilius Reading Group meetings, go to:

This is a reminder that we gather around to read Manilius together on Thursday this week. Here’s the essential info:
Manilius Reading Group (continuing Book II)
Thurs, 17 April 2025
Starting at - 7:30 pm UTC ← click this Time and Date link to check the time in your locality.
Our Zoom link:

We are picking up the text of the Astronomica in book II, starting at line 692 (Garrod p.43 / Goold p.137). The section coming up is very interesting. It first introduces the topic of dodecatemories (12-fold divisions), then moves on to a crucial section on cardinal points before concluding book II with an account of house meanings.
I have prepared annotated/illustrated material for the passage we will cover in the meeting. These pages are attached to this post and I have already inserted them into our annotated edition of Garrod  - our new section starts on p.32 of that illustrated digital file.
Looking forward to joining up again with Mireille and all!

Reminder: we will soon reconnect for the next gathering of our lively/fun/friendly/informative Manilius Reading Group. Here’s the essential info to note:
Manilius Reading Group (continuing Book II)
Thurs, 17 April 2025
Starting at - 7:30 pm UTC ← click this Time and Date link to check the time in your locality.
Our Zoom link:
http://us06web.zoom.us/j/6123333126
Meeting password = Skyscript
Our ‘Reading Manilius’ meetings are held monthly and last around 75 mins. If you have never been before, don’t hesitate to join us – you will be made very welcome, and each meeting turns up something new and interesting for all of us.
In our next session, we pick up the text of the Astronomica in book II, starting at line 692 (Garrod p.43 / Goold p.137), which introduces the topic of dodecatemories (12-fold divisions) and then moves on to the very important section on houses.
(Despite my previous indications that the first section will possibly be a yawn for those of us who don’t use dodecatemories, there are elements of this passage that I found fascinating when preparing the material. I am excited and looking forward to covering that material together as a group now – it turned up some very interesting research points.)
I have prepared most of the annotated/illustrated material that we will cover in the next meeting. The new pages are attached to this post and I have already inserted them into our annotated edition of Garrod  - it starts on p.32 of that digital file.
If anyone wants to review any of the previous sessions, all have been recorded and can be watched on this link, which also has links to various Manilius reading resources. 
https://vimeopro.com/stapresenter/manilius 
To enter - add password: Garrod
Hope to see you then. I will leave you with the sage quote from Alexander Pope, used in footnote 99 of our annotated edition, which shows symbolic understanding of the ‘Pierian Spring’ Manilius refers to in this upcoming section (and nicely captures my thoughts that people shouldn’t dabble too half-heartedly with astrology) :)

Drink deep, or taste not the Pierian Spring

content_blocks.author: Karl Skellenger
content_blocks.text:
Here is more on generation Jones, a short blurb from Christopher Knowles secret history of rock and roll blog:

There was definitely a shift in '78, as the Gen Jonesers (1959-1964) came into their own and wanted their own music, not just their older siblings' hand-me-downs. To me, the Jonesers were the coolest cohort ever - tough, smart, cool, funny, sexy, free. The Boomers were too arrogant and self-righteous and cringe -- and we Xers were a bit too fractured by broken families and diminishing opportunities -- but the GJs really benefited from that Cindarella-zone sweet-spot. 

So once this heatwave breaks, bust out the grill and the chaise and let these glorious bursts of life and noise fill your soul and fuel your spirit.
https://open.spotify.com/playlist/6a0oU2xyev8oz0qit8ReHb?si=hJKwo60ZSoGKLHe34gcEkA&pi=Cs1pUubJQGeU8

content_blocks.author: Karl Skellenger
content_blocks.text:
Quite a lot comes to mind after listening to this informative lecture on the topic I've followed with some interest over the years. 
-- It is always fascinating to observe how generation X always remains invisible and always get a thorough lashing by the baby boomers.
-- Over the years I've been highly intrigued to observe that demographers of generations have been compelled to make a special carve out for people born around 1960-65, the time when I was born. I first heard this group described as the "wedgy" generation. More recently, I heard a more complementary  description calling this cohort the "Joneses" generation, this referring to both Jim Jones, and the idea of keeping up with the Joneses. The idea here is that this "Jones" group benefited from some of the wealth of the baby boomers while simultaneously being subjected to the growing scarcity of resources, forcing them to begin competing on a level not seen before (Jupiter/Saturn--Capricorn) 1961.
--  Carl Jung once remarked on the fact that one generation lives in the shadow of their parents and must subsequently be forced to compensate for their actual or perceived failings. This explains why they so often don't get on well with their parents, but also explains why we do get on so well with our grandparents. this is of course,  more true of the baby boomer generation and generation X, who were not exactly known to be best friends with their parents as some of the more recent generations are...

content_blocks.author: Skyscript
content_blocks.text: That makes sense to me. As one of the Joneses (I've never heard that before but prefer it to 'wedgy'), I had already wondered whether there might be some kind of 'cuspal' effect, because the BB bracket seems too wide for a period where life changed so dramatically - huge difference in life conditioning for parents giving birth at the end of the 1940s to those in the early 1960s.

Just this week i received my copy of Renn Butler’s ‘The Archetypal Universe’ and made my notes from Joy’s Generation talk in it. 

Early in the talk, I intuitively sensed the Generational vibe driving inner compass forces. They may have qualities and frequencies similarity to themes/programming similar to a miasm that are there for us to grow thru and with. 

“Homeopaths view miasms as underlying predispositions or chronic conditions that can manifest as various symptoms…”

Like the attendees pointed out, its not a cut/dry label that applies to the Generation. Although, we might notice that certain transits Trigger Generational groups within it  shifting their consciousness to action collectively in a certain way. 

I’m excited to let the info sink in and mature. ✨

Upcoming:
Our next gathering will be:
Manilius Reading Group (continuing Book II)
Thurs, 17 April 2025
Starting at - 7:30 pm UTC ← click this Time and Date link to check the time in your locality.
Our ‘Reading Manilius’ meetings are held monthly and last around 75 mins. In our next session, we pick up the text of the Astronomica in book II, starting at line 692 (Garrod p.43 / Goold p.137), which introduces the topic of dodecatemories (12-fold divisions).
(Despite my previous indications that this next section will possibly be a yawn for those of us who don’t use dodecatemories, there are elements of this passage that I found quite fascinating when preparing the material. So, I am excited and looking forward to covering that material together as a group now – it turned up some very interesting research points.)
More details, with Zoom link, to follow in the reminder post I will circulate next week.

content_blocks.text: Date:Thurs, 3 April 2025starting at -7 pm UTC← click this to see the time for you!Our Zoom link:http://us06web.zoom.us/j/6123333126Meeting password = Skyscript
Talking 'Bout My Generation
“Each generation imagines itself to be more intelligent than the one that went before it and wiser than the one that comes after it” - George Orwell

So much of our modern thinking has been influenced by the psychological model of dividing large groups of people according to the time period in which they were born. The term ‘generational influences’ is used for the division of generations into five basic groups and social media, advertising, political analysis, and financial planning are just some areas that use these models.

The term ‘generational influences’ is used for the division of generations into five basic groups and social media, advertising, political analysis, and financial planning are just some areas that use these models.

content_blocks.text: For instance, marketing research has shown that theBaby Boomers(60 – 78 years old) are the most loyal generation of consumers as they are reluctant to try new brands or products.Generation X(45 to 59 years old) tends to research businesses on the internet to find out more about the reliability of the product.Generation Y(30 to 44 years old) want brands to understand them, to connect with them, and to build a relationship of meaning and value.Generation Z(15 to 29 years old) are likely to buy products if influencers or content creators are recommending them as they will trust their opinions. There is even a strategy that exists behind marketing toGeneration Alpha(14 years to 1 year old) and that is to make sure content and messaging reflects a diverse range of perspectives, backgrounds, and experiences. content_blocks.html:
For instance, marketing research has shown that the Baby Boomers (60 – 78 years old) are the most loyal generation of consumers as they are reluctant to try new brands or products. Generation X (45 to 59 years old) tends to research businesses on the internet to find out more about the reliability of the product. Generation Y (30 to 44 years old) want brands to understand them, to connect with them, and to build a relationship of meaning and value. Generation Z (15 to 29 years old) are likely to buy products if influencers or content creators are recommending them as they will trust their opinions. There is even a strategy that exists behind marketing to Generation Alpha (14 years to 1 year old) and that is to make sure content and messaging reflects a diverse range of perspectives, backgrounds, and experiences. Gen Alpha is quick to notice and appreciate brands that embrace diversity. 

But is there an astrological basis to dividing over 80 years into five distinct groups? 
Each generation’s experience of the synodic cycles that occur during their age group gives an interesting insight into why the divisions work, and why each generation shares major characteristics which are unique to their age group, different to the one before them, or the one that follows them.

content_blocks.text: About our speaker:

Joy Usheris an Australian astrologer who began her studies in 1990 and completed them with Robert Zoller's Medieval Course in 1995. She began teaching astrology the year after and became co-principal ofAstroMundiwith Mari Garcia in 2002. She has continued to teach and consult over the past 30 years, lecturing at national and international conferences over this period. Recent collaboration with the Taiwanese schoolSkygaze Academy of Traditional Astrology(SATA) has extended her international reputation as a teacher and lecturer. In 2012 she co-authored an anthology of essays titledScala Coeli: Ladder to Heavenwith Mari Garcia. In 2018 she published two booksA Tiny UniverseandA Tiny Universe's Companion. Her third book,Munakara: Planets in Contentionis due to be released in 2025 with Revelore publishing house.

30 March

Please peg a note in your diary for our next speaker event this week.
Hope to see you there – I’ll be representing the BBs :)
Date: Thurs, 3 April 2025
starting at - 7 pm UTC ← click this to see the time for you!

Our Zoom link:
http://us06web.zoom.us/j/6123333126
Meeting password = Skyscript
Talking 'Bout My Generation 
“Each generation imagines itself to be more intelligent than the one that went before it and wiser than the one that comes after it” - George Orwell 
So much of our modern thinking has been influenced by the psychological model of dividing large groups of people according to the time period in which they were born. The term ‘generational influences’ is used for the division of generations into five basic groups and social media, advertising, political analysis, and financial planning are just some areas that use these models. 
For instance, marketing research has shown that the Baby Boomers (60 – 78 years old) are the most loyal generation of consumers as they are reluctant to try new brands or products. Generation X (45 to 59 years old) tends to research businesses on the internet to find out more about the reliability of the product. Generation Y (30 to 44 years old) want brands to understand them, to connect with them, and to build a relationship of meaning and value. Generation Z (15 to 29 years old) are likely to buy products if influencers or content creators are recommending them as they will trust their opinions. There is even a strategy that exists behind marketing to Generation Alpha (14 years to 1 year old) and that is to make sure content and messaging reflects a diverse range of perspectives, backgrounds, and experiences. Gen Alpha is quick to notice and appreciate brands that embrace diversity. 

But is there an astrological basis to dividing over 80 years into five distinct groups? 
Each generation’s experience of the synodic cycles that occur during their age group gives an interesting insight into why the divisions work, and why each generation shares major characteristics which are unique to their age group, different to the one before them, or the one that follows them.

About our speaker:
Joy Usher is an Australian astrologer who began her studies in 1990 and completed them with Robert Zoller's Medieval Course in 1995. She began teaching astrology the year after and became co-principal of AstroMundi with Mari Garcia in 2002. She has continued to teach and consult over the past 30 years, lecturing at national and international conferences over this period. Recent collaboration with the Taiwanese school Skygaze Academy of Traditional Astrology (SATA) has extended her international reputation as a teacher and lecturer. In 2012 she co-authored an anthology of essays titled Scala Coeli: Ladder to Heaven with Mari Garcia. In 2018 she published two books A Tiny Universe and A Tiny Universe's Companion. Her third book, Munakara: Planets in Contention is due to be released in 2025 with Revelore publishing house.

title: The president's astrologer: exploring the work of Joan Quigley (Joshua Hancock)

content_blocks.description: It is worth getting past the first 5-10 mins (intros, etc) then this becomes really interesting. Josh does a great job as narrator and Joan working for the Reagans is fascinating from so many different levels. (I love to think about the subtle manoeuvring and PR battle once the story broke and everyone felt the need to come out of an awkward situation with dented dignity in tact).

content_blocks.author: Leena Chauhan
content_blocks.text:
I really enjoyed learning about how Joan Quigley came to be astrologer to the Reagans, and about how her unique appointment became public news. 

I love that Quigley accepted and devoted herself to the weighty brief which Nancy invited her to accept for many years...until Nancy’s cover was blown. I love how, at that point, Quigley felt a sense of duty to astrology as well as to her own reputation to speak up about the true nature of her services to the President, and in turn the nation. As Josh notes, Quigley was a committed Republican. As an Arian, I guess she wasn’t going to take being airbrushed as a kindly friend-counsellor lying down! I recall hearing that Quigley used to cast all her charts by hand as software wasn’t yet available. She would have needed all her martial energy to keep up with the multiple scheduling requests made of her. Kudos to Joan.

Still, it was saddening if unsurprising to watch the gulf between Quigley and the TV interviewer as to the ’seriousness’ of her work. Given the level, depth and volume she worked at, and her own sense of purpose, she can be forgiven for finding unfathomable anyone questioning the importance of her work. I appreciated the video clip being included to 'feel the energy' of someone who is now a historical figure in astrology.

I love how, as a self-avowed astrologer with technical chops, Quigley also confidently followed her own intuition e.g. electing a trine to undo Carter in the first Carter-Reagan debate. The Aries does what wins the battle. Emplacing Gorbachev’s significator in ‘Ronnie’s’ first house for the Geneva Summit also reminded me how sticking to reliable, basic principles creates sound elections. Arian uncomplicated clarity.

Now I want to read ‘What Would Joan Say?’!

content_blocks.author: Skyscript
content_blocks.text: That point about her having to cast all the charts by hand is very relevant - and it applies to all historical astrologers too.

content_blocks.author: Elizabeth Barton
content_blocks.text:
If you want inside information on who was casting the charts for Joan, talk with Nicki Michaels of San Francisco.
She was casting the charts of all the world leaders for Regan.

When he made major announcements he didn’t want the people to hone in on, they used the Void of course moon.
Hence the name “Teflon Ron.”

FYI, Silva, I think her name is Hansen? Caroline Casey would know.
Silva and her friends attended astrology classes with Nancy in the early 1960’s.
The chart she gave as Regan’s has a different time.
I may still have it somewhere.

Nicki is still alive, not sure about Silvia.

content_blocks.author: Skyscript
content_blocks.text: Wonderful info - thank you Elizabeth!

Given the level, depth and volume she worked at, and her own sense of purpose, she can be forgiven for finding unfathomable anyone questioning the importance of her work. I appreciated the video clip being included to 'feel the energy' of someone who is now a historical figure in astrology.

I love how, as a self-avowed astrologer with technical chops, Quigley also confidently followed her own intuition e.g. electing a trine to undo Carter in the first Carter-Reagan debate. The Aries does what wins the battle. Emplacing Gorbachev’s significator in ‘Ronnie’s’ first house for the Geneva Summit also reminded me how sticking to reliable, basic principles creates sound elections. Arian uncomplicated clarity.

Now I want to read ‘What Would Joan Say?’!

2

That point about her having to cast all the charts by hand is very relevant - and it applies to all historical astrologers too.

She was casting the charts of all the world leaders for Regan.

When he made major announcements he didn’t want the people to hone in on, they used the Void of course moon.
Hence the name “Teflon Ron.”

Silva and her friends attended astrology classes with Nancy in the early 1960’s.
The chart she gave as Regan’s has a different time.
I may still have it somewhere.

Nicki is still alive, not sure about Silvia.

After the meeting I did some more research into the end points we covered – the association of aspects with relationship groups, and the awkward comment that quadrate signs form squares and divide the circle into four but “are not reckoned under the law of squares”. I realised that Goold treats that particular point with more clarity than Garrod, so I have changed the annotated handout pages to draw from him and added in an extra diagram – the revised pages for last nights reading are attached to this post.

content_blocks.text: Erigone

Some mention was made last night to the labelling of Virgo as Erigone.  Since our meeting was held as the Moon moved into its eclipse, we enjoyed recalling the tragic story of Erigone (and her dad and her dog).  I promised to find the bit where it had been previously discussed and mention it here.Manilius usually refers to Virgo by the name of Erigone, and it is in his second book, line 31 (Goold 85/ Garrod 3) where he says that this constellation honours her “for her filial affection (Goold) / justice (Garrod).  Here isthe annotationI added to that point:
content_blocks.html:
Some mention was made last night to the labelling of Virgo as Erigone.  Since our meeting was held as the Moon moved into its eclipse, we enjoyed recalling the tragic story of Erigone (and her dad and her dog).  I promised to find the bit where it had been previously discussed and mention it here. 
Manilius usually refers to Virgo by the name of Erigone, and it is in his second book, line 31 (Goold 85/ Garrod 3) where he says that this constellation honours her “for her filial affection (Goold) / justice (Garrod).  Here is the annotation I added to that point:

content_blocks.text: Myth records Erigone to be the daughter of Icarius (Ikarios), a devotee of Dionysus in Athens. After Icarius was stoned to death by shepherds who became intoxicated on the wine he kindly gave them, his body was hidden under a tree. Erigone’s faithful dog, Maira, found his body and grief-struck Erigone cursed the city before hanging herself from the same tree. Then Maira jumped into a well and drowned. Infuriated Dionysus placed the Maiden in heaven to commemorate her piety, along with Icarius in the stars of Boötes and Maira in Canis Major, then inflicted Athens with a terrible drought. Erigone’s curse resulted in a widespread spate of other Athenian maidens killing themselves in the same manner as Erigone. The wrath of Dionysus was only appeased when the Athenians introduced an annual festival to honour the dead – dedicated to Erigone and called theAeora(the Swing) it involved hanging icons and offerings from trees, sacrificing fruit, and young women ritualistically swinging on trees in sympathy with the suicidal maidens. (In view of this myth, it is interesting to note that a 2003 statistical survey by E. Salib of the University of Liverpool established a significantly increased distribution of suicide by hanging by those born when the Sun is in Virgo (details:pubmed.nci.nih.gov).The reference to justice Manilius makes portrays a more general theme of Virgo symbolism, as depicted in the description of Virgo recorded by Aratus (98ff.):

Beneath both feet of Boötes mark the Maiden, who in her hands bears the gleaming Ear of Corn … Her men called Justice; but she assembling the elders, it might be in the market-place or in the wide-wayed streets, uttered her voice, ever urging on them judgements kinder to the people.
We had an intersting discussion of this point in our Meeting 10 last year  (direct link| password Garrod) - we begin discussing the issue of Erigone 10 minutes into that recording.

Manilius Reading Group 14 recording

14 March
1
I've attached the recording of yesterday's Manilius Meeting Group meeting for those who are following and were unable to attend.
Reminder: ALL archived recordings of our Manilius meetings can also be viewed on this link:
https://vimeopro.com/stapresenter/manilius
Add the password: Garrod
After the meeting I did some more research into the end points we covered – the association of aspects with relationship groups, and the awkward comment that quadrate signs form squares and divide the circle into four but “are not reckoned under the law of squares”. I realised that Goold treats that particular point with more clarity than Garrod, so I have changed the annotated handout pages to draw from him and added in an extra diagram – the revised pages for last nights reading are attached to this post.
(I believe the purpose of that comment is only to say that the quadruplicity groups divide the circle of the zodiac into four but do not relate to the rules that quarter the celestial sphere into the four cardinal points.)
Erigone
Some mention was made last night to the labelling of Virgo as Erigone.  Since our meeting was held as the Moon moved into its eclipse, we enjoyed recalling the tragic story of Erigone (and her dad and her dog).  I promised to find the bit where it had been previously discussed and mention it here. 
Manilius usually refers to Virgo by the name of Erigone, and it is in his second book, line 31 (Goold 85/ Garrod 3) where he says that this constellation honours her “for her filial affection (Goold) / justice (Garrod).  Here is the annotation I added to that point:
Myth records Erigone to be the daughter of Icarius (Ikarios), a devotee of Dionysus in Athens. After Icarius was stoned to death by shepherds who became intoxicated on the wine he kindly gave them, his body was hidden under a tree. Erigone’s faithful dog, Maira, found his body and grief-struck Erigone cursed the city before hanging herself from the same tree. Then Maira jumped into a well and drowned. Infuriated Dionysus placed the Maiden in heaven to commemorate her piety, along with Icarius in the stars of Boötes and Maira in Canis Major, then inflicted Athens with a terrible drought. Erigone’s curse resulted in a widespread spate of other Athenian maidens killing themselves in the same manner as Erigone. The wrath of Dionysus was only appeased when the Athenians introduced an annual festival to honour the dead – dedicated to Erigone and called the Aeora (the Swing) it involved hanging icons and offerings from trees, sacrificing fruit, and young women ritualistically swinging on trees in sympathy with the suicidal maidens. (In view of this myth, it is interesting to note that a 2003 statistical survey by E. Salib of the University of Liverpool established a significantly increased distribution of suicide by hanging by those born when the Sun is in Virgo (details: pubmed.nci.nih.gov).
The reference to justice Manilius makes portrays a more general theme of Virgo symbolism, as depicted in the description of Virgo recorded by Aratus (98 ff.):
Beneath both feet of Boötes mark the Maiden, who in her hands bears the gleaming Ear of Corn … Her men called Justice; but she assembling the elders, it might be in the market-place or in the wide-wayed streets, uttered her voice, ever urging on them judgements kinder to the people.
We had an intersting discussion of this point in our Meeting 10 last year (direct link  | password Garrod) - we begin discussing the issue of Erigone 10 minutes into that recording.

In the next meeting, we pick up the text of book II, starting at line 693 (Garrod p.43 / Goold p.137) which introduces the theory of dodecatemories (12-fold sign divisions) before moving on to the topic of angles and house division.

content_blocks.html: Quick reminder that we meet again tomorrow for our next Manilius Reading Group meeting.

content_blocks.text: Manilius Reading Group (continuing Book II)Thurs, 13 Match 2025starting at -8 pm UTC← click this to see the time for you!Our Zoom link:http://us06web.zoom.us/j/6123333126Meeting password = Skyscript

We are continuing book II, picking up at line 520 (Goold p.123 /Garrod p.33), where we go further into exploring the subtleties of sign relationships based on triplicity arrangements and other details that create hostilities or alliances.  Once the principles are understood, this is an interesting passage for showing how two signs in relationship don't necessarily react and respond in the same way to each other.I am still working on tables/diagrams/annotations that ease understanding of the verse (it was almost done and then my computer crashed!).  I don't mind too much though, because I have since realised there is a better way to tabulate the info, so now I have a good reason to start some points again.  I will have this all finished some time tomorrow and will circulate ahead of the meeting - look forward to meeting up with Mireille and group members then!

Skyscript

Quick reminder that we meet again tomorrow for our next Manilius Reading Group meeting.
Manilius Reading Group (continuing Book II)
Thurs, 13 Match 2025
starting at - 8 pm UTC ← click this to see the time for you!

Our Zoom link:
http://us06web.zoom.us/j/6123333126
Meeting password = Skyscript
We are continuing book II, picking up at line 520 (Goold p.123 / Garrod p.33), where we go further into exploring the subtleties of sign relationships based on triplicity arrangements and other details that create hostilities or alliances. Once the principles are understood, this is an interesting passage for showing how two signs in relationship don't necessarily react and respond in the same way to each other.

I am still working on tables/diagrams/annotations that ease understanding of the verse (it was almost done and then my computer crashed!). I don't mind too much though, because I have since realised there is a better way to tabulate the info, so now I have a good reason to start some points again. I will have this all finished some time tomorrow and will circulate ahead of the meeting - look forward to meeting up with Mireille and group members then!

title: Canada's new PM: Mark Carney

Skyscript
10 March
content_blocks.html: 10 March

content_blocks.text: Noon chart for Mark Carney: in “the next few days” he will be sworn in as the new Prime Minister of Canada, ending Trudeau’s 10-year  run.
content_blocks.html: Noon chart for Mark Carney: in “the next few days” he will be sworn in as the new Prime Minister of Canada, ending Trudeau’s 10-year  run.

content_blocks.text: Carney’s Saturn opposition to Pluto (+Uranus/Mars/Moon) in Virgo – squared by his nodal axis – guarantees an eye on details with super-firm resolve. This draws out the theme of the 2025 Ingress for Canada, which has Pluto tight on the ascendant, squared by an elevated Moon. Note the Saturn dominance, general affliction, and nodal highlight of the 2nd house cusp in the Canada ingress. Everything is pouring into this house – clearly describing the import tax trade war dominating the political scene.

content_blocks.text: Now note how the degree on the ingress 2nd-cusp (26 Pisces)  is the degree of Carney’s natal Sun. His strong background in economic management makes him the perfect person to take on this difficult task. (Brits know Carney from TV appearances as Governor of the Bank of England, 2013-2020, when he periodically stepped in with action to protect the economy).

Noon chart for Mark Carney: in “the next few days” he will be sworn in as the new Prime Minister of Canada, ending Trudeau’s 10-year  run.
Carney’s Saturn opposition to Pluto (+Uranus/Mars/Moon) in Virgo – squared by his nodal axis – guarantees an eye on details with super-firm resolve. This draws out the theme of the 2025 Ingress for Canada, which has Pluto tight on the ascendant, squared by an elevated Moon. Note the Saturn dominance, general affliction, and nodal highlight of the 2nd house cusp in the Canada ingress. Everything is pouring into this house – clearly describing the import tax trade war dominating the political scene.

Now note how the degree on the ingress 2nd-cusp (26 Pisces)  is the degree of Carney’s natal Sun. His strong background in economic management makes him the perfect person to take on this difficult task. (Brits know Carney from TV appearances as Governor of the Bank of England, 2013-2020, when he periodically stepped in with action to protect the economy).
That ingress 2nd house is ruled by Jupiter: angular but in detriment in the ingress 4th house, opposed by the elevated Moon. So also note how that ingress Jupiter, at 14 Gemini, lights up the grand cross between Carney’s Pluto and the stellium of planets around it, Saturn and his nodal axis.  No doubt he is the right man for Canada now, and this is the right time for him to take office.

content_blocks.author: Theodora Vasilopoulou
content_blocks.text:
Thank you so much for this presentation ! :) Just a quick thought: In Greek Orthodoxy, the number 40 is a big deal because it marks moments of transition and change. You see it everywhere: Christ fasted for 40 days before starting his ministry, the Great Flood lasted 40 days, Moses spent 40 days on Mount Sinai, and after his resurrection, Christ stayed on Earth for 40 days before ascending to Heaven.

This idea carries over into everyday Orthodox traditions. When a baby is born, they aren’t brought to church right away. Instead, they’re welcomed on the 40th day in a blessing called Sarantismos, just like Christ was presented at the temple. When someone passes away, their family holds a memorial service on the 40th day because it’s believed that the soul goes through a journey before reaching its resting place. Even fasting periods, like Lent, last 40 days; it’s seen as the right amount of time to prepare for something important.

How Sufis dance with Saturn and Mars
content_blocks.html: How Sufis dance with Saturn and Mars

content_blocks.text: During her studies on the astrology of the Ottoman Empire, Barış gained new perspectives on Mars and Saturn from the 13th century texts of Nasir al-Din al-Tusi. His writings, as yet untranslated into English, offer ethical guidelines on becoming more cognizant of these two ‘inauspicious’ planets so as to better manage their conditions and significations.In this presentation, Barış combines perspectives from al-Tusi with her long-standing research on integrating Sufism into horoscope interpretation. She will discuss the effects of these two planets on solidification, generation and personal growth, so you should leave this talk with a new set of ideas on navigating Mars and Saturn in your chartwork.
About our speaker:
content_blocks.html: About our speaker:

content_blocks.text: Baris Ilhanhas been a full-time astrologer since 1993 and is one of the leading astrologers in Turkey. She founded an astrological publishing house and an astrology school,Ilhan Astrology Institutein 1997.Baris writes astrology artcles for Radikal newspaper, and wrote two books: “The Puberty Age of Adults,” which is about planetary cycles, and “Astrology Lessons,” a text-book for the students. She is currently conducting research on 13th century Islamic astrologer Nasir al-Din al-Tusi. She is President of NCGR-Turkey, a member of ISAR and AFAN, and serves on NCGR’s Advisory Board.Visit Baris's website athttps://www.barisilhan.com

His writings, as yet untranslated into English, offer ethical guidelines on becoming more cognizant of these two ‘inauspicious’ planets so as to better manage their conditions and significations.In this presentation, Barış combines perspectives from al-Tusi with her long-standing research on integrating Sufism into horoscope interpretation. She will discuss the effects of these two planets on solidification, generation and personal growth, so you should leave this talk with a new set of ideas on navigating Mars and Saturn in your chartwork.

Note this presentation is delivered on Sunday - apologies that the time is awkward for those of you outside of Europe but it will be recorded for members unable to attend the live event


How Sufis dance with Saturn and Mars
During her studies on the astrology of the Ottoman Empire, Barış gained new perspectives on Mars and Saturn from the 13th century texts of Nasir al-Din al-Tusi. His writings, as yet untranslated into English, offer ethical guidelines on becoming more cognizant of these two ‘inauspicious’ planets so as to better manage their conditions and significations.
In this presentation, Barış combines perspectives from al-Tusi with her long-standing research on integrating Sufism into horoscope interpretation. She will discuss the effects of these two planets on solidification, generation and personal growth, so you should leave this talk with a new set of ideas on navigating Mars and Saturn in your chartwork.

About our speaker:
Baris Ilhan has been a full-time astrologer since 1993 and is one of the leading astrologers in Turkey. She founded an astrological publishing house and an astrology school, Ilhan Astrology Institute in 1997.
Baris writes astrology artcles for Radikal newspaper, and wrote two books: “The Puberty Age of Adults,” which is about planetary cycles, and “Astrology Lessons,” a text-book for the students. She is currently conducting research on 13th century Islamic astrologer Nasir al-Din al-Tusi. She is President of NCGR-Turkey, a member of ISAR and AFAN, and serves on NCGR’s Advisory Board.

Visit Baris's website at https://www.barisilhan.com

content_blocks.text: The meeting began with a review of recent developments on Skyscript for mundane astrologers, highlighting in particular the ongoing development of the Mundane Matters webpage atskyscript.co.uk/mm.html.This now features the ability to 'pop out' any number of charts and give them focus by creating a blank screen behind them.The discussion then focussed on Israel by way of exploring the key charts provided in the 'Israel' section of that page.

The discussion then focussed on Israel by way of exploring the key charts provided in the 'Israel' section of that page.

The recording for yesterday's MM matters meeting is attached to this post. It is also linked into the Membertalk showreel hosted in the Members area.
The meeting began with a review of recent developments on Skyscript for mundane astrologers, highlighting in particular the ongoing development of the Mundane Matters webpage at skyscript.co.uk/mm.html. This now features the ability to 'pop out' any number of charts and give them focus by creating a blank screen behind them.

The discussion then focussed on Israel by way of exploring the key charts provided in the 'Israel' section of that page.
Thank you to everyone who attended and for the lovely feedback comments provided in the chat box re the improving facilities of the mm page :)

Our next meeting will be a Sunday event, presented by Baris Ilhan. Here's the preliminary info now, and I'll circulate a fuller reminder in early March

16 February
content_blocks.html: 16 February

content_blocks.text: Thanks again to Garry for his stimulating exploration of 'How Astrology is True'.
content_blocks.html: Thanks again to Garry for his stimulating exploration of 'How Astrology is True'.

content_blocks.text: For those unable to attend live, the video can be viewed here, or via the full showreel of past talks in the Skyscript members area -https://www.skyscript.co.uk/patron
content_blocks.html: For those unable to attend live, the video can be viewed here, or via the full showreel of past talks in the Skyscript members area - https://www.skyscript.co.uk/patron

content_blocks.text: Follow up thoughts and a plan to revisit ...

Gary emailed me the following day with some extra thoughts he wished he’d expressed in response to one of my comments. (Doesn’t it always happen that you think of the perfect response after the conversation?)  I also spent much of the next day musing on some of the issues touched on in the after-chat. I ought to have better articulated my view that horary and mundane astrology are more connected in philosophy and principle than we tend to acknowledge. (I see every horary as, in some way, bearing out a mundane theme, which becomes personalised through whatever is the focus-context for the individual. Planets don’t move out of their cycles to answer our questions, so with horary it is not so much that ‘the question comes to us’ but that ‘ we come to the question’. Garry’sLuna-Sea(cy) chart was a perfect example – a dramatic ‘flood’ theme in the mundane emerges in a highly personalised, yet-still-connected, form via horary).
content_blocks.html: Gary emailed me the following day with some extra thoughts he wished he’d expressed in response to one of my comments. (Doesn’t it always happen that you think of the perfect response after the conversation?)  I also spent much of the next day musing on some of the issues touched on in the after-chat. I ought to have better articulated my view that horary and mundane astrology are more connected in philosophy and principle than we tend to acknowledge. (I see every horary as, in some way, bearing out a mundane theme, which becomes personalised through whatever is the focus-context for the individual. Planets don’t move out of their cycles to answer our questions, so with horary it is not so much that ‘the question comes to us’ but that ‘ we come to the question’. Garry’s Luna-Sea(cy) chart was a perfect example – a dramatic ‘flood’ theme in the mundane emerges in a highly personalised, yet-still-connected, form via horary).

content_blocks.text: It feels that there is still more for us to push towards here in the pursuit of honing that Truth. Most well-informed, experienced astrologers appear to accept that the ‘mechanism’ of astrology is not expected to work reliably in a mechanical, linear fashion.  Yet it is frustrating, trying to grasp that point where the veracity of astrology moves from being subjective, internally recognised, and dependent on an interpretative conduit (the astrologer) to something that can be relied on whether a human mind is engaged or not.

content_blocks.text: Is there, in fact, any external objective truth in astrology? If so, why is this so elusive to astrologers who want to counter the criticisms of sceptics? (I believe there is, BTW – I also believe that falling trees make sounds, even if no one hears them)
content_blocks.html: Is there, in fact, any external objective truth in astrology? If so, why is this so elusive to astrologers who want to counter the criticisms of sceptics? (I believe there is, BTW – I also believe that falling trees make sounds, even if no one hears them)

content_blocks.text: Garry’s presentation was an extremely interesting catalyst for stirring ideas and taking this conversation further. We only had limited time for follow-up discussion last Thursday so I propose that we revisit this theme in a few months, next time purely as a panel discussion with group interaction, building on the expectation that participants will have watched Garry’s talk already and had some time to digest and reflect on the issues raised.
