Recording of Garry Phillipson's talk now available (and other news)
Skyscript
16 February
4
Thanks again to Garry for his stimulating exploration of 'How Astrology is True'.
For those unable to attend live, the video can be viewed here, or via the full showreel of past talks in the Skyscript members area - https://www.skyscript.co.uk/patron
Follow up thoughts and a plan to revisit ...
Gary emailed me the following day with some extra thoughts he wished he’d expressed in response to one of my comments. (Doesn’t it always happen that you think of the perfect response after the conversation?)  I also spent much of the next day musing on some of the issues touched on in the after-chat. I ought to have better articulated my view that horary and mundane astrology are more connected in philosophy and principle than we tend to acknowledge. (I see every horary as, in some way, bearing out a mundane theme, which becomes personalised through whatever is the focus-context for the individual. Planets don’t move out of their cycles to answer our questions, so with horary it is not so much that ‘the question comes to us’ but that ‘ we come to the question’. Garry’s Luna-Sea(cy) chart was a perfect example – a dramatic ‘flood’ theme in the mundane emerges in a highly personalised, yet-still-connected, form via horary).
It feels that there is still more for us to push towards here in the pursuit of honing that Truth. Most well-informed, experienced astrologers appear to accept that the ‘mechanism’ of astrology is not expected to work reliably in a mechanical, linear fashion.  Yet it is frustrating, trying to grasp that point where the veracity of astrology moves from being subjective, internally recognised, and dependent on an interpretative conduit (the astrologer) to something that can be relied on whether a human mind is engaged or not.
Is there, in fact, any external objective truth in astrology? If so, why is this so elusive to astrologers who want to counter the criticisms of sceptics? (I believe there is, BTW – I also believe that falling trees make sounds, even if no one hears them)
Garry’s presentation was an extremely interesting catalyst for stirring ideas and taking this conversation further. We only had limited time for follow-up discussion last Thursday so I propose that we revisit this theme in a few months, next time purely as a panel discussion with group interaction, building on the expectation that participants will have watched Garry’s talk already and had some time to digest and reflect on the issues raised.
I have already floated this idea with Garry, and he is up for it. I expect to put this on the calendar during the summer, so stay tuned for more news on that – and let me know if you want to participate directly with an angle to add.

Let me add here some of the links placed in the chat to resources mentioned during Garry's talk:
https://cosmocritic.com - the website maintained by Garry and Kirk Little which features rare and significant texts about astrology – what it is, how it works and how to evaluate it
https://www.skyscript.co.uk/rev_nasser.html - Kirk Little’s review of Under One Sky  by Rafael Nasser, published in 2004
https://karlskellenger.substack.com/p/men-at-war-under-the-dark-sun-of - recent article by Karl Skellenger on significance of the 17th degree & Neptune ingress into Aries


Important notice on upcoming talks:
As mentioned in the meeting, the next Manilius Reading Group meeting is being pushed back a couple of weeks to allow that meeting date – 27th February – to be used for a Mundane Matters discussion instead.  In this we will look at the upcoming eclipse, and some relevant nativities/mundane themes that impact the peace prospects for Israel and surrounding nations.
To clarify, the details of our upcoming events are as follows (I’ll circulate reminders for each event one week in advance):
Feb 27  (Thurs) - 8:00 pm UTC - Mundame Matters (current events, open discussion) - focus on upcoming eclipse & Israel
Mar 9 (Sun) - 11:00 am UTC   - How Sufis dance with Saturn and Mars with Baris Ilhan
Mar 13 (Thurs) - 8:00 pm UTC - Reading MANILIUS: Astronomica, book II
Be sure to note the Sunday presentation on 9th March, delivered by top international astrologer Baris Ilhan, who will share insights from her unique research and expertise.
Also note that bookings are being take now for the InMundo World Astrology Summit hosted by Wade Caves. This is not a free event, but there is a discounted price of $85 available to you as a Skyscript Patreon for the full 2-day  program.



MUNDANE resources on Skyscript
I’ll close by letting you know that the Mundane Matters Skyscript page is back online now with many improvements: 

https://www.skyscript.co.uk/mm.html  

I mentioned the scripting developments in progress for this page – they are still ongoing so not fully implemented yet. I'm not ready to promote the page publicly but giving you a heads up because the interim page is still bursting with useful mundane charts that are easily cross-referenced with each other. (This has been my life of late – I have added a *lot* of new charts ... charts ... tables ... diagrams ..., with a lot more currently ‘in process’).

Check out the improvements in the Skyscript Eclipse section too, because oodles of work have been poured into that. It now includes visuals of eclipse charts through to 2030 along with easy-to-access tables of eclipse degrees that range from 1500-2500 AD. I have the full set of lunation charts preprepared as chart visuals too, through to 2030 - they are preprogrammed to appear on site at the appropriate time and when I have a little more time I will put them together in a booklet to distribute to members.
https://www.skyscript.co.uk/eclipse.html

BTW, here is the chart for the timing of the Peace agreement between Israel and Hamas - one of the charts we can consider together in our upcoming Mundame Matters meeting on the 27th.




It was lovely to connect with everyone as we listened to Garry.
Peace be with you.
Have a great weekend
Deb

How Astrology is True
The issues in this title will be explored from two perspectives.
content_blocks.html: The issues in this title will be explored from two perspectives.

content_blocks.text: The first is that of astrology’s critics: to consider how and why their arguments are valid up to a point, yet based on questionable beliefs thereafter.
content_blocks.html: The first is that of astrology’s critics: to consider how and why their arguments are valid up to a point, yet based on questionable beliefs thereafter.

content_blocks.text: The second is that of astrologers who experience the truth of astrology on a regular basis but struggle to articulate how it works, or indeed why the cosmos has such a nature that astrology – despite what can seem to an outsider like its implausibility – is true. As part of this, Garry will look at what practical consequences the emerging picture has for the way we practise astrology today.
content_blocks.html: The second is that of astrologers who experience the truth of astrology on a regular basis but struggle to articulate how it works, or indeed why the cosmos has such a nature that astrology – despite what can seem to an outsider like its implausibility – is true. As part of this, Garry will look at what practical consequences the emerging picture has for the way we practise astrology today.

content_blocks.text: About our speaker:

Garry Phillipsonis a tutor and supervisor for MA and PhD students ofCultural Astronomy and Astrologywith the Sophia Centre. His interests include the philosophy, practice and history of astrology; and religious thought and practice, particularly Theravadan Buddhism, Advaita Vedanta and neo-Advaita. Garry read philosophy at the University of East Anglia and completed his PhD in 2020. His doctoral thesis, ‘Astrology and Truth’, discusses the truth-status of horoscopic astrology in the context of western epistemology. He is the author ofAstrology in the Year Zero(London: Flare, 2000, 2nd edition forthcoming) and has written and spoken about astrology, and strategies for its comprehension, in many settings. Along with Kirk Little he curates the websiteCosmocritic.com– a repository of freely downloadable resources with a focus on the philosophy of astrology.

content_blocks.text: I've attached the recording of yesterday's Manilius Meeting Group meeting for those who are following and were unable to attend.
content_blocks.html: I've attached the recording of yesterday's Manilius Meeting Group meeting for those who are following and were unable to attend.

content_blocks.text: All archived recordings can also be viewed on this link:
content_blocks.html: All archived recordings can also be viewed on this link:

content_blocks.text: https://vimeopro.com/stapresenter/maniliusAdd the password:Garrod

A question arose in the group about whether the audentia have a different interpretational flavour than the videntia. Since these techniques are embedded in the principle of antiscia, this detailed article on Skyscript is useful for exploring that theme more deeply, and does give a glimpse of a distinction between them.The Classical Basis of Antiscia and Contra-antiscia -https://www.skyscript.co.uk/antiscia.htmlOf relevance to this point:
content_blocks.html:
A question arose in the group about whether the audentia have a different interpretational flavour than the videntia. Since these techniques are embedded in the principle of antiscia, this detailed article on Skyscript is useful for exploring that theme more deeply, and does give a glimpse of a distinction between them.

The Classical Basis of Antiscia and Contra-antiscia - https://www.skyscript.co.uk/antiscia.html

Of relevance to this point:

content_blocks.text: Manilius and other ancient authors called such signs audentia, 'signs which hear each other'. William Lilly refers to signs that are 'commanding and obeying' on page 92 of Christian Astrology, but doesn't offer a description of their meaning. The Greek astrologer Paulus Alexandrinus noted that signs which 'hear each other' dispose well for the flight of fugitives, for going abroad, and for accusations, suggesting that there is some divisive element attributed to their meaning.[16]This technique may appear to have dropped from favour in later tradition, but in fact it gives us the contra-antiscia, which Lilly tells us to find by simply looking for the point in opposition to the antiscia. This is correct because the reflection of a degree across the equinoctial axis lies opposite to that which reflects across the tropical axis. ...Antiscion gives us instead a notion of 'likeness'[17] based upon the similarity of the degree of the zodiac as it relates to rising times and the equality of days and nights. In contra-antiscia, it is based upon an inverse reflection because the days of one are mirrored by the night of the other. With antiscion a more immediately equivalent factor is involved; with contra-antiscion it is an opposing principle so the relationship is more difficult or antipathetic. These philosophical principles tally with William Lilly's assessment:"as there are antiscia, which of the good planets we think are equal to a sextile or trine, so there are contra-antiscions, which we find to be of the nature of a square or opposition".[18]

Within the meeting Joy gave reference to Schoener's table of body part associations, and has provided the PDF of that part of Schoener in case anyone wants to check that out (I believe this is from the Rob Hand translation, that we spoke about in our chat). For more about Schoener, and his nativity - see this Skyscript page which Joy co-authored with Mari Garci:https://www.skyscript.co.uk/schoener_intro.html

In the next meeting, we pick up the text of book II, starting at line 520 (Garrod p.33 / Goold p.123). I hope to have the annotated pages done well before that date and will circulate in advance when I can.
content_blocks.html: In the next meeting, we pick up the text of book II, starting at line 520 (Garrod p.33 / Goold p.123). I hope to have the annotated pages done well before that date and will circulate in advance when I can.

content_blocks.text: PS - I am trying very hard not to think about the horoscope of Augustus, since that will open up a can of worms I can't afford to look into right now, LOL. But the more I think about it, the more I agree with Garrod - Manilius was too close to the event and too insistent that Capricorn was his rising sign for the later charts that show other signs rising to be correct. They usually try to fit with the Capricorn coins by suggesting Capricorn was his Moon sign - but Manilius is clear, Capricorn was the sign on the ascendant (he really leaves no doubt about that).

Add the password: Garrod

A question arose in the group about whether the audentia have a different interpretational flavour than the videntia. Since these techniques are embedded in the principle of antiscia, this detailed article on Skyscript is useful for exploring that theme more deeply, and does give a glimpse of a distinction between them.

The Classical Basis of Antiscia and Contra-antiscia - https://www.skyscript.co.uk/antiscia.html

Of relevance to this point:
Manilius and other ancient authors called such signs audentia, 'signs which hear each other'. William Lilly refers to signs that are 'commanding and obeying' on page 92 of Christian Astrology, but doesn't offer a description of their meaning. The Greek astrologer Paulus Alexandrinus noted that signs which 'hear each other' dispose well for the flight of fugitives, for going abroad, and for accusations, suggesting that there is some divisive element attributed to their meaning.[16]

This technique may appear to have dropped from favour in later tradition, but in fact it gives us the contra-antiscia, which Lilly tells us to find by simply looking for the point in opposition to the antiscia. This is correct because the reflection of a degree across the equinoctial axis lies opposite to that which reflects across the tropical axis. ...

Antiscion gives us instead a notion of 'likeness'[17] based upon the similarity of the degree of the zodiac as it relates to rising times and the equality of days and nights. In contra-antiscia, it is based upon an inverse reflection because the days of one are mirrored by the night of the other. With antiscion a more immediately equivalent factor is involved; with contra-antiscion it is an opposing principle so the relationship is more difficult or antipathetic. These philosophical principles tally with William Lilly's assessment:

"as there are antiscia, which of the good planets we think are equal to a sextile or trine, so there are contra-antiscions, which we find to be of the nature of a square or opposition".[18]
Within the meeting Joy gave reference to Schoener's table of body part associations, and has provided the PDF of that part of Schoener in case anyone wants to check that out (I believe this is from the Rob Hand translation, that we spoke about in our chat). For more about Schoener, and his nativity - see this Skyscript page which Joy co-authored with Mari Garci: https://www.skyscript.co.uk/schoener_intro.html

PS - I am trying very hard not to think about the horoscope of Augustus, since that will open up a can of worms I can't afford to look into right now, LOL. But the more I think about it, the more I agree with Garrod - Manilius was too close to the event and too insistent that Capricorn was his rising sign for the later charts that show other signs rising to be correct. They usually try to fit with the Capricorn coins by suggesting Capricorn was his Moon sign - but Manilius is clear, Capricorn was the sign on the ascendant (he really leaves no doubt about that).

content_blocks.text: Friday, 17 January 2024starting at -8 pm UTC← click this to see the time for you!Our Zoom link:http://us06web.zoom.us/j/6123333126Meeting password = Skyscript
We pick up the text in Book II, from line 453. This is p.119 of the Loeb Goold translation, although we are following theH.W. Garrod English translation, where this text is onp.29.
content_blocks.html: We pick up the text in Book II, from line 453. This is p.119 of the Loeb Goold translation, although we are following the H.W. Garrod English translation, where this text is on p.29.

content_blocks.text: I have been working through the text before the meeting, so our annotated/illustration edition now goes up to II.535. You can view/download the whole of book II, with the new pages, on this link:https://skyscript.co.uk/pdf/pubs/texts/manilius/Garrod_II/#page=23
content_blocks.html: I have been working through the text before the meeting, so our annotated/illustration edition now goes up to II.535. You can view/download the whole of book II, with the new pages, on this link: https://skyscript.co.uk/pdf/pubs/texts/manilius/Garrod_II/#page=23

content_blocks.text: Or download the new pages only in the attached PDF file.  I recommend you have a copy of those pages handy, as the diagrams help to make sense of the text.(We may read beyond the pages I have annotated in our meeting tonight, in which case we will read directly from Garrod's original text).  I hoped to get more 'ahead', but ... art is long and computer challenges have been many. This particular passage also took me down some cavernous research detours, which helped me make sense of several vague details that have been needling me for years - largely, about the origins of antiscia and how these are presented in Ptolemy's work ...  this isn't the kind of material that can be easily rushed.)
content_blocks.html:

full_content:
Manilius Reading Group - this Friday
Skyscript
15 January
3
1
Reminder: we reconnect this Friday for the next instalment of the Manilius Reading Group. The meeting begins on Friday, 17th January, at 8pm UTC. 
We are picking up the text in Book II, from line 453. This is p.119 of the Loeb Goold translation, although we are following the H.W. Garrod English translation, available on this link: https://www.skyscript.co.uk/pdf/pubs/texts/manilius/garrod/index.html#page=126
Our passage starts “Learn now how the parts of the human body are distributed among the signs …”.
The text goes on to describe relationships between the signs based on parallel associations rather than aspectual configurations (summarised in the attached diagram, which should make sense after our meeting). These create the audentia  -- signs of ‘hearing’; videntia ‘seeing’; amantia ‘loving’ and aversa ‘loathing’. There’s some interesting points about non-reciprocated affections here: as a Taurean married to an Aries, I smile at the thought that the Ram “loves the Bull with a baffled love” while the Bull “weaves guile for the Ram” -- hah, so true :)
I am still working on illustrations and annotations for this passage, and hope to our annotated edition updated and circulated here before the meeting – but I know it will be tight, so I won’t delay any longer in sending out this reminder.
Here’s the essential info again:
Manilius Reading Group (continuing Book II)
Friday, 17 January 2024
starting at - 8 pm UTC ← click this to see the time for you!

Our Zoom link:
http://us06web.zoom.us/j/6123333126
Meeting password = Skyscript
 If anyone wants to review any of the previous sessions, all have been recorded and can be watched on this link, which also has links to various Manilius reading resources. 
https://vimeopro.com/stapresenter/manilius 
To enter - add password: Garrod
 Have a good week and hope to see you Friday!

All members are warmly invited to the December 2024 Skyscript member meeting, a solstice special medley of end-of-year themes, including a ‘round-table’ member discussion on various topical issues.
Deb Houlding will update on Skyscript development, reviewing tasks progressed and plans for the year ahead (member input welcomed for suggestions!).

Hope to see you for a final time in 2024 in what promises to be a lively and stimulating array of lively member-chat!

content_blocks.text: Guardian Deities of the signs

As a follow up to the point discussed last night about the Deities of the signs (II.433-452), I thought it might be interesting to circulate some imagery depicting the association of the 12 months with the Dii Consentes‘Harmonious Gods’ .Charlotte Long’s The Twelve Gods of Greece and Rome(Leiden, 1987) is the best source I've found for exploring this matter in detail, and integrating the details from Manilius (it is based on her PhD thesis). A digital copy is available on the Internet Archive site - you need to log in and 'borrow' to view the full text:https://archive.org/details/twelvegodsofgree0000longAltar of the Twelve Gods (found at Gabii, Italy):This monument has been dated to around the 1st century BCE, but a similar altar at Athens is described in the 5th century BCE text of Herodotus, supposedly borrowing from Egyptian mysticism: "the Egyptians first used the appellations of twelve gods​ (which the Greeks afterwards borrowed from them); and it was they who first assigned to the several gods their altars and images and temples, and first carved figures on stone ..). (II.4)The image on the right is especially useful, as someone has kindly scribbled the order of the gods described by Manilius, which are identified by the details of their insignia.
content_blocks.html:
As a follow up to the point discussed last night about the Deities of the signs (II.433-452), I thought it might be interesting to circulate some imagery depicting the association of the 12 months with the Dii Consentes ‘Harmonious Gods’ .

Charlotte Long’s The Twelve Gods of Greece and Rome (Leiden, 1987) is the best source I've found for exploring this matter in detail, and integrating the details from Manilius (it is based on her PhD thesis). A digital copy is available on the Internet Archive site - you need to log in and 'borrow' to view the full text: https://archive.org/details/twelvegodsofgree0000long



Altar of the Twelve Gods (found at Gabii, Italy):

This monument has been dated to around the 1st century BCE, but a similar altar at Athens is described in the 5th century BCE text of Herodotus, supposedly borrowing from Egyptian mysticism: "the Egyptians first used the appellations of twelve gods​ (which the Greeks afterwards borrowed from them); and it was they who first assigned to the several gods their altars and images and temples, and first carved figures on stone ..). (II.4)

The image on the right is especially useful, as someone has kindly scribbled the order of the gods described by Manilius, which are identified by the details of their insignia.

content_blocks.text: Menologium Rusticum Colotianum - RomeThis is a 1st century marble pillar, thought to act as the base of a sundial. It shows the arrangement of gods described by Manilius, but with a curious displacement which moves the depictions of the zodiac signs and gods one month away from what we might expect. This is explained by the pillar showing the zodiac sign that is prevalent that month, rather than the one that makes the ingress that month, yet retaining the god of the ingressed sign.For example, the month of October is associated with Libra on the pillar, the sign that prevails that month, not September, which is when the Sun enters Libra. However, the associated tutelary god is Mars - which is correct for Scorpio, which the Sun ingresses in October, but not for Libra. So there is a relatable logic that ties the schemes together, but this gives evidence that the priority arrangement is based on these gods being guardians of months of the year, which pick up the zodiac association as a consequence.Image sources:I've created a forum post with full details of sources and extra information - unfortunately, most of you cannot see it yet, because I am still settung up the member's only forum, but you will be able to very soon. I'll get back to working ont his now :)
content_blocks.html:
Menologium Rusticum Colotianum - Rome

This is a 1st century marble pillar, thought to act as the base of a sundial. It shows the arrangement of gods described by Manilius, but with a curious displacement which moves the depictions of the zodiac signs and gods one month away from what we might expect. This is explained by the pillar showing the zodiac sign that is prevalent that month, rather than the one that makes the ingress that month, yet retaining the god of the ingressed sign.
For example, the month of October is associated with Libra on the pillar, the sign that prevails that month, not September, which is when the Sun enters Libra. However, the associated tutelary god is Mars - which is correct for Scorpio, which the Sun ingresses in October, but not for Libra. So there is a relatable logic that ties the schemes together, but this gives evidence that the priority arrangement is based on these gods being guardians of months of the year, which pick up the zodiac association as a consequence.



Image sources:

I've created a forum post with full details of sources and extra information - unfortunately, most of you cannot see it yet, because I am still settung up the member's only forum, but you will be able to very soon. I'll get back to working ont his now :)

Since diary dates in December are getting cramped, the next meeting has been arranged for 8pm UTC Thursday, 9 January 2025 (details are posted in the member's area and a reminder will be sent one week before).

Guardian Deities of the signs
As a follow up to the point discussed last night about the Deities of the signs (II.433-452), I thought it might be interesting to circulate some imagery depicting the association of the 12 months with the Dii Consentes ‘Harmonious Gods’ .

Charlotte Long’s The Twelve Gods of Greece and Rome (Leiden, 1987) is the best source I've found for exploring this matter in detail, and integrating the details from Manilius (it is based on her PhD thesis). A digital copy is available on the Internet Archive site - you need to log in and 'borrow' to view the full text: https://archive.org/details/twelvegodsofgree0000long



Altar of the Twelve Gods (found at Gabii, Italy):

This monument has been dated to around the 1st century BCE, but a similar altar at Athens is described in the 5th century BCE text of Herodotus, supposedly borrowing from Egyptian mysticism: "the Egyptians first used the appellations of twelve gods (which the Greeks afterwards borrowed from them); and it was they who first assigned to the several gods their altars and images and temples, and first carved figures on stone ..). (II.4)

The image on the right is especially useful, as someone has kindly scribbled the order of the gods described by Manilius, which are identified by the details of their insignia.


Menologium Rusticum Colotianum - Rome

This is a 1st century marble pillar, thought to act as the base of a sundial. It shows the arrangement of gods described by Manilius, but with a curious displacement which moves the depictions of the zodiac signs and gods one month away from what we might expect. This is explained by the pillar showing the zodiac sign that is prevalent that month, rather than the one that makes the ingress that month, yet retaining the god of the ingressed sign.
For example, the month of October is associated with Libra on the pillar, the sign that prevails that month, not September, which is when the Sun enters Libra. However, the associated tutelary god is Mars - which is correct for Scorpio, which the Sun ingresses in October, but not for Libra. So there is a relatable logic that ties the schemes together, but this gives evidence that the priority arrangement is based on these gods being guardians of months of the year, which pick up the zodiac association as a consequence.



Image sources:

I've created a forum post with full details of sources and extra information - unfortunately, most of you cannot see it yet, because I am still settung up the member's only forum, but you will be able to very soon. I'll get back to working ont his now :)

14 Nov 2024

We are returning to Manilius today, so join us if you can, at 8pm UTC, for a delightful 75 minutes of exploring turn-of-the-first-millennium astrology.
This session will pick up in Book II, from line 270, at a very interesting passage that lays out the principles of aspectual configurations. There are some real gems in this section, of great value to researchers and anyone concerned with the origins and development of astro-technique.
We are following H.W. Garrod’s English translation, and our own illustrated and annotated edition is embedded in the member’s area or can be found online here. (You can download as a PDF from that link).
Meeting details:
Thursday, 14th November 2024
starting at - 8 pm UTC ← click this to see the time for you!
Duration: 75 mins

Our Zoom link:
http://us06web.zoom.us/j/6123333126
Meeting password = Skyscript
 Everyone is welcome – don’t worry if you haven’t been to any of the earlier sessions, if you are new to our group we will make you very welcome.
The meeting will be recorded for anyone who is unable to attend today but wants to follow along.

(Mireille will be in charge again, but I'll be there and looking forward to this!)
Deb

PS - if you want to read the original version of Garrod's text, the link to this (and lost of other resources is easily found on the recently published Skyscript Manilius page)

This presentation will be recorded for those unable to attend the live event
 We are delighted to have our next member talk delivered by Meira Epstein, whose talk theme will be:

Ibn Ezra & the Jewish Tradition in Astrology
The distinguished 12th-century astrologer-scholar-poet Abraham Ibn Ezra was one of the most influential philosophers of the Middle Ages. His Hebrew text, Beginning of Wisdom is among the most important basic medieval texts of astrology. Ezra's works are philosophical yet practical - and stimulating because he was passionate about astrological principles. Meira will discuss his life and work while outlining the Jewish Tradition in Astrology.

About our speaker:
Meira Epstein lectures and teaches internationally on all aspects of astrology. She is a certified professional astrological consultant and a principal teacher for the NCGR education and certification program. Her early career as a programmer-analyst on Wall Street foreshadowed the multifaceted talents she would employ for systems and symbols in integrating an ancient language into our modern world. Meira is active in the revival of ancient and medieval Hebrew texts and techniques, and has researched Abraham Ibn Ezra's astrological texts since the late 1980's. Her published translations are The Beginning of Wisdom, The Book of Reasons, The Book of Nativities and Revolutions, and The Correspondence between Maimonides and the Rabbis of the South of France about Astrology. In preparation are The Book of Elections and The Book of Interrogations.

Visit Meira's website at www.bear-star.com.

Of interest on Skyscript:
Outline Introduction to Ibn Ezra - by Mari Garcia & Joy Usher
The Life & Work of Ibn Ezra - by David McCann
Book Review: The Book of Nativities and Revolutions by Ibn Ezra - translated by Meira B. Epstein - by Deborah Houlding

NEXT MEMBER TALK: Meira Epstein - 10 November 2024 (6 pm UTC)
Delighted to have our next member talk delivered by Meira Epstein, whose talk theme will be:

Ibn Ezra & the Jewish Tradition in Astrology
The distinguished 12th-century astrologer-scholar-poet Abraham Ibn Ezra was one of the most influential philosophers of the Middle Ages. His Hebrew text, Beginning of Wisdom is among the most important basic medieval texts of astrology. Ezra's works are philosophical yet practical - and stimulating because he was passionate about astrological principles. Meira will discuss his life and work while outlining the Jewish Tradition in Astrology.

About our speaker:
Meira Epstein lectures and teaches internationally on all aspects of astrology. She is a certified professional astrological consultant and a principal teacher for the NCGR education and certification program. Her early career as a programmer-analyst on Wall Street foreshadowed the multifaceted talents she would employ for systems and symbols in integrating an ancient language into our modern world. Meira is active in the revival of ancient and medieval Hebrew texts and techniques, and has researched Abraham Ibn Ezra's astrological texts since the late 1980's. Her published translations are The Beginning of Wisdom, The Book of Reasons, The Book of Nativities and Revolutions, and The Correspondence between Maimonides and the Rabbis of the South of France about Astrology. In preparation are The Book of Elections and The Book of Interrogations.

Visit Meira's website at www.bear-star.com.

Of related interest to this topic on Skyscript:
Outline Introduction to Ibn Ezra - by Mari Garcia & Joy Usher
The Life & Work of Ibn Ezra - by David McCann
Book Review: The Book of Nativities and Revolutions by Ibn Ezra - translated by Meira B. Epstein - by Deborah Houlding

Mireille's Manilius talk is now on YouTube, supported by the new Manilius Page on Skyscript
I am very proud of Skyscript’s feature-rich new page about Manilius and his Astronomica, a topic crying out for better representation on the web. Take a look at this, to check out the resources it offers

https://www.skyscript.co.uk/manilius.html

The Astronomica is an incredibly important astrology source text, as the oldest instructional manual on astrology we have. It is often overlooked that this work is one of pure artistry, too! The page draws attention to what this book offers and the long line of scholars involved in the text’s restoration and translation into English.
The page includes Mireille Crossley’s article ‘Who was Marcus Manilius – astrologer, astronomer, poet … slave ?’ a fascinating exploration first published in the Skyscript Newsletter last year.
The presentation that Mireille gave about this topic at this year’s AA conference is also now available on YouTube and embedded as a resource within this page.  More resources will continue to be added to the Manilius page as they become available, including a more user-friendly version of the Creech poetic translation which is currently being put together by Mireille.

And finally ... many congrats and best wishes to Mireille, who has today - after many months of organisation - taken possession of her new flat in Edinburgh.

content_blocks.text: Date:Thursday, 24 October 2024Start: 7pm UTC– New York: 3 pm | London: 8 pm | Sydney 6 am[check all local timeson this link]|duration≈75minsSkyscript Zoom link:http://us06web.zoom.us/j/6123333126Zoom password: Skyscript

I am delighted that this meeting is going to be hosted byWade CavesandRod Chang, who will be looking at current themes with a focus on the spectacular comet (A3) currently putting on a stunning display shortly after sunset (look to the west – it trails the Sun). It has been termed the comet of the century because of its length and brightness – it is a “mountain-size” comet with a 30 km tail. More realistically, it is not the comet of the century, but it has already been recorded as the brightest comet in 27 years sinceHale-Bopp in 1997. It has a huge orbit, meaning it will not return to the sight of the Earth again for 80,000 years.(Some of you will remember me mentioning this October comet much earlier in the year with concerns about its connections with the natal chart of King Charles III in his solar return. Since comets are historically linked to crisis periods for leaders, I wondered whether this might bring him back into the news with renewed concerns about his health. I see today he is getting global attention for having a hard time visiting Australia, the message being “You are not my king!" which might prove to be the start of a hard passage to come for the House of Windsor).

A reminder that we’ll be holding our next Mundane Matters meeting this Thursday.
 Date: Thursday, 24 October 2024
Start: 7 pm UTC – New York: 3 pm | London: 8 pm | Sydney 6 am
[check all local times on this link] |
duration ≈ 75 mins
Skyscript Zoom link: http://us06web.zoom.us/j/6123333126
Zoom password: Skyscript 
I am delighted that this meeting is going to be hosted by Wade Caves and Rod Chang, who will be looking at current themes with a focus on the spectacular comet (A3) currently putting on a stunning display shortly after sunset (look to the west – it trails the Sun). It has been termed the comet of the century because of its length and brightness – it is a “mountain-size” comet with a 30 km tail. More realistically, it is not the comet of the century, but it has already been recorded as the brightest comet in 27 years since Hale-Bopp in 1997. It has a huge orbit, meaning it will not return to the sight of the Earth again for 80,000 years. 

(Some of you will remember me mentioning this October comet much earlier in the year with concerns about its connections with the natal chart of King Charles III in his solar return. Since comets are historically linked to crisis periods for leaders, I wondered whether this might bring him back into the news with renewed concerns about his health. I see today he is getting global attention for having a hard time visiting Australia, the message being “You are not my king!" which might prove to be the start of a hard passage to come for the House of Windsor). 
Rod and Wade will present other interesting thoughts on this comet, using charts that are topical or in the news.

BTW, unlike previous Mundane Matters meetings, and partly because I am currently under the weather myself – this meeting will be recorded. (I regret that the talk about Hamas and Hezbollah wasn’t recorded – events since have proven how reliable those Mars-laden charts were, I believe that all of those leaders we looked at in that session as likely to be eliminated with targetted attacks have now been assassinated, leaving that area tragically drastic and volatile).

content_blocks.text: Restoring the Masculine Benefic - Bernard EcclesDate of Meeting:Thursday, 10th October 2024Start time:7 pm UTC(check all local times on this link)Duration: ≈ 75-90 mins

Restoring the Masculine BeneficAstrology has enjoyed a remarkable resurgence of popularity lately, fuelled by many things: New Age philosophy, new paganism, and feminist politics, to name a few. Yet somewhere, a balance has been lost: Mars, Jupiter, and even the Sun are being seen as malefic, and new asteroids are usually named goddesses rather than masculine deities. To redress this issue and restore astrology's original state, it is time to rediscover the masculine benefic. This talk is sure to generate lively discussion!
content_blocks.html:
Restoring the Masculine Benefic
Astrology has enjoyed a remarkable resurgence of popularity lately, fuelled by many things: New Age philosophy, new paganism, and feminist politics, to name a few. Yet somewhere, a balance has been lost: Mars, Jupiter, and even the Sun are being seen as malefic, and new asteroids are usually named goddesses rather than masculine deities. To redress this issue and restore astrology's original state, it is time to rediscover the masculine benefic. This talk is sure to generate lively discussion!

content_blocks.text: About our speaker:
content_blocks.html: About our speaker:

content_blocks.text: Bernard Eccleshas been teaching and lecturing in astrology for over forty years. A prominent member of the Astrological Lodge of London since 1978, he was its President twice between 1988 and 1995. He taught 'Techniques of Prediction' courses at the Marylebone-Paddington Institute and short courses for the Lodge and at the Faculty of Astrological Studies Summer Schools. In the early 2000s he was closely involved in the Sophia Project and the MA in Cultural Astronomy and Astrology (then at Bath Spa University College; now at the University of Wales, Lampeter). In his commercial guise, he writes sunsign columns for magazines worldwide, and his books have sold over half a million copies.

A final reminder of our talk today by Bernard Eccles:
Meeting details: 
Restoring the Masculine Benefic - Bernard Eccles
Date of Meeting: Thursday, 10th October 2024
Start time: 7 pm UTC ( check all local times on this link)
Duration: ≈ 75-90 mins

Restoring the Masculine Benefic
Astrology has enjoyed a remarkable resurgence of popularity lately, fuelled by many things: New Age philosophy, new paganism, and feminist politics, to name a few. Yet somewhere, a balance has been lost: Mars, Jupiter, and even the Sun are being seen as malefic, and new asteroids are usually named goddesses rather than masculine deities. To redress this issue and restore astrology's original state, it is time to rediscover the masculine benefic. This talk is sure to generate lively discussion!

About our speaker:
Bernard Eccles has been teaching and lecturing in astrology for over forty years. A prominent member of the Astrological Lodge of London since 1978, he was its President twice between 1988 and 1995. He taught 'Techniques of Prediction' courses at the Marylebone-Paddington Institute and short courses for the Lodge and at the Faculty of Astrological Studies Summer Schools. In the early 2000s he was closely involved in the Sophia Project and the MA in Cultural Astronomy and Astrology (then at Bath Spa University College; now at the University of Wales, Lampeter). In his commercial guise, he writes sunsign columns for magazines worldwide, and his books have sold over half a million copies.

A reminder of our talk this Thursday by Bernard Eccles : Meeting details:  Restoring the Masculine Benefic - Bernard Eccles Date of Meeting: Thursday, 10th October 2024 Start time: 7 pm UTC  (   check all local times on this link ) Duration: ≈ 75-90 mins Restoring the Masculine Benefic Astrology has enjoyed a remarkable resurgence of popularity lately, fuelled by many things: New Age philosophy, new paganism, and feminist politics, to name a few. Yet somewhere, a balance has been lost: Mars, Jupiter, and even the Sun are being seen as malefic, and new asteroids are usually named goddesses rather than masculine deities. To redress this issue and restore astrology's original state, it is time to rediscover the masculine benefic. This talk is sure to generate lively discussion! About our speaker: Bernard Eccles  has been teaching and lecturing in astrology for over forty years. A prominent member of the Astrological Lodge of London since 1978, he was its President twice between 1988 and 1995. He taught 'Techniques of Prediction' courses at the Marylebone-Paddington Institute and short courses for the Lodge and at the Faculty of Astrological Studies Summer Schools. In the early 2000s he was closely involved in the Sophia Project and the MA in Cultural Astronomy and Astrology (then at Bath Spa University College; now at the University of Wales, Lampeter). In his commercial guise, he writes sunsign columns for magazines worldwide, and his books have sold over half a million copies. A reminder of our talk this Thursday by Bernard Eccles:
Meeting details: 
Restoring the Masculine Benefic - Bernard Eccles
Date of Meeting: Thursday, 10th October 2024
Start time: 7 pm UTC ( check all local times on this link)
Duration: ≈ 75-90 mins
Restoring the Masculine Benefic
Astrology has enjoyed a remarkable resurgence of popularity lately, fuelled by many things: New Age philosophy, new paganism, and feminist politics, to name a few. Yet somewhere, a balance has been lost: Mars, Jupiter, and even the Sun are being seen as malefic, and new asteroids are usually named goddesses rather than masculine deities. To redress this issue and restore astrology's original state, it is time to rediscover the masculine benefic. This talk is sure to generate lively discussion!

About our speaker:
Bernard Eccles has been teaching and lecturing in astrology for over forty years. A prominent member of the Astrological Lodge of London since 1978, he was its President twice between 1988 and 1995. He taught 'Techniques of Prediction' courses at the Marylebone-Paddington Institute and short courses for the Lodge and at the Faculty of Astrological Studies Summer Schools. In the early 2000s he was closely involved in the Sophia Project and the MA in Cultural Astronomy and Astrology (then at Bath Spa University College; now at the University of Wales, Lampeter). In his commercial guise, he writes sunsign columns for magazines worldwide, and his books have sold over half a million copies.

content_blocks.text: Mireille -  I held the fort, and we had a lovely meeting, but of course, you were missed! I was onlyslightlyrude about you in your absence – you will have to watch the recording to find that bit :)
content_blocks.html: Mireille -  I held the fort, and we had a lovely meeting, but of course, you were missed! I was only slightly rude about you in your absence – you will have to watch the recording to find that bit :)

content_blocks.text: I do enjoy these  Manilius meetings – so satisfying to spend a little leisure time with the finer details of 1st-century astrology, with artistry attached. Last night’s meeting was very valuable to me, with some great observations made on points I had missed. The final part of the discussion about why the Archer is a ‘maimed’ sign was especially useful. I have now revised the document where that point was annotated to reference the nebulous cluster of stars in the forehead of the Archer, which, of course, is historically associated with blindness.

 Mireille -  I held the fort, and we had a lovely meeting, but of course, you were missed! I was only slightly rude about you in your absence – you will have to watch the recording to find that bit :)
I do enjoy these  Manilius meetings – so satisfying to spend a little leisure time with the finer details of 1st-century astrology, with artistry attached. Last night’s meeting was very valuable to me, with some great observations made on points I had missed. The final part of the discussion about why the Archer is a ‘maimed’ sign was especially useful. I have now revised the document where that point was annotated to reference the nebulous cluster of stars in the forehead of the Archer, which, of course, is historically associated with blindness.
I've set the next meeting for 14 November at 8:00 PM GMT. The details are in the members’ area, and I’ve arranged for a reminder post to circulate one week beforehand.
 
Next week: Bernard Eccles stirs up gender issues
Be sure to make a note of our member talk which will be given next Thursday by Bernard Eccles:
Restoring the Masculine Benefic
Astrology has enjoyed a remarkable resurgence of popularity lately, fuelled by many things: New Age philosophy, new paganism, and feminist politics, to name a few. Yet somewhere, a balance has been lost: Mars, Jupiter, and even the Sun are being seen as malefic, and new asteroids are usually named goddesses rather than masculine deities. To redress this issue and restore astrology's original state, it is time to rediscover the masculine benefic. This talk is sure to generate lively discussion!

About our speaker:
Bernard Eccles has been teaching and lecturing in astrology for over forty years. A prominent member of the Astrological Lodge of London since 1978, he was its President twice between 1988 and 1995. He taught 'Techniques of Prediction' courses at the Marylebone-Paddington Institute and short courses for the Lodge and at the Faculty of Astrological Studies Summer Schools. In the early 2000s he was closely involved in the Sophia Project and the MA in Cultural Astronomy and Astrology (then at Bath Spa University College; now at the University of Wales, Lampeter). In his commercial guise, he writes sunsign columns for magazines worldwide, and his books have sold over half a million copies.

Of interest on site:
An interview with Bernard Eccles - by Garry Phillipson
Astrological Physiognomy: From Ptolemy to the Present Day - by Bernard Eccles
(I recommend you read Bernard's interview - it is full of insight from an astrologer who has explored all avenues of professional practice, from commercial sun signs to highbrow academic papers. With his decades of experience, Bernard has a lot to say that is worth listening to and thinking about).

content_blocks.text: A final reminder that we are resuming theManilius Reading Grouptoday. We are picking up from Book II, line 150, just at the point where we finally get to explore the details of astrological techniques.
content_blocks.html: A final reminder that we are resuming the Manilius Reading Group today. We are picking up from Book II, line 150, just at the point where we finally get to explore the details of astrological techniques.

content_blocks.text: Manilius Reading Group 11 – continuing Book II 150ff.Date of Meeting:Thursday, 3rd October 2024Start time:8:30 pm UTC(check all local times on this link)Duration: ≈ 75 mins

A final reminder that we are resuming the Manilius Reading Group today. We are picking up from Book II, line 150, just at the point where we finally get to explore the details of astrological techniques. 
Here are the details: 
Manilius Reading Group 11 – continuing Book II 150ff.
Date of Meeting: Thursday, 3rd October 2024
Start time: 8:30 pm UTC ( check all local times on this link)
Duration: ≈ 75 mins
We are working from the English translation of H.W. Garrod, which has been illustrated and annotated in preparation for our meeting.   
You can download it or read it online (from the point we are starting at) in a flipbook format here:
https://skyscript.co.uk/pdf/pubs/texts/manilius/Garrod_II/#page=11
 If you are curious and have never attended our Reading Group before, pop along ... this is a very friendly group and you will be made very welcome.

I will be recording the meetings for those unable to attend at this time.
Deb

Argh, I know I don’t have any right to complain after reading about all the horrible and devastating international floods … but I am so fed up with the the rain!!  The last couple of weeks have been everything September’s eclipsed lunation conjunct Neptune on Scheat promised, haven't they?  The weather in the UK is generally mild and temperate, but even here, we have been having record levels of rainfall and many problems caused by floods.
(I am fine, myself, BTW; just being a typical Brit and moaning about the dismal weather.)

But … one bright light in this week is that we will be resuming the Manilius Reading Group this Thursday!  We are picking up from Book II.150, just at the point where we finally get to explore the details of astrological technique.

content_blocks.html: 23 Sept 2024

content_blocks.text: Thank you to everyone who attended my presentation yesterday, on how historical astrologers defined natural and judicial astrology and the approach they took to issues of fate and freewill.  The points I hoped to demonstrate with this talk are that, historically, astrology was not (as critics would have it) ridiculed as a topic or considered contrary to faith, nor was it an essentially fatalistic study, purely concerned with prediction.I haven’t been able to link the recording into the member’s area yet – I will do that in the morning - but if anyone wants to catch the recording, it is attached to this post and already showing in the member-area showreel.
content_blocks.html:
Thank you to everyone who attended my presentation yesterday, on how historical astrologers defined natural and judicial astrology and the approach they took to issues of fate and freewill.  The points I hoped to demonstrate with this talk are that, historically, astrology was not (as critics would have it) ridiculed as a topic or considered contrary to faith, nor was it an essentially fatalistic study, purely concerned with prediction.
I haven’t been able to link the recording into the member’s area yet – I will do that in the morning - but if anyone wants to catch the recording, it is attached to this post and already showing in the member-area showreel.

content_blocks.text: The lecture part of the presentation lasts just over an hour, followed by about 40 mins of stimulating follow-up member discussion :)

content_blocks.text: A final reminder that I’ll be offering the next member-presentation tomorrow. Details as follows:
content_blocks.html: A final reminder that I’ll be offering the next member-presentation tomorrow. Details as follows:

content_blocks.text: Date:Saturday, 21 September 2024Start:1:30 pm UTC– New York: 9:30 am | London: 2:30 pm | Sydney 11:30 pm[check all local timeson this link]|duration≈75minsSkyscript Zoom link:http://us06web.zoom.us/j/6123333126Zoom password: SkyscriptBlurb:Providence, Prophecy, & the Divinational Role of Judicial AstrologyAstrology has played a role in all world cultures, and for most of its history, a fine line has preserved the legally accepted and theologically approved practice of ‘natural astrology’ from the harsh consequences attached to the practice of ‘judicial astrology’ when it "transgresses its limits" and blasphemously claims to know the Will of God. This presentation explores what astrologers said about the philosophical issues at stake and the stance they have taken towards the thorny issue of fate and free will in traditional predictive practice.
I hope you can join me.  The talk will be recorded for those of you who cannot connect at this time.

[check all local times on this link] |
duration ≈ 75 mins

Blurb:
Providence, Prophecy, & the Divinational Role of Judicial Astrology
 Astrology has played a role in all world cultures, and for most of its history, a fine line has preserved the legally accepted and theologically approved practice of ‘natural astrology’ from the harsh consequences attached to the practice of ‘judicial astrology’ when it "transgresses its limits" and blasphemously claims to know the Will of God. This presentation explores what astrologers said about the philosophical issues at stake and the stance they have taken towards the thorny issue of fate and free will in traditional predictive practice.
 I hope you can join me.  The talk will be recorded for those of you who cannot connect at this time.

content_blocks.text: Mireille Crossley presents on Manilius

Mireille Crossly gave members a presentation about Manilius in June 2023 as a kick-off to our Manilius Reading Group.  She has since polished up her research points and recently gave a wonderful one-hour presentation on the life and work of Manilius at the AA 2024 conference.  That presentation recording is shared here for anyone who did not get access to it as an AA delegate.  (It is also linked to the member's area). Thank you, Mireille!
content_blocks.html: Mireille Crossly gave members a presentation about Manilius in June 2023 as a kick-off to our Manilius Reading Group.  She has since polished up her research points and recently gave a wonderful one-hour presentation on the life and work of Manilius at the AA 2024 conference.  That presentation recording is shared here for anyone who did not get access to it as an AA delegate.  (It is also linked to the member's area). Thank you, Mireille!

content_blocks.text: Our next member-presentation: this Saturday
A reminder that I’ll be offering the next member-presentation this upcoming Saturday. Here are the details to note:
content_blocks.html: A reminder that I’ll be offering the next member-presentation this upcoming Saturday. Here are the details to note:

content_blocks.text: Date:Saturday, 21 September 2024Start:1:30 pm UTC– New York: 9:30 am | London: 2:30 pm | Sydney 11:30 pm[check all local timeson this link]|duration≈75minsSkyscript Zoom link:http://us06web.zoom.us/j/6123333126Zoom password: SkyscriptBlurb:Providence, Prophecy, & the Divinational Role of Judicial AstrologyAstrology has played a role in all world cultures, and for most of its history, a fine line has preserved the legally accepted and theologically approved practice of ‘natural astrology’ from the harsh consequences attached to the practice of ‘judicial astrology’ when it "transgresses its limits" and blasphemously claims to know the Will of God. This presentation explores what astrologers said about the philosophical issues at stake and the stance they have taken towards the thorny issue of fate and free will in traditional predictive practice.
I hope you can join me.  The talk will be recorded for those unable to attend at that time.
content_blocks.html: I hope you can join me.  The talk will be recorded for those unable to attend at that time.

content_blocks.text: An Interview with Geoffrey Cornelius, by Garry Phillipson

My thoughts are with Maggie Hyde and all the friends and colleagues of Geoffrey Cornelius, whose funeral was held today.  On Monday this week, I was contacted by Garry Phillipson, whose interview with Geoffrey is no longer showing on his own site due to a problem with Goole sites.  He asked if I could host it on Skyscript, and of course, I was happy to oblige.  It is now available on the link below.  This is a vital interview that raises issues every astrologer needs to think about – it is especially relevant for horary astrologers, but, really, every practising astrologer needs to contemplate the points that Geoffrey has raised.  The astrological community has certainly been enriched by his views and by how he brought a rich philosophical contribution to our craft.

content_blocks.text: Deadly devices triggered under a Saturn-Mercury opposition eclipse

Our recent Mundane Matters meeting focussed on the charts for Lebanon and Hezbollah, which gave clear indications of immediate and then sustained escalation of attack (making it inevitable Lebanon would become a focus of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict).  The region has become critical now after two days of exploding devices (first pagers on Tuesday, then walkie-talkies yesterday), injuring thousands and killing more than 37  people, including several children and (obviously) many innocent civilians.
content_blocks.html: Our recent Mundane Matters meeting focussed on the charts for Lebanon and Hezbollah, which gave clear indications of immediate and then sustained escalation of attack (making it inevitable Lebanon would become a focus of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict). The region has become critical now after two days of exploding devices (first pagers on Tuesday, then walkie-talkies yesterday), injuring thousands and killing more than 37  people, including several children and (obviously) many innocent civilians.

content_blocks.text: The first ‘pager’ attack occurred around 3:30 pm local Beirut time on Tuesday. The astrology of that attack is striking for drawing out the lunation themes of the eclipse, which followed 12 hours later. At 3:30 pm EEDT, the Moon, at 16.47 Pisces, brought full attention to Saturn’s retrograde opposition to Mercury in Virgo, as it squared the degree of the Sun in the Hezbollah foundation chart (17 Gemini). It is hard to imagine a more literal symbol for deathly communication devices than that.
content_blocks.html: The first ‘pager’ attack occurred around 3:30 pm local Beirut time on Tuesday. The astrology of that attack is striking for drawing out the lunation themes of the eclipse, which followed 12 hours later. At 3:30 pm EEDT, the Moon, at 16.47 Pisces, brought full attention to Saturn’s retrograde opposition to Mercury in Virgo, as it squared the degree of the Sun in the Hezbollah foundation chart (17 Gemini). It is hard to imagine a more literal symbol for deathly communication devices than that.

content_blocks.text: At the same time, Mars, at 7 Cancer, opposed the Hezbollah foundation chart Moon at 6° Capricorn.  Also note how that Saturn-Mercury opposition lands on the Moon in the Lebanon formal independence chart, which has Mars opposing its Sun.
content_blocks.html: At the same time, Mars, at 7 Cancer, opposed the Hezbollah foundation chart Moon at 6° Capricorn.  Also note how that Saturn-Mercury opposition lands on the Moon in the Lebanon formal independence chart, which has Mars opposing its Sun.

content_blocks.text: Mars is at the bendings right now, as it squares the nodal axis (7° Ar-Li), which is falling across Mars in the Hezbollah foundation chart (trine to Mercury in Gemini), in the same degree as Neptune in the Lebanon chart.  Nodal alignments with Mars highlight crucial times for battles, and these are all very worrying ‘trigger point’ indications of conflicts that move to a new phase.  We are between eclipses now - the upcoming solar eclipse of 2nd October is also dominated by a square to Mars (trine Saturn). Sadly, the outlook looks bleak and set to get only worse for Lebanon, the region as a whole, and for the prospect of peace in the Near East happening anytime soon.

 Mireille Crossley presents on Manilius
 Mireille Crossly gave members a presentation about Manilius in June 2023 as a kick-off to our Manilius Reading Group.  She has since polished up her research points and recently gave a wonderful one-hour presentation on the life and work of Manilius at the AA 2024 conference.  That presentation recording is shared here for anyone who did not get access to it as an AA delegate.  (It is also linked to the member's area). Thank you, Mireille!

Blurb:
Providence, Prophecy, & the Divinational Role of Judicial Astrology
 Astrology has played a role in all world cultures, and for most of its history, a fine line has preserved the legally accepted and theologically approved practice of ‘natural astrology’ from the harsh consequences attached to the practice of ‘judicial astrology’ when it "transgresses its limits" and blasphemously claims to know the Will of God. This presentation explores what astrologers said about the philosophical issues at stake and the stance they have taken towards the thorny issue of fate and free will in traditional predictive practice.
 I hope you can join me.  The talk will be recorded for those unable to attend at that time.
An Interview with Geoffrey Cornelius, by Garry Phillipson
 My thoughts are with Maggie Hyde and all the friends and colleagues of Geoffrey Cornelius, whose funeral was held today.  On Monday this week, I was contacted by Garry Phillipson, whose interview with Geoffrey is no longer showing on his own site due to a problem with Goole sites.  He asked if I could host it on Skyscript, and of course, I was happy to oblige.  It is now available on the link below.  This is a vital interview that raises issues every astrologer needs to think about – it is especially relevant for horary astrologers, but, really, every practising astrologer needs to contemplate the points that Geoffrey has raised.  The astrological community has certainly been enriched by his views and by how he brought a rich philosophical contribution to our craft.
 https://www.skyscript.co.uk/cornelius.html
 Deadly devices triggered under a Saturn-Mercury opposition eclipse
 Our recent Mundane Matters meeting focussed on the charts for Lebanon and Hezbollah, which gave clear indications of immediate and then sustained escalation of attack (making it inevitable Lebanon would become a focus of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict). The region has become critical now after two days of exploding devices (first pagers on Tuesday, then walkie-talkies yesterday), injuring thousands and killing more than 37  people, including several children and (obviously) many innocent civilians.
The first ‘pager’ attack occurred around 3:30 pm local Beirut time on Tuesday. The astrology of that attack is striking for drawing out the lunation themes of the eclipse, which followed 12 hours later. At 3:30 pm EEDT, the Moon, at 16.47 Pisces, brought full attention to Saturn’s retrograde opposition to Mercury in Virgo, as it squared the degree of the Sun in the Hezbollah foundation chart (17 Gemini). It is hard to imagine a more literal symbol for deathly communication devices than that.
At the same time, Mars, at 7 Cancer, opposed the Hezbollah foundation chart Moon at 6° Capricorn.  Also note how that Saturn-Mercury opposition lands on the Moon in the Lebanon formal independence chart, which has Mars opposing its Sun. 
Mars is at the bendings right now, as it squares the nodal axis (7° Ar-Li), which is falling across Mars in the Hezbollah foundation chart (trine to Mercury in Gemini), in the same degree as Neptune in the Lebanon chart.  Nodal alignments with Mars highlight crucial times for battles, and these are all very worrying ‘trigger point’ indications of conflicts that move to a new phase.  We are between eclipses now - the upcoming solar eclipse of 2nd October is also dominated by a square to Mars (trine Saturn). Sadly, the outlook looks bleak and set to get only worse for Lebanon, the region as a whole, and for the prospect of peace in the Near East happening anytime soon.
I have no words (only observations), so I'll end with a quote from someone wiser than I:
“We must accept finite disappointment, but we must never lose infinite hope” – Martin Luther King, Jr.

Stay well
Deb

13 Sept 2024
content_blocks.html: 13 Sept 2024

content_blocks.text: Huge thanks to Sheila and Michele for leading us through last night’s informative demonstration and lively discussion of US election issues.
content_blocks.html: Huge thanks to Sheila and Michele for leading us through last night’s informative demonstration and lively discussion of US election issues.

content_blocks.text: The recording is attached to this post and linked into the member’s area.
content_blocks.html: The recording is attached to this post and linked into the member’s area.

content_blocks.text: I am disappointed not to be able to show a screenshot of the poll we ran in the meeting.  I thought it would be captured in the recording, but that didn’t happen, because when I was looking at the poll it wasn’tmyscreen that was being shared (duh! - I’ll know for next time).The poll asked attendees to choose – based only on astrological reasoning – whether Harris or Trump is more likely to win the election.  73% judged Kamala Harris is more likely to win.  However, last night’s meeting made it abundantly clear that the astrological signatures of this election are very dramatic and volatile. So we ended up deciding it is all still a ‘cliff-hanger’ (and being happy that these folks are not our own clients).
content_blocks.html:
I am disappointed not to be able to show a screenshot of the poll we ran in the meeting.  I thought it would be captured in the recording, but that didn’t happen, because when I was looking at the poll it wasn’t my screen that was being shared (duh! - I’ll know for next time).
The poll asked attendees to choose – based only on astrological reasoning – whether Harris or Trump is more likely to win the election.  73% judged Kamala Harris is more likely to win.  However, last night’s meeting made it abundantly clear that the astrological signatures of this election are very dramatic and volatile. So we ended up deciding it is all still a ‘cliff-hanger’ (and being happy that these folks are not our own clients).

content_blocks.text: I have attached some follow-up assets to this post
content_blocks.html: I have attached some follow-up assets to this post

items: This is a link to Karl Skellenger’s ‘Anteros Astrology’ blog post on how the introduction of televised debate shifted the dynamics of US elections. It's very interesting commentary that relates to some of the points Sheila was making about the contest between Nixon and Kennedy. (There’s a lot more top-notch astrology and US-election-themed narrative on Karl’s substack site, so be sure to check it out and subscribe.)https://karlskellenger.substack.com/p/astrological-precedents-in-presidential

I’ve included a screenshot below of the slide where Michele presented her main testimonies for winners or losers when considering the candidate’s solar returns.  Although this is in the recording, it’s handy to have a copy to hand as her examples are worked through, as she illustrated how these rules play out.

I’ve attached a pdf related to Michele’s 1892 example of Harrison v Cleveland (around 1 hr 45 mins in the video). I mentioned being aware of a horary, cast in October 1892, where the astrologer correctly predicted a win for Cleveland – it was published by Alan Leo in 1909 and I commented on it in a Mountain Astrologer article in 2012:

content_blocks.text: “Harrison’s campaign was blighted by in-fighting, many of his party preferring James Blaine as their candidate. He also failed to campaign in the run-up to the election, nursing his sick wife instead, who died of pneumonia on October 25, two weeks before the election… the Moon (an important co-significator in any horary) gives an immediate reflection of his situation. The Moon (wife) in the 8th house, along with the debilitated 7th-house ruler (wife) being Venus in the 10th, shows how, for him, his political downfall was overshadowed by the death of his wife. He took up a private life after this event.

That’s why I felt it was ‘cheating’ for me to comment on that example.  I could immediately recognise Harrison from the two solar return charts presented, because – just as it was in the horary – the Moon was in the 8th house with Venus on the 8th house cusp.  That solar return had such a clear resonance with how his life played out that year, with the same features as in the horary cast at the time, that it seemedtoo easyto identify him. In fact, I had never seen his natal chart before, let alone his solar return chart that year, so this was not me cheating (LOL!) just an example of why Michelle’s use of solar returns is another reliable and self-validating approach to this kind of analysis.
content_blocks.html: That’s why I felt it was ‘cheating’ for me to comment on that example.  I could immediately recognise Harrison from the two solar return charts presented, because – just as it was in the horary – the Moon was in the 8th house with Venus on the 8th house cusp.  That solar return had such a clear resonance with how his life played out that year, with the same features as in the horary cast at the time, that it seemed too easy to identify him. In fact, I had never seen his natal chart before, let alone his solar return chart that year, so this was not me cheating (LOL!) just an example of why Michelle’s use of solar returns is another reliable and self-validating approach to this kind of analysis.

content_blocks.text: Thanks Sheila, Michelle, and to everyone who joined in with lively discussion.
content_blocks.html: Thanks Sheila, Michelle, and to everyone who joined in with lively discussion.

content_blocks.text: Our next presentation will be delivered by me on Saturday 21st September, and I look forward to catching up with some of you again there.

content_blocks.text: Thanks to Michelle, Sheila & Deb for a fascinating talk. I found it all very interesting and useful. I particularly liked Deb's comments in the middle, about the importance of the chart who best "carries" the emerging collective energy.. I think this is always very interesting, as politics in itself is such an impersonal theatre. I was also intrigued by Michelle's comments about Kennedy at the end... I have found it interesting how he has come to prominence as the Uranus- Pluto conjunction of the 60's is moving towards  a waxing trine. Good stuff!

I’ve attached a pdf related to Michele’s 1892 example of Harrison v Cleveland (around 1 hr 45 mins in the video). I mentioned being aware of a horary, cast in October 1892, where the astrologer correctly predicted a win for Cleveland – it was published by Alan Leo in 1909 and I commented on it in a Mountain Astrologer article in 2012:
 “Harrison’s campaign was blighted by in-fighting, many of his party preferring James Blaine as their candidate. He also failed to campaign in the run-up to the election, nursing his sick wife instead, who died of pneumonia on October 25, two weeks before the election… the Moon (an important co-significator in any horary) gives an immediate reflection of his situation. The Moon (wife) in the 8th house, along with the debilitated 7th-house ruler (wife) being Venus in the 10th, shows how, for him, his political downfall was overshadowed by the death of his wife. He took up a private life after this event.
That’s why I felt it was ‘cheating’ for me to comment on that example.  I could immediately recognise Harrison from the two solar return charts presented, because – just as it was in the horary – the Moon was in the 8th house with Venus on the 8th house cusp.  That solar return had such a clear resonance with how his life played out that year, with the same features as in the horary cast at the time, that it seemed too easy to identify him. In fact, I had never seen his natal chart before, let alone his solar return chart that year, so this was not me cheating (LOL!) just an example of why Michelle’s use of solar returns is another reliable and self-validating approach to this kind of analysis.
----------------------------- 
Thanks Sheila, Michelle, and to everyone who joined in with lively discussion.
Our next presentation will be delivered by me on Saturday 21st September, and I look forward to catching up with some of you again there.
  Attachments
Download all

title: Re: your Skyscript subscription

content_blocks.text: Re: your Skyscript subscription
Skyscript

content_blocks.html: 28 Aug 2024

content_blocks.text: As many of you already know, one of my main priorities this year is to move the Skyscript membership scheme away from Patreon. This will provide a more integrated and streamlined experience, as all membership functions will be housed fully on the Skyscript site. You will have an individual login that works across the whole site. Instead of messages and updates being placed here on Patreon, there will be a dedicated area in the Skyscript forum that is only visible to members.  We will have improved facilities to provide news and notices and to continue focused discussion as a follow-up to Skyscript talks and events. You will also have more control over what you receive or choose not to receive and a better ability to share charts, graphics, assets and discussions with each other.This migration will provide many long-term benefits — for you as a member and for the development of future Skyscript content and assets so that, next year, I can be more focused on arranging a legacy plan for the site. I am still awaiting technical information on how this will be managed on the server side. I have been informed today that everything is going well. We are in the beta-testing stage now, and the final ‘go-ahead’ to proceed with the plan should come through this weekend. Since I will be away at the AA conference for the next few days, I will give you a loose overview now of how this plan is expected to work.
content_blocks.html:
As many of you already know, one of my main priorities this year is to move the Skyscript membership scheme away from Patreon. This will provide a more integrated and streamlined experience, as all membership functions will be housed fully on the Skyscript site. You will have an individual login that works across the whole site. Instead of messages and updates being placed here on Patreon, there will be a dedicated area in the Skyscript forum that is only visible to members.  We will have improved facilities to provide news and notices and to continue focused discussion as a follow-up to Skyscript talks and events. You will also have more control over what you receive or choose not to receive and a better ability to share charts, graphics, assets and discussions with each other.

This migration will provide many long-term benefits — for you as a member and for the development of future Skyscript content and assets so that, next year, I can be more focused on arranging a legacy plan for the site. I am still awaiting technical information on how this will be managed on the server side. I have been informed today that everything is going well. We are in the beta-testing stage now, and the final ‘go-ahead’ to proceed with the plan should come through this weekend. Since I will be away at the AA conference for the next few days, I will give you a loose overview now of how this plan is expected to work.
