title: A little something for the weekend

content_blocks.text: A little something for the weekend
Skyscript

content_blocks.html: 3 May 2024

content_blocks.text: If you have a little time this weekend, you might enjoy reading this 2010 ‘restored’ article, which gives an account of what was observed and what was expected the last time Jupiter joined up with Uranus.
content_blocks.html: If you have a little time this weekend, you might enjoy reading this 2010 ‘restored’ article, which gives an account of what was observed and what was expected the last time Jupiter joined up with Uranus.

content_blocks.text: https://www.skyscript.co.uk/cwh.html
content_blocks.html: https://www.skyscript.co.uk/cwh.html

content_blocks.text: This is the transcript of the Carter Memorial lecture I gave as that aspect perfected in September 2010 – it’s a wide-ranging exploration which meanders through several themes, giving a recollection of the development of the internet, noting the birth of online astrology conferences (which took off at that time), and surveying some of the notable events that captured the headlines for the 2010 conjunction, and the one preceding that in 1997.
content_blocks.html: This is the transcript of the Carter Memorial lecture I gave as that aspect perfected in September 2010 – it’s a wide-ranging exploration which meanders through several themes, giving a recollection of the development of the internet, noting the birth of online astrology conferences (which took off at that time), and surveying some of the notable events that captured the headlines for the 2010 conjunction, and the one preceding that in 1997.

content_blocks.text: In the process of reformatting this (and correcting some original links that were going to dead websites), I took the opportunity to enrich the content with some extra resources and links of interest. Two to note:
content_blocks.html: In the process of reformatting this (and correcting some original links that were going to dead websites), I took the opportunity to enrich the content with some extra resources and links of interest. Two to note:

content_blocks.text: 1)   I created a new page to provide information on the (now out of print) Traditional Astrologer magazine. This currently contains three of the 19 issues as full digital reproductions available to anyone (issues 1, 8, and 16) plus two more that are only available to patrons (issues 7 and 17). I plan to make all other issues available to patrons as soon as time allows.  Full information available on the new page atohttps://www.skyscript.co.uk/TA.htmlIn addition to the full information on that webpage, you will also find links to all of the issues available to you as a member in the ‘extras’ section of the members' area:https://www.skyscript.co.uk/patron/news.php#extrasBTW, I enjoyed taking that diversion down memory lane - there is some great content in these ‘turn of the last millennium’ magazines that stands up well because of its strong focus on the application of traditional technique. I was pleased to see that issue 7 included the charts for the Estonia tragedy – that has been in the news a lot again lately with new discoveries made on the wreckage so I had been wanting to find time to dig out the charts. Here is a link to an engrossing podcast series about ithttps://crowdnetwork.co.uk/podcasts/the-secret-history-of-the-estonia/

2) Towards the end of the section ‘Grounding the fire’ in my Carter Memorial lecture, there is a weblink within the comment “Some might recall that Dennis Elwell took exception to Project Hindsight, and counter-balanced with acampaignfor astrologers to look forwards to the future, not backwards to the past, which he entitled ‘Project Foresight’.”The full force of Elwell’s campaign is not to be found on the web, but I did discover an old article that he wrote about this in January 1998, which was published on ‘astrology-world.com’ as a ‘millennium debate’.Astrology-world.comwas the first astro-website I created and has been defunct for decades but much of its content was reproduced when I started up Skyscript – most of what wasn’t included was (fortunately captured) in the Internet Archive Wayback Machine, which is where Elwell’s debate piece and follow-up replies can be found:https://web.archive.org/web/19980201200017/http://astrology-world.com/debate.htmlI had forgotten about all this, and found it interesting to reread his views again 25 years later. If you read the responses, you’ll see I gave him some scathing criticism for his view on horary at the time. It was really great to debate with Dennis, who was someone I looked up to tremendously  – we both felt completely comfortable disagreeing on some points and making our cases for those points, though I generally agreed with all of his ‘bigger points’ so that gave us a lot of common ground, and I genuinely considered him to be one of the best astrologers of my generation.

Anyway, I hope you enjoy this if you have a little time to spare to explore some broader perspectives on astrology. I was not kidding at the start of my lecture when I said that preparing it was the most stressful things I ever did as an astrologer.  It still chills me to think about how I locked myself away the week beforehand – and in my room at the conference right up to the point of delivery – rewriting most of the content in a panic as I still couldn’t decide what I was going to focus on, or in what order.  I really felt I was just “all over the place” even as I delivered it. Looking back now I realise - it was! - yet that seems to come across as part of the theme now, as if I’d planned it like that from the beginning :)

Looking back now I realise - it was! - yet that seems to come across as part of the theme now, as if I’d planned it like that from the beginning :)

content_blocks.text: Have a great weekend!

full_content:
A little something for the weekend

If you have a little time this weekend, you might enjoy reading this 2010 ‘restored’ article, which gives an account of what was observed and what was expected the last time Jupiter joined up with Uranus.
https://www.skyscript.co.uk/cwh.html
This is the transcript of the Carter Memorial lecture I gave as that aspect perfected in September 2010 – it’s a wide-ranging exploration which meanders through several themes, giving a recollection of the development of the internet, noting the birth of online astrology conferences (which took off at that time), and surveying some of the notable events that captured the headlines for the 2010 conjunction, and the one preceding that in 1997.
In the process of reformatting this (and correcting some original links that were going to dead websites), I took the opportunity to enrich the content with some extra resources and links of interest. Two to note:
1)   I created a new page to provide information on the (now out of print) Traditional Astrologer magazine. This currently contains three of the 19 issues as full digital reproductions available to anyone (issues 1, 8, and 16) plus two more that are only available to patrons (issues 7 and 17). I plan to make all other issues available to patrons as soon as time allows.  Full information available on the new page at
o   https://www.skyscript.co.uk/TA.html
In addition to the full information on that webpage, you will also find links to all of the issues available to you as a member in the ‘extras’ section of the members' area:
 https://www.skyscript.co.uk/patron/news.php#extras
BTW, I enjoyed taking that diversion down memory lane - there is some great content in these ‘turn of the last millennium’ magazines that stands up well because of its strong focus on the application of traditional technique. I was pleased to see that issue 7 included the charts for the Estonia tragedy – that has been in the news a lot again lately with new discoveries made on the wreckage so I had been wanting to find time to dig out the charts. Here is a link to an engrossing podcast series about it
https://crowdnetwork.co.uk/podcasts/the-secret-history-of-the-estonia/
 2) Towards the end of the section ‘Grounding the fire’ in my Carter Memorial lecture, there is a weblink within the comment “Some might recall that Dennis Elwell took exception to Project Hindsight, and counter-balanced with a campaign for astrologers to look forwards to the future, not backwards to the past, which he entitled ‘Project Foresight’.”
The full force of Elwell’s campaign is not to be found on the web, but I did discover an old article that he wrote about this in January 1998, which was published on ‘astrology-world.com’ as a ‘millennium debate’. Astrology-world.com was the first astro-website I created and has been defunct for decades but much of its content was reproduced when I started up Skyscript – most of what wasn’t included was (fortunately captured) in the Internet Archive Wayback Machine, which is where Elwell’s debate piece and follow-up replies can be found:
https://web.archive.org/web/19980201200017/http://astrology-world.com/debate.html
I had forgotten about all this, and found it interesting to reread his views again 25 years later. If you read the responses, you’ll see I gave him some scathing criticism for his view on horary at the time. It was really great to debate with Dennis, who was someone I looked up to tremendously  – we both felt completely comfortable disagreeing on some points and making our cases for those points, though I generally agreed with all of his ‘bigger points’ so that gave us a lot of common ground, and I genuinely considered him to be one of the best astrologers of my generation.
Anyway, I hope you enjoy this if you have a little time to spare to explore some broader perspectives on astrology. I was not kidding at the start of my lecture when I said that preparing it was the most stressful things I ever did as an astrologer.  It still chills me to think about how I locked myself away the week beforehand – and in my room at the conference right up to the point of delivery – rewriting most of the content in a panic as I still couldn’t decide what I was going to focus on, or in what order.  I really felt I was just “all over the place” even as I delivered it. Looking back now I realise - it was! - yet that seems to come across as part of the theme now, as if I’d planned it like that from the beginning :)
Have a great weekend!
Deb
4 comments
CROSSLEY Mireille
·
2y
Thank you so much for all you do for us and sending warm thoughts and hugs. 🤗

Important: Manilius meeting postponed until 30th May & other event news
Skyscript
1 May 2024
4
7
I hope this doesn’t cause anyone inconvenience, but for various reasons, it is necessary to postpone tomorrow’s planned Manilius Group meeting – this has been rescheduled for
Thursday, May 30th (usual time) - 19:30 UTC
I will circulate a reminder with full information and the handouts one week beforehand.
 There have also been a couple of other schedule adjustments to make room for this and to accommodate an extra event that wasn’t on the original schedule for this month.
 Soul-level subscribers, please note that our next meeting will be Thursday, June 6th (rather than May 30th).
The member's area has been updated to show the correct time and date information for all events.
 All-level Members
On Thursday, 16 May, Jupiter Lai and Wade Caves will hold a live-streamed discussion about Chinese astrology for the Skyscript YouTube channel (more details in the graphic below). All Skyscript patrons are welcome to watch live, and those with YouTube accounts will be free to comment and ask questions in real time.  The link details for this event will be different to usual, so I’ll circulate this information as a separate post nearer to the event. 
And as a reminder, we’ll be holding the next ‘Mundane Matters’ meeting for all patrons next Thursday (9th May) as a chance to catch up with some of the mass of things going on in the world (so much going on … who has the chance to stay abreast of it all??). I’ll circulate a reminder post about this with full information next week.
 I'll be sorry to miss tomorrow's meet-up, but Manilius is already 2000 years old, so hopefully, that postponement won't ruin the text.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

title: Hand and Houlding in Conversation: Recording now available to Patreon

content_blocks.text: This video uses Vimeo’s DNT parameter. Vimeo may still store and/or gain access to information on your device, including cookies and local storage.
content_blocks.html: This video uses Vimeo’s DNT parameter. Vimeo may still store and/or gain access to information on your device, including cookies and local storage.

content_blocks.text: Hand and Houlding in Conversation: Recording now available to Patreon
Skyscript

content_blocks.html: 21 Apr 2024

content_blocks.text: I appreciate the understanding of those of you who were unable to book onto the seminar I did with Rob Hand last November.   I am happy to announce that I can now share the recording of that event with all Skyscript Patrons.  Copies of the video are embedded in the members' page, and for those who prefer to simply listen in, there is also an audio file available.
content_blocks.html: I appreciate the understanding of those of you who were unable to book onto the seminar I did with Rob Hand last November. I am happy to announce that I can now share the recording of that event with all Skyscript Patrons. Copies of the video are embedded in the members' page, and for those who prefer to simply listen in, there is also an audio file available.

content_blocks.text: When Rob asked if I would join him for this event, he was keen to correct a false impression that he had anything but respect for arguments concerning reviewing the history of house division. Of course, my position was likewise. Rob gave me the copyright for this and passed on hopes that it would be shared as widely as possible - he anticipated that this would be the last public event he would make as an astrologer, and both of us were pleased to be able to demonstrate our enduring friendship and mutual respect in this informative and good-spirited way. However, it doesn't seem appropriate to me to share it publicly in its current form because of how it shows the faces of the attending delegates. I think it is fine to share it here, in a closed environment to sincere members of the astro-community. I'll give thought to whether I can edit the video to mask out faces, to use parts of it in a more public capacity at a later date.This recording is just over 3 hours long. I have trimmed just a couple of minutes from the video that involved a prolonged discussion (at the midway point) on whether the meeting was still being recorded and a little later when Rob took a while to find a book he was looking for—nothing of relevance was being featured at those points.

I appreciate the understanding of those of you who were unable to book onto the seminar I did with Rob Hand last November. I am happy to announce that I can now share the recording of that event with all Skyscript Patrons. Copies of the video are embedded in the members' page, and for those who prefer to simply listen in, there is also an audio file available.
When Rob asked if I would join him for this event, he was keen to correct a false impression that he had anything but respect for arguments concerning reviewing the history of house division. Of course, my position was likewise. However, it doesn't seem appropriate to me to share it publicly in its current form because of how it shows the faces of the attending delegates. I think it is fine to share it here, in a closed environment to sincere members of the astro-community. I'll give thought to whether I can edit the video to mask out faces, to use parts of it in a more public capacity at a later date.

This recording is just over 3 hours long. I have trimmed just a couple of minutes from the video that involved a prolonged discussion (at the midway point) on whether the meeting was still being recorded and a little later when Rob took a while to find a book he was looking for—nothing of relevance was being featured at those points.
Hope you enjoy it!

title: Pics, clicks and the Skyscript AI/privacy stance

content_blocks.text: Pics, clicks and the Skyscript AI/privacy stance
Skyscript

content_blocks.html: 15 Apr 2024

content_blocks.text: Pics

One of my recent ‘site prep’ tasks was to create/improve a bunch of charts shown in articles through the site. For the redesign of Kim Farnell’s biography of Alan Leo, I added charts for all the (13) astrologers mentioned on that page.  I like to add photos within chart images to make them instantly recognisable, so I was frustrated that the images we have for many past astrologers are incredibly scrappy and scruffy.
content_blocks.html: One of my recent ‘site prep’ tasks was to create/improve a bunch of charts shown in articles through the site. For the redesign of Kim Farnell’s biography of Alan Leo, I added charts for all the (13) astrologers mentioned on that page.  I like to add photos within chart images to make them instantly recognisable, so I was frustrated that the images we have for many past astrologers are incredibly scrappy and scruffy.

content_blocks.text: This is one area where recent technological advances leave me humbled with gratitude. The image here shows a few I’ve worked on, to illustrate the difference between what I start with and the kind of improvements that can be made (Alan Leo, Ivy Goldstein Jacobson, Charles Carter).  Getting good results is not an instant process – I run the images through a variety of different tools to de-scratch, de-fuss, de-pixelate, sharpen and colourise; then I work the images over in Photoshop to improve, tone down, extend and continue cut off areas, fill in blanks and fix the areas that have failed in some way.  I really enjoy doing this – one night, I swear I was woken up by the spirits of astrologers who wanted this: I got up, and Vivian Robson and Evangeline Adams got their make-over, too.
content_blocks.html: This is one area where recent technological advances leave me humbled with gratitude. The image here shows a few I’ve worked on, to illustrate the difference between what I start with and the kind of improvements that can be made (Alan Leo, Ivy Goldstein Jacobson, Charles Carter).  Getting good results is not an instant process – I run the images through a variety of different tools to de-scratch, de-fuss, de-pixelate, sharpen and colourise; then I work the images over in Photoshop to improve, tone down, extend and continue cut off areas, fill in blanks and fix the areas that have failed in some way.  I really enjoy doing this – one night, I swear I was woken up by the spirits of astrologers who wanted this: I got up, and Vivian Robson and Evangeline Adams got their make-over, too.

content_blocks.text: I’ll be featuring all of the images on site soon, with a note to make it clear that the original photographs have been amended.  For example, the credit at the bottom of the Alan Leo page reads: “Title image features a remastered and colourised version of the black and white portrait photograph of Alan Leo as presented in the frontispiece of Bessie Leo's biography on him (shown as a detail within the title image).”  That is just for the sake of transparency - I'm happy for any other astrologer who wants to use the images to do so, but I think I need to mark out what has been tampered with in some way.

content_blocks.text: Clicks

Thanks to the feedback provided here I reworked the ‘chart-click-fix’ code through to its final state. It is now possible to fix charts either to the bottom left-hand corner or the right hand corner of the screen by clicking with the left or right mouse click.  And if you are viewing on a desktop (or a device with a suitable width) you can even fix two charts  — left AND right — to the bottom of the screen as you scroll through the text.  I find this really handy when one person’s chart is being compared with another in the narrative.

content_blocks.text: I was wary about over-complicating, but now it is all finished, I think the end result is easy and logical to use for those who want to use the feature and non-intrusive for those who don’t want to use it. The Alan Leo page is a good example of how this code is implemented and can be put to good use, so take a look and click around on those charts. Note that the additional right-click enhancement is not available on mobiles or tablets, which don’t have a right-click feature anyway.

content_blocks.text: AI Disclaimer

Recent chit-chat here between Dru and Leena has made me realise that Skyscript ought to have a notice explaining its AI policy.  It should come as no surprise that while I want to employ useful tech developments, I am not moved to incorporate AI-generated text - and I want to be clear about that being a policy.  Using a disclaimer that Dru noticed on Spaceweather.com as inspiration, I have put the following as a notice on the site notes page. Hopefully, this covers it:
content_blocks.html: Recent chit-chat here between Dru and Leena has made me realise that Skyscript ought to have a notice explaining its AI policy.  It should come as no surprise that while I want to employ useful tech developments, I am not moved to incorporate AI-generated text - and I want to be clear about that being a policy.  Using a disclaimer that Dru noticed on Spaceweather.com as inspiration, I have put the following as a notice on the site notes page. Hopefully, this covers it:

content_blocks.text: Syscript does not use AI-generated text. Website content generated by artificial intelligence is hard to notice; it may seem well-written and well-informed, but it is often blighted with critical or fundamental errors. It also lacks the insightful discretion needed to represent the philosophical and metaphysical principles of astrology. Any information presented on Skyscript has been put together by a real human being. And since “to err is human…” you might occasionally find some little mistake or element of inconsistency (please appreciate that mark of authenticity, butreport it here, so a real person can correct it as soon as feasible).

And have you noticed that you never get a popup box on Skyscript asking you to agree to data collection policies?  That’s because Skyscript has no facility (or intention) to collect or hold personal information about you.  The only exception is when someone registers for the forum, where essential user information and any posts made are obviously retained in a system. Otherwise, the site privacy policy is a very simple one: there is no desire to invade anyone’s privacy.

content_blocks.author: Aquila Aurata
content_blocks.text: Deb, it's good to have this AI disclaimer. While I'm no expert on the subject, I wanted to bring your attention to the other side of this coin, which is harvesting site content for training AI language models. You might think at first that this is a moot point since everything is freely accessible on the site already, but at least it's good to have a position on whether or not you want your site to be harvested or scraped (this might already be part of your terms of permissible use for people; for crawlers, it would be controlled through a file called robots.txt). Consider, for example, that the site might have some content that's copyrighted. It could include personal data such as birth information or sensitive content on the forum. You would certainly not want expose sensitive data or be liable for inadvertently sharing it. There is a lot to think about and take care of here, which you might have done to a large part already. I'm just highlighting the fact that AI technology brings new challenges that need specific and targeted responses.

full_content:
Pics, clicks and the Skyscript AI/privacy stance
Skyscript
15 Apr 2024
7
5
Pics
One of my recent ‘site prep’ tasks was to create/improve a bunch of charts shown in articles through the site. For the redesign of Kim Farnell’s biography of Alan Leo, I added charts for all the (13) astrologers mentioned on that page.  I like to add photos within chart images to make them instantly recognisable, so I was frustrated that the images we have for many past astrologers are incredibly scrappy and scruffy. 
This is one area where recent technological advances leave me humbled with gratitude. The image here shows a few I’ve worked on, to illustrate the difference between what I start with and the kind of improvements that can be made (Alan Leo, Ivy Goldstein Jacobson, Charles Carter).  Getting good results is not an instant process – I run the images through a variety of different tools to de-scratch, de-fuss, de-pixelate, sharpen and colourise; then I work the images over in Photoshop to improve, tone down, extend and continue cut off areas, fill in blanks and fix the areas that have failed in some way.  I really enjoy doing this – one night, I swear I was woken up by the spirits of astrologers who wanted this: I got up, and Vivian Robson and Evangeline Adams got their make-over, too.
I’ll be featuring all of the images on site soon, with a note to make it clear that the original photographs have been amended.  For example, the credit at the bottom of the Alan Leo page reads: “Title image features a remastered and colourised version of the black and white portrait photograph of Alan Leo as presented in the frontispiece of Bessie Leo's biography on him (shown as a detail within the title image).” That is just for the sake of transparency - I'm happy for any other astrologer who wants to use the images to do so, but I think I need to mark out what has been tampered with in some way.
Clicks
Thanks to the feedback provided here I reworked the ‘chart-click-fix’ code through to its final state. It is now possible to fix charts either to the bottom left-hand corner or the right hand corner of the screen by clicking with the left or right mouse click.  And if you are viewing on a desktop (or a device with a suitable width) you can even fix two charts  — left AND right — to the bottom of the screen as you scroll through the text.  I find this really handy when one person’s chart is being compared with another in the narrative. 
I was wary about over-complicating, but now it is all finished, I think the end result is easy and logical to use for those who want to use the feature and non-intrusive for those who don’t want to use it. The Alan Leo page is a good example of how this code is implemented and can be put to good use, so take a look and click around on those charts. Note that the additional right-click enhancement is not available on mobiles or tablets, which don’t have a right-click feature anyway.
Biography of Alan Leo by Kim Farnell
https://www.skyscript.co.uk/Alan_Leo.html
 *If you get stuck, there is an information icon in the left margin that reads ‘Featured charts’ — click on that link to go to a ‘site notes’ page, which explains this simple facility in very simple language -
Site Notes
www.skyscript.co.uk/site_notes.html
AI Disclaimer
Recent chit-chat here between Dru and Leena has made me realise that Skyscript ought to have a notice explaining its AI policy.  It should come as no surprise that while I want to employ useful tech developments, I am not moved to incorporate AI-generated text - and I want to be clear about that being a policy.  Using a disclaimer that Dru noticed on Spaceweather.com as inspiration, I have put the following as a notice on the site notes page. Hopefully, this covers it:
Syscript does not use AI-generated text. Website content generated by artificial intelligence is hard to notice; it may seem well-written and well-informed, but it is often blighted with critical or fundamental errors. It also lacks the insightful discretion needed to represent the philosophical and metaphysical principles of astrology. Any information presented on Skyscript has been put together by a real human being. And since “to err is human…” you might occasionally find some little mistake or element of inconsistency (please appreciate that mark of authenticity, but report it here, so a real person can correct it as soon as feasible).
And have you noticed that you never get a popup box on Skyscript asking you to agree to data collection policies?  That’s because Skyscript has no facility (or intention) to collect or hold personal information about you.  The only exception is when someone registers for the forum, where essential user information and any posts made are obviously retained in a system. Otherwise, the site privacy policy is a very simple one: there is no desire to invade anyone’s privacy.
Best for now - I'll be off email until Wednesday so if any posts come in before then I'll pick them up when I'm back
Deb

Consider, for example, that the site might have some content that's copyrighted. It could include personal data such as birth information or sensitive content on the forum. title: No newsletter for a while, but …

content_blocks.text: No newsletter for a while, but …
Skyscript

content_blocks.html: 9 Apr 2024

content_blocks.text: Here is some news that will hopefully come as a minor bummer (to use up that Mars-Saturn snag), but in a way that eventually leads to improvement and contentment.  I am delaying the publication of the next Skyscript newsletter until late May – not without good reason.
content_blocks.html: Here is some news that will hopefully come as a minor bummer (to use up that Mars-Saturn snag), but in a way that eventually leads to improvement and contentment.  I am delaying the publication of the next Skyscript newsletter until late May – not without good reason.

content_blocks.text: I have been working hard on Skyscript development, and over recent weeks, I’ve reached a position where I can start implementing significant improvements and adding a lot of new content and resources. ( I’ve been close to this point a few times, but then a newsletter deadline took over and pushed me back, so whatever needed to be coordinated suffered or fell apart.)
content_blocks.html: I have been working hard on Skyscript development, and over recent weeks, I’ve reached a position where I can start implementing significant improvements and adding a lot of new content and resources. ( I’ve been close to this point a few times, but then a newsletter deadline took over and pushed me back, so whatever needed to be coordinated suffered or fell apart.)

content_blocks.text: Since the newsletter is published as a fundraiser to support the development of the website, it makes sense for me to relax its schedule during pivotal times when energies are needed on important site tasks. Your support is central to these developments, and I am always grateful for it (we are in this together!).
content_blocks.html: Since the newsletter is published as a fundraiser to support the development of the website, it makes sense for me to relax its schedule during pivotal times when energies are needed on important site tasks. Your support is central to these developments, and I am always grateful for it (we are in this together!).

content_blocks.text: I anticipate the next newsletter will be circulated in late May. I have some great contributions collected for that, and I’m eager to put that material together as soon as I can. I really do love working on the newsletter—nothing gives me greater pleasure than showcasing well-written, informative, and inspiring astrology content, so rest assured this is only a necessary delay and not a major change of plan.
content_blocks.html: I anticipate the next newsletter will be circulated in late May. I have some great contributions collected for that, and I’m eager to put that material together as soon as I can. I really do love working on the newsletter—nothing gives me greater pleasure than showcasing well-written, informative, and inspiring astrology content, so rest assured this is only a necessary delay and not a major change of plan.

content_blocks.text: In the interim, I expect to more than make up for what you will miss with the newsletter because this deadline relaxation will allow me to share some extra resources that I have planned for Skyscript patrons. Over the next few weeks, you can expect to hear from me regularly as I document the improvements being made to the site, give news of resources that will benefit you and share some privileged extras with you.

Over the next few weeks, you can expect to hear from me regularly as I document the improvements being made to the site, give news of resources that will benefit you and share some privileged extras with you.

content_blocks.text: So today, I would simply encourage you to visit the site's home page and check out the collection of articles that have been recently added or renovated. That section at the top, marked ‘Articles for astrologers’, will start to get more traction now, with content thoughtfully worked-over to maximise its usefulness in a pleasant, artistic, and calming environment that will never drown you with pop-up ads or spammy junk.

title: Eclipses are so yesterday. Comets are the new black

content_blocks.text: Eclipses are so yesterday. Comets are the new black
Skyscript

content_blocks.html: 9 Apr 2024

content_blocks.text: The sky is positively brimming with ominousity right now – today’s eclipse; tomorrow’s conjunction of the Greater and Lesser infortunes and a  ‘devil’ comet coming up to perihelion! I'm also very interested (comet-wise) in Comet Tsuchinshan–ATLAS which has the potential to evolve into a really bright, naked eye spectacle in mid October that might even be seen in the daytime. The thing about comets is that they are portents; they don’t really mean anything astrologically unless they are visible to the naked eye - both of these comets have the potential to blaze brightly and do that this year.If you are not sure what to make of comets there are two things you can do:
content_blocks.html:
The sky is positively brimming with ominousity right now – today’s eclipse; tomorrow’s conjunction of the Greater and Lesser infortunes and a ‘devil’ comet coming up to perihelion! I'm also very interested (comet-wise) in Comet Tsuchinshan–ATLAS which has the potential to evolve into a really bright, naked eye spectacle in mid October that might even be seen in the daytime. The thing about comets is that they are portents; they don’t really mean anything astrologically unless they are visible to the naked eye - both of these comets have the potential to blaze brightly and do that this year.

If you are not sure what to make of comets there are two things you can do:

content_blocks.text: Firstly, don’t forget that we haveDr Nick Campionjoining Body and Soul members this week to give a presentation about his (as yet unpublished) research into the historical understanding and use of comets by astrologers.  Nick is eager to release his new findings to an interested audience and by lucky coincidence the timing of this talk landed right on cue, with the horned devil comet grabbing a lot of media attention right now.  (Reminder details of his talk are given below).

content_blocks.text: Details of the talk by Nick Campion - for body & soul membersDate: Thursday 11th AprilTime: 3:00 pm UTCNew York - 11 am / London 4pm /check all other time zones hereSkyscript Zoom link:http://us06web.zoom.us/j/6123333126- the password (Skyscript) is embedded in the link -The talk is expected to last around 90 minutes and will be recorded for those unable to attend.Talk Theme:In the Autumn of 1618, three comets appeared in the Autumn Sky. They were significant as the first comets ever to be observed through a telescope. They also appeared at a time when people still didn’t know what comets were: one theory held that they were caused by the atmosphere igniting. As to their astrological significance, there was a near-universal understanding that they were signs from God (as was almost everything). The dominant view was that they were disruptive in a harmful way, but a counter view held that they could be positive.This talk will look at the general context within which the comets were observed and interpreted, focussing on two texts, that of John Bainbridge (who became the first Savillean Professor of Astronomy at Oxford) in December 1618, during a period of relative stability under the English king James I (James VI of Scotland), and that of William Lilly 26 years later in 1644, published in the opening stages of the traumatic English civil war. We will travel back in time to a moment at once so unlike our world, yet so similar.

For those interested in locating comet Pons-Brook (nicknamed the Devil's comet) it is currently close to the Sun so visible in the west just after sunset and will be very close beneath Jupiter later this week. The image below is courtesy viaStuart Atkinson/The Royal Astronomical Society. (View larger)

Eclipses are so yesterday. Comets are the new black
Skyscript
9 Apr 2024
11
19
The sky is positively brimming with ominousity right now – today’s eclipse; tomorrow’s conjunction of the Greater and Lesser infortunes and a ‘devil’ comet coming up to perihelion! I'm also very interested (comet-wise) in Comet Tsuchinshan–ATLAS which has the potential to evolve into a really bright, naked eye spectacle in mid October that might even be seen in the daytime. The thing about comets is that they are portents; they don’t really mean anything astrologically unless they are visible to the naked eye - both of these comets have the potential to blaze brightly and do that this year.

If you are not sure what to make of comets there are two things you can do:
Firstly, don’t forget that we have Dr Nick Campion joining Body and Soul members this week to give a presentation about his (as yet unpublished) research into the historical understanding and use of comets by astrologers.  Nick is eager to release his new findings to an interested audience and by lucky coincidence the timing of this talk landed right on cue, with the horned devil comet grabbing a lot of media attention right now.  (Reminder details of his talk are given below).
Secondly head along to this link on Skyscript, where you will find a great collection of articles and resources exploring this theme, along with some newly published historical texts, such as James Watson’s Treatise on Comets and William Lilly’s text of  ‘Strange and Wonderful Predictions of 1678’, which included his assessment of a ‘Late Blazing Star (comet). This feature is definitely worth checking out:
https://www.skyscript.co.uk/comet_chang.html
Details of the talk by Nick Campion - for body & soul members
 Date: Thursday 11th April
Time: 3:00 pm UTC
New York - 11 am / London 4pm / check all other time zones here
Skyscript Zoom link: http://us06web.zoom.us/j/6123333126
- the password (Skyscript) is embedded in the link -
The talk is expected to last around 90 minutes and will be recorded for those unable to attend.
Talk Theme:
In the Autumn of 1618, three comets appeared in the Autumn Sky. They were significant as the first comets ever to be observed through a telescope. They also appeared at a time when people still didn’t know what comets were: one theory held that they were caused by the atmosphere igniting. As to their astrological significance, there was a near-universal understanding that they were signs from God (as was almost everything). The dominant view was that they were disruptive in a harmful way, but a counter view held that they could be positive.
This talk will look at the general context within which the comets were observed and interpreted, focussing on two texts, that of John Bainbridge (who became the first Savillean Professor of Astronomy at Oxford) in December 1618, during a period of relative stability under the English king James I (James VI of Scotland), and that of William Lilly 26 years later in 1644, published in the opening stages of the traumatic English civil war. We will travel back in time to a moment at once so unlike our world, yet so similar.
For those interested in locating comet Pons-Brook (nicknamed the Devil's comet) it is currently close to the Sun so visible in the west just after sunset and will be very close beneath Jupiter later this week. The image below is courtesy via Stuart Atkinson/ The Royal Astronomical Society. (View larger)
Stay well and best for now!
Deb

content_blocks.text: I've been organising some of the resources on Skyscript.  You might find this page handy - a gallery collection of all the charts on site concerning the British royals and monarchy-related events.
content_blocks.html: I've been organising some of the resources on Skyscript.  You might find this page handy - a gallery collection of all the charts on site concerning the British royals and monarchy-related events.

content_blocks.text: https://www.skyscript.co.uk/royalcharts.htmlThese are charts of people that are always in the news, and because most of these charts are very well timed they make great natal studies. Seeing all the charts together, it is easy to note the connections between them and how this plays out in family dynamics and inter-generational dramas. (Such a lot going on in Cancer - but unfortunately, Meghan's Mars is there  -:)  There are hot spots in Libra and Scorpio, too - it's really fascinating to see note the connections being repeated from one generation to the next.

British Royals - Skyscript chart collection
Skyscript
17 Mar 2024
9
13
I've been organising some of the resources on Skyscript.  You might find this page handy - a gallery collection of all the charts on site concerning the British royals and monarchy-related events.

https://www.skyscript.co.uk/royalcharts.html

These are charts of people that are always in the news, and because most of these charts are very well timed they make great natal studies. Seeing all the charts together, it is easy to note the connections between them and how this plays out in family dynamics and inter-generational dramas. (Such a lot going on in Cancer - but unfortunately, Meghan's Mars is there  -:)  There are hot spots in Libra and Scorpio, too - it's really fascinating to see note the connections being repeated from one generation to the next.
There's currently 25 charts on the page - the number will grow as I add in more historical charts.

title: Lara's book is out this month

content_blocks.text: Lara's book is out this month
Skyscript

content_blocks.html: 14 Mar 2024

content_blocks.text: Some of you will remember from her recent Skyscript presentation that Lara Van Zydam was working on completing her book on evolutionary astrology.  It is all ready now due out at the end of this month. I love that cover design.It can be preordered on Amazon now - here is the link  for Amazon.com -https://a.co/d/4AjLnoy
content_blocks.html:
Some of you will remember from her recent Skyscript presentation that Lara Van Zydam was working on completing her book on evolutionary astrology.  It is all ready now due out at the end of this month. I love that cover design.

It can be preordered on Amazon now - here is the link  for Amazon.com - https://a.co/d/4AjLnoy

content_blocks.text: Here is the book description from teh Amazon page:
content_blocks.html: Here is the book description from teh Amazon page:

content_blocks.text: The primeval intelligence of the human soul and the ecosystem within which it operates have long remained secret, their deeper mysteries overlooked, obfuscated, or simply misunderstood. InSoul: A Modern Guide to Evolving in a Conscious Universe, Lara van Zuydam clarifies and democratizes key esoteric information by unpacking the concept of the human soul at a granular level and explaining how it interacts with the other spiritual layers that make up a human being.• The book comprehensively and concretely introduces the soul, from describing what it is to why it is currently housed in a human body, and explains the purpose of incarnation in a challenging world• It explains the distinction between the soul and the notion of "spirit," our connection to antiquity, and our deeper connection to the Source• It discusses how the modern fixation on angels and other benevolent beings has cultivated a skewed perception, and that penetrating the mysteries without invoking the necessary protections isn’t always safe• The author draws on her own experiences, the philosophical landscape articulated by the ancients, and also explores some of the more abstruse concepts discussed by influential mystic Alice A. BaileyThis powerful work explores, simplifies, and clarifies the fascinating concept of the soul and why it is important to develop self-awareness. Touching on deep topics such as death, reincarnation, and the nature of evil, it reaches beyond the light to explain how we can optimize our humanity on the journey toward self-actualization.
Congratulations Lara - I wish you every success and have just preordered my copy. Looking forward to reading it!
content_blocks.html: Congratulations Lara - I wish you every success and have just preordered my copy. Looking forward to reading it!

BaileyThis powerful work explores, simplifies, and clarifies the fascinating concept of the soul and why it is important to develop self-awareness. full_content:
Lara's book is out this month
Skyscript
14 Mar 2024
6
9
Some of you will remember from her recent Skyscript presentation that Lara Van Zydam was working on completing her book on evolutionary astrology.  It is all ready now due out at the end of this month. I love that cover design.

It can be preordered on Amazon now - here is the link  for Amazon.com - https://a.co/d/4AjLnoy
Here is the book description from teh Amazon page:

The primeval intelligence of the human soul and the ecosystem within which it operates have long remained secret, their deeper mysteries overlooked, obfuscated, or simply misunderstood. In Soul: A Modern Guide to Evolving in a Conscious Universe, Lara van Zuydam clarifies and democratizes key esoteric information by unpacking the concept of the human soul at a granular level and explaining how it interacts with the other spiritual layers that make up a human being.

• The book comprehensively and concretely introduces the soul, from describing what it is to why it is currently housed in a human body, and explains the purpose of incarnation in a challenging world
• It explains the distinction between the soul and the notion of "spirit," our connection to antiquity, and our deeper connection to the Source
• It discusses how the modern fixation on angels and other benevolent beings has cultivated a skewed perception, and that penetrating the mysteries without invoking the necessary protections isn’t always safe
• The author draws on her own experiences, the philosophical landscape articulated by the ancients, and also explores some of the more abstruse concepts discussed by influential mystic Alice A. Bailey

This powerful work explores, simplifies, and clarifies the fascinating concept of the soul and why it is important to develop self-awareness. Touching on deep topics such as death, reincarnation, and the nature of evil, it reaches beyond the light to explain how we can optimize our humanity on the journey toward self-actualization.

Congratulations Lara - I wish you every success and have just preordered my copy. Looking forward to reading it!

title: Can you check a new page design?

content_blocks.text: Can you check a new page design?
Skyscript

content_blocks.html: 13 Mar 2024

content_blocks.text: I’ve just finished creating a new page design for the articles on Skyscript that feature natal studies.
content_blocks.html: I’ve just finished creating a new page design for the articles on Skyscript that feature natal studies.

content_blocks.text: It would be great if some of you could act as beta-testers and check out this first page-revision before I template the design and apply it to other pages.
content_blocks.html: It would be great if some of you could act as beta-testers and check out this first page-revision before I template the design and apply it to other pages.

content_blocks.text: https://www.skyscript.co.uk/shelley.html
Shelley: A Tragic Romantic
A Study in Fixed Stars

This has revamped an old article that looked very shabby and uninteresting. I think the new design makes the content much more engaging to read. In any event, Shelley’s natal chart is reliably timed, and his life is dramatic enough for him to make a great natal study worth any astrologer’s attention, whether you are looking at the fixed star connections or not.
content_blocks.html: This has revamped an old article that looked very shabby and uninteresting. I think the new design makes the content much more engaging to read. In any event, Shelley’s natal chart is reliably timed, and his life is dramatic enough for him to make a great natal study worth any astrologer’s attention, whether you are looking at the fixed star connections or not.

content_blocks.text: From the design point of view, I’d like to know if the layout of the page works well for your viewing device. Note that the links to the charts (and the charts embedded in the main text) can be easily fixed into position so they remain on the screen as you read about them – just click any chart once to fix it to the lower right corner of your screen; click again to unfix.

content_blocks.html: Thank you!!

content_blocks.text: As a sidenote  - we are coming up to the centenary of Byron’s death on April 19th this year, and I mention that because he gets a mention in this piece – he died of malaria, in Missolonghi, Greece, when he was 36 – just after six in the evening, as a violent electrical thunderstorm was breaking over the city. What is it with these people and storms?! Note he has the Moon conjunct Uranus in Cancer natally, and the Moon was conjunct Uranus in Capricorn when he died, opposing Mars, which was all lined up with the transiting nodal axis. His body was sent back to England in a barrel containing 180 gallons of whisky. (I know a lot about Byron because he lived at Newstead Abbey, about 6 miles away from my house – so he was a local lad for me :) )

content_blocks.text: A beautiful article Deb, it looks very elegant... well done! I particularly like the art additions. I am using a windows PC version 10. Google browser; the pieces on the left in the "margin" the poem etc, in particular for this article seem faint. For comparison, this page that I am looking at here on Patreon, is very clear, the contrast is different. Anyway, that would be my only comment from this elderly & now visually challenged representative!! :)

content_blocks.author: Skyscript
content_blocks.text: Thanks Joanna - that is valuable feedback.  Is the main article text clear to read?  It ought to be; I have a good font there, and it is set against a white background, so it should be as clear as anything you read here.  The font in the left-hand margin *is* a bit of a compromise, to get a nice design balance to the page, but all of the content there is supplementary and not strictly necessary - in a mobile view that left side margin is dumped and doesn't appear at all.  Also - check how this appears to you in the print view.  I tried to set that up so that if someone doesn't enjoy reading on-screen, there is a good clear printout that is easily read.

content_blocks.html: 1 Mar 2024

content_blocks.text: The recording from tonight's Manilius reading group is now included in the showreel that can be accessed in the member's area.
content_blocks.html: The recording from tonight's Manilius reading group is now included in the showreel that can be accessed in the member's area.

content_blocks.text: I've also attached to this post a copy of the extract from Geminos' Phenomena which explains why there are only 4 degrees between the equator and the tropic of Cancer.
content_blocks.html: I've also attached to this post a copy of the extract from Geminos' Phenomena which explains why there are only 4 degrees between the equator and the tropic of Cancer.

content_blocks.text: Here is a graphic of the most relevant bit.
content_blocks.html: Here is a graphic of the most relevant bit.

content_blocks.text: Though it doesn’t feel like we gleaned a lot of astrological insight out of tonight’s reading some interesting points were discovered that helped to illuminate what on Earth Manilius was talking about. Plus we got that useful ref about the hand of Libra (thanks Mireille). What I like most about the 'degrees' issue, is I doubt any one of us would have cracked that point reading alone, but together as a group we figured it out - even if we were a bit fumbly getting there :) [high-5]To celebrate - and in light of complaints from certain members about the appropriateness of drawing modern technical information from the Gentleman’s Magazine for August, 1748- and (not to be outdone by Goold) I've done my own version of the diagram that explains the whole thing easily.  We might have saved a lot of time by having that diagram at the start - but then we would have missed the fun :)
content_blocks.html:
Though it doesn’t feel like we gleaned a lot of astrological insight out of tonight’s reading some interesting points were discovered that helped to illuminate what on Earth Manilius was talking about. Plus we got that useful ref about the hand of Libra (thanks Mireille). What I like most about the 'degrees' issue, is I doubt any one of us would have cracked that point reading alone, but together as a group we figured it out - even if we were a bit fumbly getting there :) [high-5]

To celebrate - and in light of complaints from certain members about the appropriateness of drawing modern technical information from the Gentleman’s Magazine for August, 1748 - and (not to be outdone by Goold) I've done my own version of the diagram that explains the whole thing easily.  We might have saved a lot of time by having that diagram at the start - but then we would have missed the fun :)

content_blocks.text: Looking forward to the next one - next Thursday's meeting will be on Mundane Matters (i'll make a reminder post about that early next week).

content_blocks.author: Jada Walston
content_blocks.text: The new diagram helped me actualize the 'colures.' I was having that modern word association problem again, thinking too closely in line with 'colors.' You ladies were a great deal of fun. I'm so thankful you offer all of these fabulous resources, Deb, it is definitely helping to fill out my learning gaps. :)

content_blocks.author: Skyscript
content_blocks.text: Oh thank you Jada - was great to have you with us :)

content_blocks.author: CROSSLEY Mireille
content_blocks.text: Thanks a lot Deb x great visual !! And loved the fun we had last night ! Little did Manilius know he would bring about such fun !!

content_blocks.author: Skyscript
content_blocks.text: Agreed :)

content_blocks.author: Leena Chauhan
content_blocks.text: This very lovely new diagram and the extract from Geminos clears up what left me a little confused yesterday. This is my fave illustration. Thank you Deb.

content_blocks.author: Joanna Grant
content_blocks.text: The new diagram is great, very helpful, but I still like the aesthetic of the Armillary Sphere :)

content_blocks.author: Skyscript
content_blocks.text: There's an interesting detail in how ancient astronomers had a different understanding of the Arctic Circle than we have today - I have been checking this out because it seemed bizarre that the Arctic Circle would commence at 54° N (I live at 53N08, so by this reckoning, I am practically arctic!)  Yes, that was what numerous ancient sources report.  Not sure when the definition changed - it is currently about 66°30′ N (the angular distance from the pole is the same as the angular distance of the ecliptic from the equator - so about 23 1/2° down from the pole, rather than the 36° Manilius reports).  Oh well, another point for another day :)

Manilius reading group recording up in the showcase
Skyscript
1 Mar 2024
4
7

The recording from tonight's Manilius reading group is now included in the showreel that can be accessed in the member's area.
I've also attached to this post a copy of the extract from Geminos' Phenomena which explains why there are only 4 degrees between the equator and the tropic of Cancer.
Here is a graphic of the most relevant bit.
Though it doesn’t feel like we gleaned a lot of astrological insight out of tonight’s reading some interesting points were discovered that helped to illuminate what on Earth Manilius was talking about. Plus we got that useful ref about the hand of Libra (thanks Mireille). What I like most about the 'degrees' issue, is I doubt any one of us would have cracked that point reading alone, but together as a group we figured it out - even if we were a bit fumbly getting there :) [high-5]

To celebrate - and in light of complaints from certain members about the appropriateness of drawing modern technical information from the Gentleman’s Magazine for August, 1748 - and (not to be outdone by Goold) I've done my own version of the diagram that explains the whole thing easily.  We might have saved a lot of time by having that diagram at the start - but then we would have missed the fun :)
Looking forward to the next one - next Thursday's meeting will be on Mundane Matters (i'll make a reminder post about that early next week).

content_blocks.html: 21 Feb 2024

content_blocks.text: It is pretty amazing that, so far, Frank Clifford’sLondon School of Astrologyhas raised over £25,000 for various worthwhile causes, through organised astrology events.
content_blocks.html: It is pretty amazing that, so far, Frank Clifford’s London School of Astrology has raised over £25,000 for various worthwhile causes, through organised astrology events.

content_blocks.text: This year I am honoured to be a part of an event that is raising funds forAwesomage– a charity that provides better prospects for orphaned children. I’ll be joining the stellar company of Frank,  Melanie Reinhart, Mark Jones and John Wadsworth in a ‘Celebration of Astrology’ at the Royal Albert Hall, London.
content_blocks.html: This year I am honoured to be a part of an event that is raising funds for Awesomage – a charity that provides better prospects for orphaned children. I’ll be joining the stellar company of Frank,  Melanie Reinhart, Mark Jones and John Wadsworth in a ‘Celebration of Astrology’ at the Royal Albert Hall, London.

content_blocks.text: If you are anywhere near London on Sunday 30th March 2024, come along and connect with fellow astrologers and be a part of this special event!
content_blocks.html: If you are anywhere near London on Sunday 30th March 2024, come along and connect with fellow astrologers and be a part of this special event!

content_blocks.text: There are currently only 50 tickets left but we absolutely want this to be a sell-out to raise as much money for theAwesomagecharity as possible.
content_blocks.html: There are currently only 50 tickets left but we absolutely want this to be a sell-out to raise as much money for the Awesomage charity as possible.

content_blocks.text: Saturday 30 March
A Celebration of Astrology
withDeborah Houlding, Mark Jones, Melanie Reinhart and John Wadsworth
Live in the Elgar Room at the Royal Albert Hall, SW7 2AP, £70, 10am–3pm.
• Melanie Reinhart on the dawning of the Age of Aquarius in shadow and light
• Mark Jones on Alan Leo, Dane Rudhyar and the birth of modern astrology
• John Wadsworth on astrology as a path to healing and wholeness
• Deborah Houlding on the fateful meeting of Alec Guinness and James Dean
• Frank Clifford celebrating the astrologers of tomorrow
Joined by the Astrology Shop of Covent Garden.
To book, visit:https://www.londonschoolofastrology.com/courses/RAH24
Any questions or to book multiple tickets, email Frank and the LSA Team:support@londonschoolofastrology.com

PS - the talk I am giving for this is the presentation onThe Startling Synastry of Guiness & Dean- which I'll be delivering to Body and Soul level members as a practice run on Thursday, 28 March 2024 - because I only have 40 minutes for my RAH event, and want to get my timing sharpened.  But even if you come to the practice run, come to the main event too (if you can!) and watch it again - its a fascinating astro-glimpse into a dramatic event and worth watching twice - AND its for charity :)

title: Newsletter #15 (Feb 2024) - update & preview

content_blocks.text: Newsletter #15 (Feb 2024) -  update & preview
Skyscript

content_blocks.html: 11 Feb 2024

content_blocks.text: With Saturn currently transiting my midheaven ( I see the gods sardonically smiling as they pile more pressure upon me), the latest issue of the newsletter has developed a definite Saturnine, melancholic theme.  In keeping with the gravity of that, it refuses to be rushed and insists on taking its time. It should be ready to distribute very soon (all being well, within the next week), but there is one feature within it that is very timely – and I don’t want it to miss its mark, so I am releasing it as an early exposure.
content_blocks.html: With Saturn currently transiting my midheaven ( I see the gods sardonically smiling as they pile more pressure upon me), the latest issue of the newsletter has developed a definite Saturnine, melancholic theme.  In keeping with the gravity of that, it refuses to be rushed and insists on taking its time. It should be ready to distribute very soon (all being well, within the next week), but there is one feature within it that is very timely – and I don’t want it to miss its mark, so I am releasing it as an early exposure.

content_blocks.text: Sheila Roher has continued her series on the astrology of dreams by compiling a fascinating article that pursues an exploration of dreams recorded by Abraham Lincoln. Reading this article is really an astrological lesson and a workshop in itself, as well as a philosophical feast, so if you have some time to set aside, please don’t ignore it – it is validating for astrology in so many ways and left me musing deeply on the impression that Lincoln left upon the world as an individual, and the impression that elements of divination made upon him as an individual.
content_blocks.html: Sheila Roher has continued her series on the astrology of dreams by compiling a fascinating article that pursues an exploration of dreams recorded by Abraham Lincoln. Reading this article is really an astrological lesson and a workshop in itself, as well as a philosophical feast, so if you have some time to set aside, please don’t ignore it – it is validating for astrology in so many ways and left me musing deeply on the impression that Lincoln left upon the world as an individual, and the impression that elements of divination made upon him as an individual.

content_blocks.text: It is timely because Lincoln was born on the 12th February - a day set aside as a national holiday (President’s day) in some states of the USA. So, wherever you live in the world, let’s recognise the solar return of a great man in history, and give thought to the magical mystery of a world that surrounds us with omens, warnings and symbols.
content_blocks.html: It is timely because Lincoln was born on the 12th February - a day set aside as a national holiday (President’s day) in some states of the USA. So, wherever you live in the world, let’s recognise the solar return of a great man in history, and give thought to the magical mystery of a world that surrounds us with omens, warnings and symbols.

content_blocks.text: The article extract is attached as a PDF file to this post, and here is the link to take you straight to it as a flipbook in the Skyscript members area:
https://www.skyscript.co.uk/patron/news.php#current

And thank you Sheila. I never feel comfortable when the newsletter is starting to feel ‘overdue’, but my original concept of a light monthly circular to be spread by email has developed into something altogether different, and the quality of the articles within it of late, such as this one, restore my calm, and make me realise that my self-imposed deadlines should not cause me stress. So, instead, I relax and take a moment to enjoy the satisfaction of playing a part in bringing great astrological content like this to the attention of colleagues who will surely appreciate it as much as I do myself.
content_blocks.html: And thank you Sheila. So, instead, I relax and take a moment to enjoy the satisfaction of playing a part in bringing great astrological content like this to the attention of colleagues who will surely appreciate it as much as I do myself.

content_blocks.text: PS – I will have no internet tomorrow, as British Telecom attempts (once again - I'll spare you the saga) to replace my old copper wiring with super-speed fibre. I am patient with their inept, feeble attempts to complete this task, realising that Saturn on my MC needs to out somewhere. Hopefully, I will be back online again on Tuesday.

I am patient with their inept, feeble attempts to complete this task, realising that Saturn on my MC needs to out somewhere. Hopefully, I will be back online again on Tuesday.

content_blocks.text: PPS – And Happy New Chinese Year of the Dragon to everyone!!

content_blocks.author: HMA
content_blocks.text:
Would this be an interesting research project?
From Wikipedia: Robert Todd Lincoln (Abraham Lincoln's son) was once saved from possible serious injury or death by Edwin Booth, whose brother, John Wilkes Booth, assassinated Robert's father. This event took place on a train platform in Jersey City, New Jersey. The exact date is uncertain, but it is believed to have taken place in late 1863 or early 1864, before John Wilkes Booth's assassination of President Lincoln.

content_blocks.author: Skyscript
content_blocks.text: Well, it's hard to make anything out of that astrologically with no time given, but it's a very interesting detail, isn't it?  I looked it up on Wikipedia - "Booth had been unaware that the man whose life he had saved on the train platform was the president's son. The knowledge of whom he had saved that day was said to have been of some comfort to Booth following his brother's assassination of the president."  Life is incredibly strange and curious, isn't it?  Thanks for that - here is the link in case anyone else wants to check it out - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Todd_Lincoln#Civil_War_years

content_blocks.author: HMA
content_blocks.text:
Pym Fontuyn, a politician in the Netherlands, was born on February 19, 1948. He was assassinated on May 6, 2002.
His chart is on the AstroDatabank. ***Progressed Mars Leo 19'20 Prog 8H conjunct Natal MC EXACT. Prog Saturn Leo 15'46 Station Direct Pluto Rx 12'34 Leo Prog 8H. Prog MC conjunct natal Neptune Rx on 12H cusp. ***
And much more in his natal 8H Gemini.

content_blocks.author: HMA
content_blocks.text:
Shortly before my husband's death, he met Julian Lincoln Simon (February 12, 1932-February 8, 1998), a well-known libertarian economist. Julian and his wife Rita became our personal friends and supported us. It was a real pleasure to talk to them.

Julian Lincoln Simon's entry in the AstroDatabank is at:
https://www.astro.com/astro-databank/Simon,_Julian

In the first pages of his autobiography, he explains his connection to Abraham Lincoln. 
A Life Against the Grain The Autobiography of an Unconventional Economist · 2018
A 52-page free preview is on Google Books. https://books.google.com/

Like Lincoln, Julian struggled with depression. "For a long time, Simon experienced debilitating depression, which allowed him to work only a few productive hours in a day. He also studied the psychology of depression and wrote a book on overcoming it." Here is a link to the full book online: http://www.juliansimon.com/writings/Good_Mood/

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Julian_Simon#Personal_life

Julian Simon         4th House Aquarius Mercury 12'59 Mars 20'35 Sun 23'17
                                 3rd House Capricorn Saturn 28'48

Abraham Lincoln   12th House Aquarius Chiron 11'43

content_blocks.author: Skyscript
content_blocks.text: That is really fascinating - thank you for sharing that. And sorry to hear about the loss of your husband at such a young age. I can only imagine how Sheila's article must have resonated with you and triggered some profound realisations.  I don't suppose you know the time of your vivid dream?  To my regret, I have memories of some profound and significant dreams but although I kept a record of the time *at the time* I have since lost that data.  I have already shared with Sheila the very vivid dream I had shortly before my son's death - it is hard even now to think about how awful that dream was, but I realise that - as some level - my soul was being prepared for a shock to come.

content_blocks.author: HMA
content_blocks.text: I am completely amazed by the analysis and Lincoln's dreams. I already knew I have one *very* close opposition in my chart to Lincoln's birth chart and now I see many more *very* close aspects, including to my Gemini MC, Cancer Mercury, and Scorpio Moon and Neptune. *** My husband died at a very young age many years ago. I had an extremely vivid lucid dream about his death in details that became a horrific reality - same details - a few months later. My dream was the first hint that anything serious was going wrong with his health.***

content_blocks.author: Kirk Little
content_blocks.text: This is pitch-perfect.  I studied Lincoln and the Civil War in a graduate history course and she has captured that blend of melancholy and grace which defined his appeal to millions in the grip of this nation's (yes, I am an American) greatest crisis.

content_blocks.author: Skyscript
content_blocks.text: Lovely way of putting it Kirk - and I agree.

content_blocks.author: Sheila Roher
content_blocks.text: Hi, Deb-- I think Saturn on your MC is telling you it's time to recognise that you have turned the  "original concept of a light monthly circular " into a beautiful, very substantial magazine that now needs to reach more people! I've been re-reading eariier editions of the 'newsletter' and am really stunned by the depth and richness of the material.

content_blocks.author: Heather
content_blocks.text: This was so educational and insightful and would love to see a workshop by Sheila.  Is William Lilly the main source if you want to study these interpretations more in depth?  (I have natal Moon and Moon’s ruler Venus conjunct my MC in the 9th).  I’m also curious about the importance or consideration of Neptune and Moon connections, although obviously more modern.  So much to explore!

content_blocks.author: Skyscript
content_blocks.text: Whether modern or not, both the Moon and Neptune are associated with the sensitised perception that empowers the strength of unconscious recognition in rational thought.  I find it hard to ignore Neptune's prominent placement on the MC in Lincoln's chart. But it is just one feature of many that show how mystical and preceptive he was beneath that austere exterior. The article has left me musing on the power of dreams as premonitions - in this case Lincoln's dreamstate was surely aware (at an extended mental level) of the danger being planned around him.  His assassination wasn't an opportunistic event - it was carefully planned and involved others who helped Booth escape. So his dreams weren't necessarily *predicting* an inevitable yet impossibly unknowable future, but they were reliably warning him about 'events in the air' that were due to take place.  (And I agree with your first suggestion totally!)

content_blocks.author: CROSSLEY Mireille
content_blocks.text: Thanks Deb - take your time !! But thanks a lot for this timely piece and thank you Sheila for your wonderful series!

content_blocks.author: Joanna Grant
content_blocks.text: Thanks, Deb, for sharing another one of Sheila's 9th house articles. This subject is so fascinating...  These pieces have helped me to make sense of my own fascination with divination! Moon in the 9th and 9th ruler conjunct the MC!

content_blocks.author: Wei
content_blocks.text: Deb, I feel hesitant to leave you another message, as I don't want to consume your time and energy in responding to me. Please take good care of yourself and rest well.❤️ Wishing you all the best. By the way, Telecom Companies around the world are all the same. 🤣

Skyscript
AUTHOR
·
2y
Whether modern or not, both the Moon and Neptune are associated with the sensitised perception that empowers the strength of unconscious recognition in rational thought.  I find it hard to ignore Neptune's prominent placement on the MC in Lincoln's chart. But it is just one feature of many that show how mystical and preceptive he was beneath that austere exterior. The article has left me musing on the power of dreams as premonitions - in this case Lincoln's dreamstate was surely aware (at an extended mental level) of the danger being planned around him.  His assassination wasn't an opportunistic event - it was carefully planned and involved others who helped Booth escape. So his dreams weren't necessarily *predicting* an inevitable yet impossibly unknowable future, but they were reliably warning him about 'events in the air' that were due to take place.  (And I agree with your first suggestion totally!)

full_content:
MUNDANE MATTERS (monthly) begins: 8 February 2024
Skyscript
3 Feb 2024
10
25
Take a little time out to catch up with current events and look into upcoming cycles. We are starting up a monthly discussion meeting which is open to all Skyscript patrons and newsletter subscribers. 
Jason Burns has offered to help steer the set-up and direction of this group, which is intended to be informal and member-led, with shared responsibility among group members for discussing ideas, giving mini-talks and leading ponderings on timely events and astronomical happenings.  
Join us for our first event on 8th February 2024 and bring ideas with you for what you want to propose or see included in the meetings moving forward. As a starting point, this first meeting will share thoughts on the Washington DC Aries ingress chart for this already tense US election year.

Please note - we want to encourage a relaxed, friendly atmosphere, without any sense of intimidation for contributing astrologers, or fear of getting things wrong 'on the record'.  For that reason, this is a live event only and will not be recorded.

Start: 10 pm UTC – San Francisco: 2 pm | New York: 5 pm | London: 10 pm | Sydney: 9 am (Fri., 9th)

Skyscript

content_blocks.html: 1 Feb 2024

content_blocks.text: At the end of last year, in the hope of ‘getting ahead’ for 2024, I decided to create all the aspectarian and lunation pages that are needed for this year’s newsletters in advance. Well, I fell behind with the plan to get this done before the year-end, but since they are all done now, I thought it might be useful to circulate this collection of charts and pre-prepared pages as an extra supplement – the tables prove very helpful to me as an easy way to get to grip with upcoming mundane themes.

2024 Astro-Calendar & Aspectarian
Skyscript
1 Feb 2024
15
14


At the end of last year, in the hope of ‘getting ahead’ for 2024, I decided to create all the aspectarian and lunation pages that are needed for this year’s newsletters in advance. Well, I fell behind with the plan to get this done before the year-end, but since they are all done now, I thought it might be useful to circulate this collection of charts and pre-prepared pages as an extra supplement – the tables prove very helpful to me as an easy way to get to grip with upcoming mundane themes.

Within this supplemement you will find:
Illustrated astrology charts for all lunations of 2024
monthly calendars showing details of mundane aspects and astronomical highlights
monthly ephemerides
‘at a glance’ illustrations of retrograde cycles for 2024 & 2025
daily calendars for 2024 showing Moon phases and planetary day rulers
overview of all the main mundane aspects for 2025
illustrated charts for the lunar and solar eclipses of 2025
daily breakdown of all major lunar and planetary aspects of 2025
24 horoscopes of the famous people whose inspiring thoughts are quoted within the publication

You can find a flip book presentation of this supplement within the 'extras' area of the member’s page – on this link: https://www.skyscript.co.uk/patron/news.php#extras 

From there ypu can also download the PDF file for your personal use if you wish.

Please do not circulate the PDF file as it is for members only. A digital edition of the supplement is available for sale to non-members through Issuu (price £5.75) and if any of you would like to add that to your Issuu library here is the code so you can claim it for free: DGDF7TZ3

Or just click this link below, which has the code embedded within it
https://issuu.com/store/code/DGDF7TZ3

I am toying with the idea of targeting a 3 or 5-year collection of these sorts of asses for next year, and making that available as a hard copy for purchase through Amazon (as well as remaining free as a PDF file or digital publication to members).  Any feedback on this, or ideas on what you would like to see added or changed is very appreciated.

Hope you find this useful!
Deb

content_blocks.text: Skyscript Brainstorming meeting - recording
Skyscript

content_blocks.html: 10 Dec 2023

content_blocks.text: Thank you to everyone who attended the brainstorming meeting yesterday. I found it tremendously helpful. Thrashing through some of the ideas has given me a much clearer sense of what needs to be done - plus a ton of extra motivation to do it.  Glad to see that my instinct of valueing links and making sure Skyscript builds strong connections to good resources elsewhere was echoed by so many of you in the chat.
content_blocks.html: Thank you to everyone who attended the brainstorming meeting yesterday. I found it tremendously helpful. Thrashing through some of the ideas has given me a much clearer sense of what needs to be done - plus a ton of extra motivation to do it.  Glad to see that my instinct of valueing links and making sure Skyscript builds strong connections to good resources elsewhere was echoed by so many of you in the chat.

content_blocks.text: Sorry that for many of you who would have liked to be there, the time of this meeting wasn't ideal - I plan to hold another meeting like this in about 6 months time, when some of the necessary facilities are in place to allow delegation of tasks.  I'll be sure to give better thought then to making sure the time is as accessible as possible, and that reminders are given more in advance.The recording is attached to this post and can also be viewed at any time in the All Member Talks showreel in the member's area.Here isa direct linkto that showreel.
