title: Alive or dead? ... the answer

content_blocks.text: Alive or dead? ... the answer
Skyscript
17 Sept 2022
content_blocks.html: 17 Sept 2022

content_blocks.text: That is a nasty Saturn (in detriment) upon the ascendant, and good things rarely happen when a nasty Saturn afflicts the ascendant. Our astrologer said that, although he considered the elevation of the asc-ruler (Sun) in the 10th house to be a good sign, he decided on the judgement of death because the greater testimonies are destructive:– Saturn on the asc; the Moon combust, and Venus being the almuten ruler of the 8th house in square to Saturn and the degree of the ascendant.  It is true that Saturn is conjunct the Part of Fortune, but that was seen as an affliction to the POF, not a benefit to Saturn.
content_blocks.html: That is a nasty Saturn (in detriment) upon the ascendant, and good things rarely happen when a nasty Saturn afflicts the ascendant. Our astrologer said that, although he considered the elevation of the asc-ruler (Sun) in the 10th house to be a good sign, he decided on the judgement of death because the greater testimonies are destructive:– Saturn on the asc; the Moon combust, and Venus being the almuten ruler of the 8th house in square to Saturn and the degree of the ascendant.  It is true that Saturn is conjunct the Part of Fortune, but that was seen as an affliction to the POF, not a benefit to Saturn.

content_blocks.text: So he judged the man to be dead, which turned out to be the case.  Sadly, we are not told how the man died, or when or where he was discovered.
content_blocks.html: So he judged the man to be dead, which turned out to be the case.  Sadly, we are not told how the man died, or when or where he was discovered.

content_blocks.text: But there is a further twist to this. Based on his chart, the astrologer went on to speculate who *killed* the missing man … so …
content_blocks.html: But there is a further twist to this. Based on his chart, the astrologer went on to speculate who *killed* the missing man … so …

content_blocks.author: Sarah McCulloch
content_blocks.text: Could it be Mercury (dispositor of the Sun and Moon) ruling and placed in the 11th H and ruling the 2nd H. The subject was murdered by a young friend over money.

content_blocks.author: Katarina Campagnola
content_blocks.text: With the Sun, ruler of first, in the tenth house, this is most likely somebody with some prominence. Ruler of the seventh on the 12th side of the ascendant and Saturn very debilitated indicates an ill willed personality that is a secret enemy, yet the querent knows the person well as it is situated on the ascendant. A lot of ill willed thoughts and feelings may have brewed under the surface. Mars squared Saturn from the 9th - long distance relations/religious/political differences may have been part of the conflict. Yet, as Mars also rules the fourth, it may be a family member involved in causing the death, or a situation related to the home and family. Mars in Aries is strong willed and wants to be seen, known and heard in their own independent way and will not take no for an answer.

content_blocks.author: Gloria Lorenzo
content_blocks.text:
• Saturn as L7 (open enemy) indicates the killer - medium height, sallow complexion, broad forehead, large ears, hair fine & dry, possibly dark red (Leo)
Saturn also L6: killing connected to a physically strong foreign employee (6th) (last Saturn contact is trine 9th Mars in domicile, then Mars trine Ascendant): killing was swift and brutal (Mars in domicile & trine Saturn)
•  Saturn is principle actor (Moon applies sextile Saturn)
• There were two or more killers:
     L1 in a common sign, esp. Gemini; 
     more than one peregrine planet in an angle (Jupiter and Saturn both)

• The killers are male, and older
 L7 perpetrator Saturn man
 Moon in Gemini man
 Moon’s dispositor Mercury conj masculine Sun man
 Moon’s phase balsamic older man
 Perpetrator is Saturn & mid-to-late degree in sign older man

•  Killers are known to the victim
 L1 Sun approaching sextile Saturn
 L7 on 1st house
 Moon conj L1
• Killers are nearby (Saturn on 1st)

content_blocks.author: CROSSLEY Mireille
content_blocks.text: Saturn ruling 6th and 7th could show he was working a very hard job for someone who killed him because he got injured during work SN in 6th. He may have been ‘put out of his misery’ on compassionate ground by the boss’s henchman and buried - Mars in Aries 9th ruling 4th house (trine Saturn) and also Jupiter on IC. Strong Venus on MC almuten of 8th could show the death to be in his benefit - no more suffering…..although it could also be because the man was very outspoken Sun/Moon Gemini about his beliefs and he was killed for religious reasons (Mars 9th, Jupiter 4th, Saturn Asc…..)

content_blocks.author: Samantha Blackadder
content_blocks.text:
Ruler of the 8th, Jupiter on the 4th, and dispositer Mars being the last planet to connect with Saturn indicates it may have happened in the home. Could it be the partners sibling (if they had one?

Or, 6th/7th house ruler on 1st. Could he have taken his own life at home L8 on L4 due to an argument with a spouse/lover?

content_blocks.author: Joanna Grant
content_blocks.text: With the ruler of the 12th the Moon, applying to the ascendant ruler, the Sun, it looks as if the man may have had a "secret enemy". 9th ruler Mars, separates from the trine of Saturn and applies to the asc, perhaps a mercenary was involved? 10th house ruler Venus, dignified and emplaced in the 10th could suggest the perpetrator, Saturn? was perhaps assisted by someone in authority, or who had a "high" position.

full_content:
Alive or dead? ... the answer
Skyscript
17 Sept 2022
8
6

That is a nasty Saturn (in detriment) upon the ascendant, and good things rarely happen when a nasty Saturn afflicts the ascendant. Our astrologer said that, although he considered the elevation of the asc-ruler (Sun) in the 10th house to be a good sign, he decided on the judgement of death because the greater testimonies are destructive:– Saturn on the asc; the Moon combust, and Venus being the almuten ruler of the 8th house in square to Saturn and the degree of the ascendant.  It is true that Saturn is conjunct the Part of Fortune, but that was seen as an affliction to the POF, not a benefit to Saturn.
So he judged the man to be dead, which turned out to be the case.  Sadly, we are not told how the man died, or when or where he was discovered.
But there is a further twist to this. Based on his chart, the astrologer went on to speculate who *killed* the missing man … so …
Does anyone want to break this chart down a little further and speculate a killer or their motive?
I will say no more myself until the full judgment is revealed in the astrologer’s own words,  in the upcoming newsletter.

Please don't feel frustrated if you judged the man to be alive - I know you were just being kind :)

content_blocks.author: Liam Sofias
content_blocks.text: My initial judgment was that the man was alive, however likely incarcerated and about to die. This was because the lights are above the earth and the Sun, lord of the Asc is not joyned to the lord of the 8th, nor is he in the 8th or 4th. The Lord of the Asc joyned to the lord of the 12th and the Moon, co-significator of the missing person being combust both lead me to believe the person was trapped somewhere. Saturn, a natural planet of imprisonment or captivity rising affirmed this as well. The applying aspect of Venus, almuten of the 8th to Saturn, a star posited in the Asc lead me to believe the man would soon die. This was supported by the Moon moving farther into combustion. However I read through the delineations others made and saw Deb mention that in the historical chart Venus was not applying to Saturn but separating, this changes the timing so I would judge the man to likely have died in some type of captivity, maybe away from his hometown because the Asc lord is peregrine!

content_blocks.author: Skyscript
content_blocks.text: Thank you to everyone who has commented here - I am going to reveal the known outcome to this in a couple of days and then move on to a second detail in the horary - so if anyone still has thoughts to share, be aware that I'll be posting the 'spoiler' soon.

content_blocks.author: Celeste F Brooks
content_blocks.text: In true Mercury Rx I have gone back and forth on dead or alive.  Started with dead and am going back to it with my original judgment.  I think the querent is dead for several reasons.  As a Leo AC he is signified by the peregrine Sun in Gemini.  His cosignifier the Moon is combust and peregrine.  Combustion symbolizes death.  The Moon phase is balsamic, the Moon in her last gasps of light before being extinguished. Saturn, the grim reaper on the cusp of the AC is also a symbology of death.  The last aspect was a trine from malefic Mars in domicile and the next aspect is a square from Venus in domicile which rules the 3rd house of communication. Venus translates the light from the cusp of the 8th house to The Sun is in a partile quincunx with Jupiter in Scorpio on the cusp of the 4th house of the grave.  Quincunx's move you into a new situation and Jupiter is often present in death charts. By the end of writing this I think he is alive again and just went out for milk and ran off. I cant wait to read the whole story.

content_blocks.author: Skyscript
content_blocks.text: Ha ha - feeling your angst :)

content_blocks.author: West McDonough
content_blocks.text: Of course, having already argued that it says he's dead, I'm reminded of the aphorism from Culpepper saying something like "judge not rashly that the missing person is dead, he may be but drunk" ;)

content_blocks.author: AMANDA WILLIAMS
content_blocks.text: Alive but everything seems to suggest close to death. Even though I wouldn't usually use a quincunx in horary- the Sun seconds away from the aspect to the 8th house ruler which is so close to the 4th house cusp, together with the moon ruler of 12th approaching the Sun suggests the matter will be resolved very quickly

content_blocks.author: Skyscript
content_blocks.text: There's some great observations in this thread! One thing I should have pointed out from the start - this chart wheel shows the closest computer match to the historical chart, so some of the positions in the wheel vary very slightly from what the 14th century astrologer recorded, as shown in the box below the image.  For example, Venus is recorded at 18.37 Leo int eh historical image, not 17.34 as shown here.  The newsletter will show both the historical chart and the modern computation - generally they agree very well.

content_blocks.author: peter moodie
content_blocks.text: Alive, but in great danger health wise. (1)( Sun in the 10th house of medication, and visibility, with no aspect to the 8th house of death,but in detriment and Peregrin. (2.) Saturn ruler of the 6th house of sickness,and the 7th. of    enemy, and the south node in the 6th, is in detriment in the 1st by the 5deg    rule, conj.POF.,fortune is not favourable.  Moon co. significator and ruler of     the 12th house of imprisonment, self-undoing applying by conj. with sun.   Sun, and Jupiter retrograde (ruler of the 8th.)in mutual application by inconjunct, is hinting of problems that lacks clarity. A dignified Venus, ruler of the 10th(medication) and the 3rd(communication) applying by square to Saturn( maybe with lots of help danger can be averted.

content_blocks.author: Katarina Campagnola
content_blocks.text: Saturn, the ruler of the 7th as a representative of portal of death is on the ascendant, weak and debilitated. Mars, ruler of the 4th - end of things, has just squared Saturn (also ruler of sixth - possible accident on a journey (9th)?), and Venus, almuten ruler of the eight, strong and potent, is about to square Saturn. If he is not dead yet, he will be when Venus squares Saturn and the ascendent. The Sun does not have dignity, although Mercury is present in the same sign and dignified, but leaving the ruler of first, the Sun (not much help there). The Sun is strong in its position in the tenth house by placement, but the Moon applying to the Sun- and in its balsamic face, points to the end of a cycle and it is also going in to a weakened state of combustion. Jupiter, ruler of the eight is in poor condition on the 4th cusp, end of matters. Jupiters benefic qualities are not present under such circumstances (no dignity in Scorpio, and retrograde). The planets associated with death and accidents (mars and Venus in this case) are stronger, so  my guess is that the person is dead.

content_blocks.author: Skyscript
content_blocks.text: Some good points here. "Venus, almuten ruler of the eight, strong and potent, is about to square Saturn. If he is not dead yet, he will be when Venus squares Saturn and the ascendent" - in the historical chart wheel Venus is recorded at 18.42, so the square to Saturn is very close but already past perfection (as the original astrologer understood it), but its square to the ascendant is still applying.

content_blocks.author: Doug McIntosh
content_blocks.text: Alive. It seems strange to use L1 for the missing man, but assuming that is proper, I'd say judgment is given by the fact that neither L1 or the Moon (if we're going to give that to the missing man as a cosignificator) separates from aspect to Lord 8 (nor could it, as they and Jupiter are inconjunct). Also, Lord 1 is on the North Node by antiscion, which would seem to be a positive.

content_blocks.author: Skyscript
content_blocks.text: I suspect this was a question asked about a person of importance - I did try to research around that time but there was nothing to be found to confirm that. But it doesn't seem that the question was asked by someone in an identifyable relationship with the missing man, because the historical principle, as explained by Lilly (CA, p.151) is “If a Question be demanded of one absent in a general way, and the querent hath no relation to the party; then the first house, the lord of that house and the Moon shall signify the absent party”.

content_blocks.author: Gloria Lorenzo
content_blocks.text:
DEad:• Sun, the missing man’s significator, is peregrine, so he’s receiving no help. 
• Asc is in fixed Leo, so he’s motionless.
• Malefic Saturn on ASC - strong by angularity, peregrine, and in detriment, making it especially malevolent - adding to the situation’s violence. 
• Almuten of the 8th, Venus is very strong (domicile, trip., angular, most elevated).
• End of the matter/the grave Lord 4 is Mars in Scorpio, a death sign itself, L4 cinching the death conclusion. 
• L8 Jupiter (in Scorpio: death) moving away from 4th – death has already occurred.
• Course of the question: Moon goes combust, then squares 8th cusp (death).

Alive or dead?
Skyscript
12 Sept 2022
2
19
This is a modern format chart for a 14th century horary that has been translated out of Latin by Morgan and will appear in the next edition of the newsletter.
The question concerns a missing man and aims to establish if he is alive or dead.  
The astrologer used the ascendant to signify the missing man. He also considered the almuten rulers of the houses - these are shown in the box on the right.
What do you think? 
(And if you feel bold enough ... why ??)
Alive
Dead

• L8 Jupiter (in Scorpio: death) moving away from 4th – death has already occurred.
• Course of the question: Moon goes combust, then squares 8th cusp (death).

title: End of an era

content_blocks.text: End of an era
Skyscript
9 Sept 2022
content_blocks.html: 9 Sept 2022

content_blocks.text: I have been following, demonstrating and considering the queen’s chart for the whole of my life as an astrologer.  It is a well-timed chart that has never failed to deliver remarkable correspondences between major astro-cycles and transits and the most important events of her life.
content_blocks.html: I have been following, demonstrating and considering the queen’s chart for the whole of my life as an astrologer.  It is a well-timed chart that has never failed to deliver remarkable correspondences between major astro-cycles and transits and the most important events of her life.

content_blocks.text: Back in May, I posted a Twitter post that gave a very gentle heads up to her being at an age where the difficult upcoming astro-events would be too much for a woman of her age to be able to bear and to watch for August as a time when ‘the worst of it’ would be understood.  I had noticed that the lunar eclipse in May this year fell exactly upon the degree of her natal MC, and that she was experiencing the transiting square of Saturn to her Saturn-MC conjunction. By the end of August Saturn was retrograding to her 1st house Mars-Jupiter conjunction – so given the eclipse, and this dramatic line up I expected some kind of sad announcement to come around the end of August.
content_blocks.html: Back in May, I posted a Twitter post that gave a very gentle heads up to her being at an age where the difficult upcoming astro-events would be too much for a woman of her age to be able to bear and to watch for August as a time when ‘the worst of it’ would be understood.  I had noticed that the lunar eclipse in May this year fell exactly upon the degree of her natal MC, and that she was experiencing the transiting square of Saturn to her Saturn-MC conjunction. By the end of August Saturn was retrograding to her 1st house Mars-Jupiter conjunction – so given the eclipse, and this dramatic line up I expected some kind of sad announcement to come around the end of August.

content_blocks.text: It was at the end of August that it was publicly announced her health was too much of a concern for her to shake the new PM's hand at Buckingham Palace.  At this time, it was clear that the Queen was at the end, probably only holding on by a staunch sense of duty to make that final hand-shake.
content_blocks.html: It was at the end of August that it was publicly announced her health was too much of a concern for her to shake the new PM's hand at Buckingham Palace.  At this time, it was clear that the Queen was at the end, probably only holding on by a staunch sense of duty to make that final hand-shake.

content_blocks.text: According to official reports, the Prime Minister was told of the Queen’s death at 4:30 pm yesterday (8th September 2022), two hours before the news was released to the public.  We can assume there was some private delay before this occurred, but not much – this is too much of an important event in terms of national changes for the PM not to be informed as soon as feasible.
content_blocks.html: According to official reports, the Prime Minister was told of the Queen’s death at 4:30 pm yesterday (8th September 2022), two hours before the news was released to the public.  We can assume there was some private delay before this occurred, but not much – this is too much of an important event in terms of national changes for the PM not to be informed as soon as feasible.

content_blocks.text: As she passed away yesterday, the conjunction of transiting Saturn with her natal Mars was exact, and the Moon moved right in to spot-light the moment. The Sun was upon her 8th house cusp (these charts show Regio, but the conjunction is still tight whichever quadrant system used), whilst the 8th-ruler, Mercury, was stationing in the 8th house, in opposition to its natal position, which had Jupiter joining it by transit.  Once again, the Queen’s nativity revealed her impeccable sense of cosmic timing.
content_blocks.html: As she passed away yesterday, the conjunction of transiting Saturn with her natal Mars was exact, and the Moon moved right in to spot-light the moment. The Sun was upon her 8th house cusp (these charts show Regio, but the conjunction is still tight whichever quadrant system used), whilst the 8th-ruler, Mercury, was stationing in the 8th house, in opposition to its natal position, which had Jupiter joining it by transit.  Once again, the Queen’s nativity revealed her impeccable sense of cosmic timing.

content_blocks.text: I cannot say I am “saddened” by her passing – she had lived a very long life and I am sure she was ready. But I am feeling struck by the chord of the moment, and the realisation of how much she played a part of daily life in Britain, as a stoic and respected back-ground figure who was “always there”.

But I am feeling struck by the chord of the moment, and the realisation of how much she played a part of daily life in Britain, as a stoic and respected back-ground figure who was “always there”.

content_blocks.text: So now begins the reign of Charles III – not that they will ask my opinion, but if I were electing the date for his coronation, 1st March 2023 would be perfect, with a Jupiter Venus conjunction then at 12° Aries, (on his natal MC) and the Moon then applying to the trine of the Sun in Pisces.

full_content:
End of an era
Skyscript
9 Sept 2022
15
14

I have been following, demonstrating and considering the queen’s chart for the whole of my life as an astrologer.  It is a well-timed chart that has never failed to deliver remarkable correspondences between major astro-cycles and transits and the most important events of her life.
Back in May, I posted a Twitter post that gave a very gentle heads up to her being at an age where the difficult upcoming astro-events would be too much for a woman of her age to be able to bear and to watch for August as a time when ‘the worst of it’ would be understood.  I had noticed that the lunar eclipse in May this year fell exactly upon the degree of her natal MC, and that she was experiencing the transiting square of Saturn to her Saturn-MC conjunction. By the end of August Saturn was retrograding to her 1st house Mars-Jupiter conjunction – so given the eclipse, and this dramatic line up I expected some kind of sad announcement to come around the end of August.
It was at the end of August that it was publicly announced her health was too much of a concern for her to shake the new PM's hand at Buckingham Palace.  At this time, it was clear that the Queen was at the end, probably only holding on by a staunch sense of duty to make that final hand-shake.
According to official reports, the Prime Minister was told of the Queen’s death at 4:30 pm yesterday (8th September 2022), two hours before the news was released to the public.  We can assume there was some private delay before this occurred, but not much – this is too much of an important event in terms of national changes for the PM not to be informed as soon as feasible.
As she passed away yesterday, the conjunction of transiting Saturn with her natal Mars was exact, and the Moon moved right in to spot-light the moment. The Sun was upon her 8th house cusp (these charts show Regio, but the conjunction is still tight whichever quadrant system used), whilst the 8th-ruler, Mercury, was stationing in the 8th house, in opposition to its natal position, which had Jupiter joining it by transit.  Once again, the Queen’s nativity revealed her impeccable sense of cosmic timing.
I cannot say I am “saddened” by her passing – she had lived a very long life and I am sure she was ready. But I am feeling struck by the chord of the moment, and the realisation of how much she played a part of daily life in Britain, as a stoic and respected back-ground figure who was “always there”.
So now begins the reign of Charles III – not that they will ask my opinion, but if I were electing the date for his coronation, 1st March 2023 would be perfect, with a Jupiter Venus conjunction then at 12° Aries, (on his natal MC) and the Moon then applying to the trine of the Sun in Pisces.

Skyscript Newsletter, Vol II
Skyscript
24 Aug 2022
9
2
Hi everyone,
I am very excited to share the second edition of the Skyscript newsletter, which is hot off my desk.
Apparently, this is not the solstice and the Sun did not stand still as I hoped it would, to allow me distribute the newsletter *before* it made its ingress. What I lack in deadline delivery skills I hope I make up for in content delivery.  There is some really good stuff in this month’s newsletter, with a nice variety of content to give everyone something to enjoy with a cup of tea.
I have attached it as a reduced size PDF file for those who prefer a straightforward download.  If you'd rather view it as a flip book, you can get free access on the ISSUU site by going to the following address and entering the access code below:

https://issuu.com/store/publishers/sta_astrology/issues/skyscript_aug_22_newsletter_2/code/CKYCMKSY
CKYCMKSY
I will be opening up poll post shortly to solicit your feedback on the AG mystery detailed in this issue.
Enjoy!
Deb

Skyscript Newsletter #11 (August 2023) is out!
It’s a rarity, but wait long enough and a month comes along with a Blue Moon in it, and I manage to get ahead of a deadline :)  The August
21 Jul 2023
11
30
I want to thank you, again - your support has enlivened and enthused me,  and I am bursting with creative excitement – loving all the potential for creating a more ‘discerning’ reservoir of astro-info on the web. This is to let you know about one particular project I am working on, and to give you exclusive access to some of its content. I am currently partnering with Morgan Le Gall to improve the appearance and resources on the page that gives David McCann’s biography of Julius Firmicus. David McCann was a very unassuming yet talented classical scholar, a perfect gentleman who had pursued a life-long study of the history, theory and practice of astrology. I lost contact with David in the late 1990s and since he was an elderly man when I was young, I doubt I will be able to regain contact with him again. After Jean Rhys Bram’s English 1975 translation of Firmicus’s  Mathesis  had been many years out of print, David took it on himself to retype the whole manuscript, in the hope that I would keep it in circulation through the small print publishing company I ran at the time (Ascella Publications).  As a classicist he was already very familiar with its content - he had learned his own astrology from a Latin edition of this work, so, in the process of retyping, he corrected various errors and made several rearrangements and improvements to Bram’s original text, whilst I worked on a new layout, did the final editing and indexing, and created new diagrams.  I sought, and was given, permission by Jean Rhys Bram to publish the new edition.  Sadly, within just a few years I needed to dispose of Ascella publications for health reasons, and very shortly afterwards the Ascella edition dropped out of print too. Since I no longer have any digital files, I am in the process of scanning and editing a hard copy, to recapture this text once again.  Having acquired a little knowledge of Latin myself in the interim, I am also seeing places where amendments or additional footnotes could be helpful. I will be including several chapters on Skyscript – which will be serialised over time, starting with book II, which lays out the basic concepts. Book I will not be included on Skyscript (at least not in the foreseeable future) but I am including a copy of that chapter here as a 15-page PDF download for Patreons who would like a copy. Note – there is no practical astrology in book I of the  Mathesis  – this acts as a Preface which presents arguments against contemporary critics and sceptics of astrology. The points of dispute are considered quite important for anyone wishing to understand or research the historical setting and development of astrology because Firmicus holds a remarkably severe Stoical stance which rejects free will in favour of determinism.  Because of the influence of this work, it is often claimed that all ancient astrology was deterministic, which was not the case in reality. In our first Skyscript discussion meeting to be held over Zoom (details to follow in the newsletter), I will open up exploration and discussion of the issue of fate and freewill in historical sources, and as part of that, I will be looking at some of the comments made in this chapter.   That’s all for now – as this is my very first email to Patrons, I am keeping my fingers crossed that this circulates just as it should! Deb

title: Agatha Christie Poll

content_blocks.text: Agatha Christie Poll
Skyscript

content_blocks.html: 24 Aug 2022

content_blocks.text: What was the cause or motivation of Agatha’s disappearance and prolonged absence?Please feel encouraged to add extra thoughts and observations of your own!
content_blocks.html:
What was the cause or motivation of Agatha’s disappearance and prolonged absence?

Please feel encouraged to add extra thoughts and observations of your own!

content_blocks.text: Ambition (publicity stunt, designed to raise her profile as a mystery writer)
content_blocks.html: Ambition (publicity stunt, designed to raise her profile as a mystery writer)

content_blocks.author: Leena Chauhan
content_blocks.text: Turns out the BBC made a 3-part TV programme about Lucy Worsley’s book on Agatha Christie! https://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/episodes/p0d9c9v5/agatha-christie-lucy-worsley-on-the-mystery-queen

content_blocks.author: Skyscript
content_blocks.text: Brilliant!

content_blocks.author: Leena Chauhan
content_blocks.text: Just came across a FT Weekend review (from 10 Sep 2022) of 'Agatha Christie: A Very Elusive Woman' by Lucy Worsley. "The wartime horrors of her experience as a nurse inspired the 'queen of crime' to expose the dark side of the upper-crust society she knew so well." [Read it in the print  version and no link due to paywall.]

content_blocks.author: Skyscript
content_blocks.text: That sounds really interesting Leena - I feel that the big story for Agatha is what she went through as a young woman in those war experiences, and how she got fascinated in herbs abd poisons, etc.  Do you have the link you can paste here?

content_blocks.author: Jeanette Han
content_blocks.text: What a fascinating insight. The newspapers and theories back then made this much talked about mystery even more intriguing. Reading that she had suffered from insomnia; the death of her mother, and 'a number of private troubles', made it easy to see how low she must have felt and how her mental state must have been completely confused and depressed. The fallen Scorpio Moon in the house of endings is in partile trine to the 12th Cancer cusp, which Lily says is '...signification of private enemies, of witches..." bringing attention to the history of the home. The Moon approaching retrograde Mercury paints a very sad picture. I found real grief in the dispositor, Mars, cadent and peregrine, when I read its Sabian Symbol; "A widow at an open grave". The text mentioned that 'Amnesia can be triggered by stress' makes sense, especially as Horace Leaf described her as 'Half dazed and half purposeful'. I agree with the 4th option, yet I feel there's something else that I can't put my finger on. Thanks, Deb, for sharing this, it took me back in time as my mother was a massive Agatha Christie fan!

content_blocks.author: Skyscript
content_blocks.text: I like that reference to Horace Leaf too Jeanette. A lot of psychics made predictions (most predicted that she was dead) - but he didn't volunteer to get involved, he was called upon by Arthur Conan Doyle.  Of course, he would have known exactly who the glove belonged to because it was so "in the news". I think he called it right with that comment, because the mix of motives and causes is too complicated to put into one neat bracket.

content_blocks.author: CROSSLEY Mireille
content_blocks.text: Thanks Deb, fantastic article and sleuthing exercise ! I too go with the overwhelming of the mind and loss of control of the situation even if jealousy, anger and vengeance are there too. A natal Venus in Scorpio in 10th disposited by that Mars 1st Sag square Uranus is unlikely to feel kindly at being betrayed. However I think that her natal Saturn in 8th in Virgo, triggered by the Sun squaring it on her disappearance - anguish of the mind on overdrive, as it is already a Virgo's natural tendency to worry and analyse -  and also Tr Saturn slowly coming to the square of it also shows the upcoming breakdown/death of her established world. Neptune natal square to her Saturn, as well as Neptune rising on her disappearance shows that she may indeed have chosen to escape (drugs like you mention ) and then somehow found it hard to get a grip back on both the reality and the situation (however temporary).  Interesting to see that Tr Neptune is also in her Natal 8th house (Trine Mars & Sext Uranus)which again picks on death, anguish etc, as you pointed out this was highlighted in her SR.  She wanted out - of this world and its mess I feel!

content_blocks.author: Skyscript
content_blocks.text: Yes - "death of her established world" is a very good way to put it. I do believe that when she left the house that night she was truly desperate and despondent. Thanks for the extra thoughts Mireille.

content_blocks.author: Skyscript
content_blocks.text:
I am sure there must be some complicated mix in this situation too. Today we have much better understanding (and openness) towards mental health problems - back in the 1920s you had to be either  1) someone with no emotional issue who just had a memory problem from a knock on the head or 2) a deranged wife who needs locking up in the west wing.
One theory is that she planned to go away in order to punish her husband with the help of her sister who was in on it all. The car crash was within walking distance of a train station that would take her to London, where she could have spent the night with her sister before catching the train to Harrogate the next day. That sequence of events sounds plausible to me, but I doubt it was planned in advance. 
Thanks for commenting on the progressions - I didn't get time to look at progressions or directions and was hoping somebody would.

content_blocks.author: AMANDA WILLIAMS
content_blocks.text: I've chosen subtle vengeance but my feeling is that it is a mix of that and the emotional breakdown. I feel that her Mars ( coupled with the Mars on the MC when she disappeared) would have meant that she needed to act, to do something, anything. The configuration between Neptune, Uranus and the Moon with Mercury suggests sudden action but the involvement of Mercury suggests a certain amount of decision making as well as the Moon's emotional response. I am still not sure whether the car incident was deliberate or truly an accident, I am inclined to think a genuine accident that happened because she was upset, but I think she decided that it would serve a purpose when it happened. She may well have intended to go away to the hotel before the accident - it just changed her means of getting there? I don't believe for a minute she lost her memory, and her pointing out her resemblance to the missing person was entirely deliberate to preempt anyone reporting it. She knew what she was doing. I pulled up the progressions for the date and the transiting Sun is 1 degree away from her progressed Venus-and by the next day she had taken on the name of her romantic rival. That's lovely astrology.

content_blocks.author: Emma Gardiner
content_blocks.text: She must have felt imprisoned too (one interpretation of Sun in the 12th in her SR), plus a natal Mars and Sag rising doesn't like to be blocked! It's interesting that in the disappearance chart, as the Sun she is applying to 5th ruler Jupiter placed on 7th house cup of husband but also destinations, (which Jupiter receives), and in the discovery chart she is the Sun again but now in the 5th house. Alongside the signification of affairs, the 5th house connection shows how she spent the rest of the time on her own "holiday". This was a great read, thank you!

content_blocks.author: Skyscript
content_blocks.text: Thank you Emma - I agree with you.  The more I think about how she has been characterised as a dowdy character the more I realise the astrology shows us how she really was - not retiring at all :)

content_blocks.author: Skyscript
content_blocks.text:
Hi Jason - I can't recall the exact details without hunting them down again in one of the detailed biographies, but it was reported that sales of her books increased a lot in the 3 years following this incident, so it certainly didn't do her any harm career-wise. A lot of people were very unhappy with her at the time though, and there was a huge amount of criticism, with some people arguing that the Christies should be made to cover the costs of the police searches etc (they weren't asked to do this, but questions were asked in parliament about it). 
But I doubt she was worried much about money to stage this. It is true they had stretched their budget when buying the house at Sunningdale, because it needed a lot of repairs, but remember her wealthy mother had recently died, and she was starting to get good book contracts, so all-in-all she was in a good place financially.

content_blocks.author: David ZL
content_blocks.text: The Moon separates from 8th ruler Jupiter and applies to 2nd ruler Mercury, Jupiter is angular and disposes the Sun. I wonder if there’s money involved in this? Otherwise Jupiter also rules the 5th house, maybe she IS going for a nice spa after all.

content_blocks.author: Sonja G Foxe
content_blocks.text: Sheila's convinced me

Agatha Christie Poll
Skyscript
24 Aug 2022
5
24
What was the cause or motivation of Agatha’s disappearance and prolonged absence?

Please feel encouraged to add extra thoughts and observations of your own!

Ambition (publicity stunt, designed to raise her profile as a mystery writer)
Subtle vengeance (to punish/expose the cruelty of her husband and his mistress)
Genuine loss of memory (dissociate fugue after knocking her head in the accident)
Emotional breakdown followed by inability to deal with a situation that got out of hand

It's interesting that in the disappearance chart, as the Sun she is applying to 5th ruler Jupiter placed on 7th house cup of husband but also destinations, (which Jupiter receives), and in the discovery chart she is the Sun again but now in the 5th house. Alongside the signification of affairs, the 5th house connection shows how she spent the rest of the time on her own "holiday". This was a great read, thank you!

Hi Jason - I can't recall the exact details without hunting them down again in one of the detailed biographies, but it was reported that sales of her books increased a lot in the 3 years following this incident, so it certainly didn't do her any harm career-wise. A lot of people were very unhappy with her at the time though, and there was a huge amount of criticism, with some people arguing that the Christies should be made to cover the costs of the police searches etc (they weren't asked to do this, but questions were asked in parliament about it). 
But I doubt she was worried much about money to stage this. It is true they had stretched their budget when buying the house at Sunningdale, because it needed a lot of repairs, but remember her wealthy mother had recently died, and she was starting to get good book contracts, so all-in-all she was in a good place financially.

content_blocks.html:
Hi everyone
An aspectarian for August - attached as a PDF file. You'll get good value from this by looking at the two lunations of the month and the major themes coming up.
August strikes me as quite a challenging and unsettled month.
It is dominated by Uranus in many ways, and I note that the upcoming Mars-Uranus conjunction, which perfects on 1st August, is the only non-lunar conjunction of the month.
The full Moon in Aquarius on 12th August is certainly not the easiest lunation, with the Moon conjunct Saturn and squaring the Mars-Uranus conjunction.  Since the sign of Leo is associated with thunderstorms (said to be the lion roaring) I expect the weather will be quite unsettled with maybe periods of thunderstorms & hail, &c.  Hopefully no earthquakes!
If anyone would like to venture any thoughts of your own, please do.

Here are three more signs of the month's turbulence:
- Stationary Uranus squares the full Moon degree throughout the month.
- Mars begins August in square to the full Moon, ends it in square to the new Moon, and is peregrine both times.
- At the full Moon, Venus disposes the Mars-Uranus conjunction in opposition to where Pluto will enter Aquarius.

Hi everyone
An aspectarian for August - attached as a PDF file. You'll get good value from this by looking at the two lunations of the month and the major themes coming up.
August strikes me as quite a challenging and unsettled month.
It is dominated by Uranus in many ways, and I note that the upcoming Mars-Uranus conjunction, which perfects on 1st August, is the only non-lunar conjunction of the month.
The full Moon in Aquarius on 12th August is certainly not the easiest lunation, with the Moon conjunct Saturn and squaring the Mars-Uranus conjunction.  Since the sign of Leo is associated with thunderstorms (said to be the lion roaring) I expect the weather will be quite unsettled with maybe periods of thunderstorms & hail, &c.  Hopefully no earthquakes!
If anyone would like to venture any thoughts of your own, please do.

title: Part of Spirit Update

content_blocks.text: Part of Spirit Update
Skyscript

content_blocks.html: 26 Jul 2022

content_blocks.text: A quick note about some feedback on a point I made on p.8 of the newsletter, where I wrote:
content_blocks.html: A quick note about some feedback on a point I made on p.8 of the newsletter, where I wrote:

content_blocks.text: Martin Gansten has emailed me to explain that where it has been translated as the “Part ofAbsent Persons” (as it is in the Warburg translation, for example) this is not a good rendering of the Arabicsahm al-ghayb.
content_blocks.html: Martin Gansten has emailed me to explain that where it has been translated as the “Part of Absent Persons” (as it is in the Warburg translation, for example) this is not a good rendering of the Arabic sahm al-ghayb.

content_blocks.text: He says that phrase “is in fact a fairly close translation of the Greek 'Lot of the Daimon' (or Spirit, which is itself an approximative translation) … The notion of ‘absence’ comes from the fact that the pertinent word can mean “absence, the hidden, hidden, the invisible, the supersensory, divine secret…”.
content_blocks.html: He says that phrase “is in fact a fairly close translation of the Greek 'Lot of the Daimon' (or Spirit, which is itself an approximative translation) … The notion of ‘absence’ comes from the fact that the pertinent word can mean “absence, the hidden, hidden, the invisible, the supersensory, divine secret…”.

content_blocks.text: Martin adds – “Translatingghaybas 'absence' or 'absent' isn't wrong in itself, in the sense that if you had no context, it could reasonably mean that. But since we do have context, we can understand that the Arabic authors had a different meaning in mind.”
content_blocks.html: Martin adds – “Translating ghayb as 'absence' or 'absent' isn't wrong in itself, in the sense that if you had no context, it could reasonably mean that. But since we do have context, we can understand that the Arabic authors had a different meaning in mind.”

content_blocks.text: So this is another example of the words being correct, but the translation not correctly communicating the intention of the words – a point I talk about in my translation notes on p.13 of the newsletter.
content_blocks.html: So this is another example of the words being correct, but the translation not correctly communicating the intention of the words – a point I talk about in my translation notes on p.13 of the newsletter.

content_blocks.text: I’ll include Martin’s update in full in the next issue of the newsletter, but just wanted to pass that info on quickly, to clear it up before further confusion is spread.

full_content:
Part of Spirit Update
Skyscript
26 Jul 2022
10
A quick note about some feedback on a point I made on p.8 of the newsletter, where I wrote:
Martin Gansten has emailed me to explain that where it has been translated as the “Part of Absent Persons” (as it is in the Warburg translation, for example) this is not a good rendering of the Arabic sahm al-ghayb.
He says that phrase “is in fact a fairly close translation of the Greek 'Lot of the Daimon' (or Spirit, which is itself an approximative translation) … The notion of ‘absence’ comes from the fact that the pertinent word can mean “absence, the hidden, hidden, the invisible, the supersensory, divine secret…”.
Martin adds – “Translating ghayb as 'absence' or 'absent' isn't wrong in itself, in the sense that if you had no context, it could reasonably mean that. But since we do have context, we can understand that the Arabic authors had a different meaning in mind.”
So this is another example of the words being correct, but the translation not correctly communicating the intention of the words – a point I talk about in my translation notes on p.13 of the newsletter.
I’ll include Martin’s update in full in the next issue of the newsletter, but just wanted to pass that info on quickly, to clear it up before further confusion is spread.
Comments
Get more out of every post with the app.
Open app
Related posts
I want to thank you, again - your support has enlivened and enthused me,  and I am bursting with creative excitement – loving all the potential for creating a more ‘discerning’ reservoir of astro-info on the web. This is to let you know about one particular project I am working on, and to give you exclusive access to some of its content. I am currently partnering with Morgan Le Gall to improve the appearance and resources on the page that gives David McCann’s biography of Julius Firmicus. David McCann was a very unassuming yet talented classical scholar, a perfect gentleman who had pursued a life-long study of the history, theory and practice of astrology. I lost contact with David in the late 1990s and since he was an elderly man when I was young, I doubt I will be able to regain contact with him again. After Jean Rhys Bram’s English 1975 translation of Firmicus’s  Mathesis  had been many years out of print, David took it on himself to retype the whole manuscript, in the hope that I would keep it in circulation through the small print publishing company I ran at the time (Ascella Publications).  As a classicist he was already very familiar with its content - he had learned his own astrology from a Latin edition of this work, so, in the process of retyping, he corrected various errors and made several rearrangements and improvements to Bram’s original text, whilst I worked on a new layout, did the final editing and indexing, and created new diagrams.  I sought, and was given, permission by Jean Rhys Bram to publish the new edition.  Sadly, within just a few years I needed to dispose of Ascella publications for health reasons, and very shortly afterwards the Ascella edition dropped out of print too. Since I no longer have any digital files, I am in the process of scanning and editing a hard copy, to recapture this text once again.  Having acquired a little knowledge of Latin myself in the interim, I am also seeing places where amendments or additional footnotes could be helpful. I will be including several chapters on Skyscript – which will be serialised over time, starting with book II, which lays out the basic concepts. Book I will not be included on Skyscript (at least not in the foreseeable future) but I am including a copy of that chapter here as a 15-page PDF download for Patreons who would like a copy. Note – there is no practical astrology in book I of the  Mathesis  – this acts as a Preface which presents arguments against contemporary critics and sceptics of astrology. The points of dispute are considered quite important for anyone wishing to understand or research the historical setting and development of astrology because Firmicus holds a remarkably severe Stoical stance which rejects free will in favour of determinism.  Because of the influence of this work, it is often claimed that all ancient astrology was deterministic, which was not the case in reality. In our first Skyscript discussion meeting to be held over Zoom (details to follow in the newsletter), I will open up exploration and discussion of the issue of fate and freewill in historical sources, and as part of that, I will be looking at some of the comments made in this chapter.   That’s all for now – as this is my very first email to Patrons, I am keeping my fingers crossed that this circulates just as it should! Deb

content_blocks.text: I want to thank you, again - your support has enlivened and enthused me,  and I am bursting with creative excitement – loving all the potential for creating a more ‘discerning’ reservoir of astro-info on the web.This is to let you know about one particular project I am working on, and to give you exclusive access to some of its content.I am currently partnering with Morgan Le Gall to improve the appearance and resources on the page that gives David McCann’s biography of Julius Firmicus.David McCann was a very unassuming yet talented classical scholar, a perfect gentleman who had pursued a life-long study of the history, theory and practice of astrology. I lost contact with David in the late 1990s and since he was an elderly man when I was young, I doubt I will be able to regain contact with him again.After Jean Rhys Bram’s English 1975 translation of Firmicus’sMathesishad been many years out of print, David took it on himself to retype the whole manuscript, in the hope that I would keep it in circulation through the small print publishing company I ran at the time (Ascella Publications).  As a classicist he was already very familiar with its content - he had learned his own astrology from a Latin edition of this work, so, in the process of retyping, he corrected various errors and made several rearrangements and improvements to Bram’s original text, whilst I worked on a new layout, did the final editing and indexing, and created new diagrams.  I sought, and was given, permission by Jean Rhys Bram to publish the new edition.  Sadly, within just a few years I needed to dispose of Ascella publications for health reasons, and very shortly afterwards the Ascella edition dropped out of print too.Since I no longer have any digital files, I am in the process of scanning and editing a hard copy, to recapture this text once again.  Having acquired a little knowledge of Latin myself in the interim, I am also seeing places where amendments or additional footnotes could be helpful. I will be including several chapters on Skyscript – which will be serialised over time, starting with book II, which lays out the basic concepts.Book I will not be included on Skyscript (at least not in the foreseeable future) but I am including a copy of that chapter here as a 15-page PDF download for Patreons who would like a copy.Note – there is no practical astrology in book I of theMathesis– this acts as a Preface which presents arguments against contemporary critics and sceptics of astrology. The points of dispute are considered quite important for anyone wishing to understand or research the historical setting and development of astrology because Firmicus holds a remarkably severe Stoical stance which rejects free will in favour of determinism.  Because of the influence of this work, it is often claimed that all ancient astrology was deterministic, which was not the case in reality.In our first Skyscript discussion meeting to be held over Zoom (details to follow in the newsletter), I will open up exploration and discussion of the issue of fate and freewill in historical sources, and as part of that, I will be looking at some of the comments made in this chapter.That’s all for now – as this is my very first email to Patrons, I am keeping my fingers crossed that this circulates just as it should!Deb
content_blocks.html:
I want to thank you, again - your support has enlivened and enthused me,  and I am bursting with creative excitement – loving all the potential for creating a more ‘discerning’ reservoir of astro-info on the web.

This is to let you know about one particular project I am working on, and to give you exclusive access to some of its content.

I am currently partnering with Morgan Le Gall to improve the appearance and resources on the page that gives David McCann’s biography of Julius Firmicus.

David McCann was a very unassuming yet talented classical scholar, a perfect gentleman who had pursued a life-long study of the history, theory and practice of astrology. I lost contact with David in the late 1990s and since he was an elderly man when I was young, I doubt I will be able to regain contact with him again.

After Jean Rhys Bram’s English 1975 translation of Firmicus’s Mathesis had been many years out of print, David took it on himself to retype the whole manuscript, in the hope that I would keep it in circulation through the small print publishing company I ran at the time (Ascella Publications).  As a classicist he was already very familiar with its content - he had learned his own astrology from a Latin edition of this work, so, in the process of retyping, he corrected various errors and made several rearrangements and improvements to Bram’s original text, whilst I worked on a new layout, did the final editing and indexing, and created new diagrams.  I sought, and was given, permission by Jean Rhys Bram to publish the new edition.  Sadly, within just a few years I needed to dispose of Ascella publications for health reasons, and very shortly afterwards the Ascella edition dropped out of print too.

Since I no longer have any digital files, I am in the process of scanning and editing a hard copy, to recapture this text once again.  Having acquired a little knowledge of Latin myself in the interim, I am also seeing places where amendments or additional footnotes could be helpful. I will be including several chapters on Skyscript – which will be serialised over time, starting with book II, which lays out the basic concepts.

Book I will not be included on Skyscript (at least not in the foreseeable future) but I am including a copy of that chapter here as a 15-page PDF download for Patreons who would like a copy.

Note – there is no practical astrology in book I of the Mathesis – this acts as a Preface which presents arguments against contemporary critics and sceptics of astrology. The points of dispute are considered quite important for anyone wishing to understand or research the historical setting and development of astrology because Firmicus holds a remarkably severe Stoical stance which rejects free will in favour of determinism.  Because of the influence of this work, it is often claimed that all ancient astrology was deterministic, which was not the case in reality.

In our first Skyscript discussion meeting to be held over Zoom (details to follow in the newsletter), I will open up exploration and discussion of the issue of fate and freewill in historical sources, and as part of that, I will be looking at some of the comments made in this chapter.  

That’s all for now – as this is my very first email to Patrons, I am keeping my fingers crossed that this circulates just as it should!

Deb

I want to thank you, again - your support has enlivened and enthused me,  and I am bursting with creative excitement – loving all the potential for creating a more ‘discerning’ reservoir of astro-info on the web.

This is to let you know about one particular project I am working on, and to give you exclusive access to some of its content.

I am currently partnering with Morgan Le Gall to improve the appearance and resources on the page that gives David McCann’s biography of Julius Firmicus.

David McCann was a very unassuming yet talented classical scholar, a perfect gentleman who had pursued a life-long study of the history, theory and practice of astrology. I lost contact with David in the late 1990s and since he was an elderly man when I was young, I doubt I will be able to regain contact with him again.

After Jean Rhys Bram’s English 1975 translation of Firmicus’s Mathesis had been many years out of print, David took it on himself to retype the whole manuscript, in the hope that I would keep it in circulation through the small print publishing company I ran at the time (Ascella Publications).  As a classicist he was already very familiar with its content - he had learned his own astrology from a Latin edition of this work, so, in the process of retyping, he corrected various errors and made several rearrangements and improvements to Bram’s original text, whilst I worked on a new layout, did the final editing and indexing, and created new diagrams.  I sought, and was given, permission by Jean Rhys Bram to publish the new edition.  Sadly, within just a few years I needed to dispose of Ascella publications for health reasons, and very shortly afterwards the Ascella edition dropped out of print too.

Since I no longer have any digital files, I am in the process of scanning and editing a hard copy, to recapture this text once again.  Having acquired a little knowledge of Latin myself in the interim, I am also seeing places where amendments or additional footnotes could be helpful. I will be including several chapters on Skyscript – which will be serialised over time, starting with book II, which lays out the basic concepts.

Book I will not be included on Skyscript (at least not in the foreseeable future) but I am including a copy of that chapter here as a 15-page PDF download for Patreons who would like a copy.

Note – there is no practical astrology in book I of the Mathesis – this acts as a Preface which presents arguments against contemporary critics and sceptics of astrology. The points of dispute are considered quite important for anyone wishing to understand or research the historical setting and development of astrology because Firmicus holds a remarkably severe Stoical stance which rejects free will in favour of determinism.  Because of the influence of this work, it is often claimed that all ancient astrology was deterministic, which was not the case in reality.

In our first Skyscript discussion meeting to be held over Zoom (details to follow in the newsletter), I will open up exploration and discussion of the issue of fate and freewill in historical sources, and as part of that, I will be looking at some of the comments made in this chapter.  

That’s all for now – as this is my very first email to Patrons, I am keeping my fingers crossed that this circulates just as it should!

Deb

I had tried to make it appear fully formed in an email, but the formatting was too complex and that proved impossible.  But I think it works really well as a PDF. I hope you enjoy it - lots of Skyscript news and a few substantial pieces that have been written exclusively for Skyscript patrons.  I aimed to give you something meaty to chew on regarding the Sun and Leo as we spend the next month basking in that sign. If you have any comments or constructive feedback please add them into this post. I look forward to catching up with some of you soon at the first Zoom meeting - details on page 7 of this file. All the best for now Deb

I've just realised that not everyone is getting the personal messages that I always send out to new Skyscript members. This message gives a welcome from me and explains how to access all the resources, and what your password is, etc. I make sure I message everyone as soon as I can - always within 24 hours of joining us.  If anyone has not received a copy of that message by email, perhaps check you are not missing any important info by logging into Patreon (it could be that email copy of the message went to your email spam folder, but it will still be visible to you in the messages area of the Patreon site). I would be interested to know who didn't get this welcome message - because if the problem is affecting many people, I will give up on the message area and email directly instead. Apologies, thanks and best wishes ! :) Deb
